Customers with valid EBT cards are eligible, and can qualify every year up to four times. Meanwhile, Wal-Mart is testing an automated 24-hour-a-day grocery-pickup kiosk for online orders.RELATED:Amazon's New Wal-Mart Assault: Prime Cut For Government-Aid RecipientsU.S. crude prices fell 5% on Wednesday after the Energy Information Administration announced that weekly U.S. crude stockpiles rose, defying analyst forecasts and separate tallies from the American Petroleum Institute and Platts. EIA also noted that gasoline inventories increased. U.S. crude production dipped but its strong uptrend is intact. Saudi Arabia and many other Gulf states cut diplomatic and economic ties with Qatar. Those tensions didn't lift crude prices, perhaps because traders see a higher risk that the OPEC production cut deal will break down.Tesla stock achieved a string of record highs, even as a broad swathe of auto-related companies tumbled after a prominent analyst slashed his outlook for U.S. vehicle sales for the next four years. Another analyst warned that a wave of optimism toward the electric-car maker could wane once investors begin to judge Tesla on product demand, growth and profit. Tesla did finally reversed from record highs on Friday.The IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index held steady at 51.3 in June, just below its level before Donald Trump's surprise election fueled a short-lived surge in spirits that carried the index to a 12-year high of 56.4 in February.The index held above the neutral 50 level, signaling optimism for the ninth straight month. Yet below the surface, June's poll reveal a modest rise in optimism about the near-term direction for the economy and deeper pessimism about the direction of federal policies.Dave & Buster's (PLAY) first-quarter earnings and revenue beat expectations, but same-store sales missed. Still, the arcade and sports bar ratcheted up the low end of its full-year revenue outlook. Dave & Buster's large amusements segment — which includes games like skee-ball and a life-size Rock 'Em Sock 'Em Robots — outperformed its dining segment. And analysts see more opportunity for the chain to move into spaces once occupied by struggling retailers. Dave & Buster shares hit record highs, but ended the week barely higher.Health-savings-account manager HealthEquity (HQY) topped first-quarter estimates. However, as Wells Fargo analyst Peter Costa noted, the company's EPS was helped by a lower-than-expected tax rate due to changes in accounting standards, and that the company expects higher service-cost spending on fraud prevention to hit gross margins. Still, management was optimistic about its planned acquisition of BenefitGuard — a move it hopes will help it compete in the 401(k) and retirement business.Bluebird Bio (BLUE) stock rocketed 26% in three days after it unveiled strong data for its drug, dubbed bb2121, during the American Society of Clinical Oncology on Monday in Chicago. The same conference saw Loxo Oncology (LOXO) stock launch 43.2% on Monday following strong data for its drug larotrectinib which shrunk tumors in a number of different cancers. Merck (MRK) and Incyte (INCY) had success in a combination of Keytruda and epacadostat in two lung cancer patients, though Bristol-Myers Squibb (BMY) reported its Opdivo and Yervoy showed little benefit over Opdivo as a monotherapy. Analysts saw Tesaro (TSRO) as having stronger data for its breast cancer drug vs. AstraZeneca (AZN).Despite assurances from Boeing (BA), the Air Force thinks the KC-46 refueling tanker will be delayed again. Boeing already pushed back the delivery date from March to August to "late 2017" over development issues, but Lt. Gen. Arnold Bunch, military deputy in Air Force acquisition, said he believes the deliveries will be "a little to the right" of that target. On the commercial side, Lion Air will reportedly be a Boeing 737 Max 10 launch customer. Indian full-service carrier Jet Airways also is reportedly in talks to purchase 50 narrow-body jets worth at least $5.6 billion and is leaning toward the 737 Max 10 or Max 200 vs. the Airbus (EADSY) A321neo, according to Bloomberg.Gigamon (GIMO) hired Goldman Sachs to explore strategic options a few weeks after activist investor Elliott Management took a 15% stake in the maker of communications-network appliances and security gear. Gigamon could draw interest from Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) or private equity firms, one analyst said.Software maker Coupa (COUP) reported a narrower fiscal Q1 loss with revenue rising 41% to $41 million, topping consensus estimates. For the current quarter, Coupa forecast a per-share loss of 19 cents, in-line with estimates, and revenue of about $41.5 million, slightly above views.Snap (SNAP) fell 14% on reports that Snapchat user growth has been slowing in the second quarter.Okta (OKTA) reported a smaller-than-expected loss and above-forecast revenue growth in its identity-security software stock's first report since coming public in April. Okta shares rose nearly 9% through Thursday, hitting a record high and breaking out of an initial IPO base. But shares reversed Friday, ending the week little changed.Thor Industries (THO) EPS rose 40% and revenue climbed 57% to $2.02 billion, beating on both. The maker of RVs and mobile homes rose about 9%.General Motors (GM) shareholders overwhelmingly rejected an activist investor's call to create two share classes, one focused on growth and another on dividends. They also re-elected all 11 board members, rejecting three nominees put forward by Greenlight Capital's David Einhorn. GM shares were down less than 1% for the week.G-III (GIII), which owns Donna Karan, G.H. Bass and other apparel brands, shot up 29% for the week. The clothing manufacturer and distributor swung to a loss of 18 cents but beat views for a 37-cent per-share loss. Revenue gained 16% to $529 million, easily topping.

XThe major stock indexes held modest gains with just over one hour remaining in Thursday's session on a busy day for headlines. Former FBI Director James Comey's testimony in front of the Senate Intelligence committee got a lot of attention. So did the European Central Bank's monetary policy statement and the U.K. general election.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 edged lower, while the Nasdaq composite inched higher. The small-cap Russell 2000 surged 1.3%. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq was tracking higher than Wednesday's levels.Goldman Sachs (GS) and JPMorgan (JPM) outperformed in the Dow with gains of around 1.5%.Financials turned in solid showings as the 10-year Treasury yield edged higher to 2.20%. East West Bancorp (EWBC) jumped 4% to 56.73 as it vies for a breakout over a 57.34 buy point. Volume was on pace to be slightly below average.In the stock market today, beaten-down department-store operators outperformed on news that Nordstrom (JWN) is considering going private. Shares jumped 9% but were well off session highs. Department stores have been hit hard by selling in recent months as fundamentals deteriorate because of the continued boom in online shopping.Inside the IBD 50, several names outperformed again, including Alibaba (BABA). Shares soared 11% after the company significantly raised its sales guidance for the current year. Shares of Yahoo (YHOO), which still owns a piece of Alibaba, jumped nearly 9% on the news.Meanwhile, IBD 50 component Nvidia (NVDA) soared 6% to 158.29 on bullish comments from Citigroup. The chip firm hasn't looked back after a bullish base breakout in May over a 121.02 buy point.Thursday's session was light on breakouts, but Sierra Wireless (SWIR) delivered one. The stock vaulted 6% to 31.38, clearing a 29.59 cup-with-handle buy point. The small cap is a formidable player in the Internet of Things market, where everyday devices are connected to the internetTTM Technologies (TTMI) cleared a flat base with a conventional entry at 17.96. Shares jumped 5% to 18.17.RELATED:Alibaba Soars On This Stunning Growth Forecast This Financial Giant Is A Buy As Banks Test Key LevelsNvidia Stock Could Double In Bull Case; eBay, PayPal Targets Upped

XThe Nordstrom (JWN) family is exploring the possibility of a "'going private transaction' involving the acquisition by the Group of 100% of the outstanding shares of common stock of the Company," said the company in an official statement.Nordstrom's board has assembled a special committee of independent directors to act on behalf of the department store chain regarding the exploration, it said.Shares jumped as much as 18% in morning trade on the stock market today but faded to close up 10.3% at 44.64, dropping back below their 50-day average. Other department stores reversed lower after early rallies, with Macy's (M) down 0.2%, Kohl's (KSS) 2.3% and J.C. Penney (JCP) 4.8%.Department stores have suffered in recent years as fast fashion options like Forever 21 proliferate and e-commerce giant Amazon (AMZN) continues to encroach on brick-and-mortar turf.Macy's warned on Tuesday that gross margins would be worse than projected in February, sending its shares and those of Kohl's, J.C. Penney and Nordstrom sharply lower.Separately Thursday, Canada's Hudson's Bay, which also owns Saks Fifth Avenue, announced late Thursday that it will cut 2,000 jobs in North America, including cuts announced in February. Hudson's Bay trades in Toronto but not in the U.S.Amazon rose 20 cents to 1,010.27, near record highs.RELATED:Macy's Triggers New Retail Rout On Gross Margins WarningDeath Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnMacy's Shocker, Other Results Trigger Broad Retail RoutMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will Work

XStocks staged a mixed open Thursday, as oil and gold prices eased and investors kept a wary eye on events in Washington D.C. and London.The Nasdaq wobbled in and out of negative territory in opening trade, while the  S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average defended very narrow gains.The morning's headline news is former FBI Director James Comey's testimony before the Senate Intelligence Committee, scheduled for 10 a.m. ET, as well as Parliamentary elections underway in the U.K. and a policy meeting of the European Central Bank.  Markets in Europe were mixed: London's FTSE 100 shed 0.3% while Frankfurt's DAX held a 0.3% gain and the CAC-40 in Paris gave up early gains and slipped 0.1%.Wal-Mart (WMT) popped 1% in early action to lead the Dow industrials, Walt Disney (DIS) brought up the rear with a 0.6% loss.Alibaba Group Holdings (BABA) vaulted 12% higher, breaking out above a 126.50 buy point in a three-weeks tight pattern. The online retail giant, also an IBD 50 and Leaderboard stock, released full-year earnings guidance for a 45% to 49% gain, well above analyst expectations, at the company's investors day conference in Hangzhou, China.

Online retail peer JD.com (JD) jumped 6%, breaking out above a 42.07 buy point in a three-weeks tight pattern.Yahoo (YHOO) surged 9% at the start of trade, retaking its November, 2014 peak and moving to a new high. Most of the gain was probably tied to Yahoo's 15% stake in Alibaba. News reports also said late Wednesday, however, that Verizon (VZ) planned to layoff up to 1,000 workers as part of its $4.8 billion acquisition of Yahoo. Verizon shares were unchanged.China-based search engine Baidu (BIDU) edged up 08% in heavy trade, just enough to retake a 188.64 buy point in a three-month cup-with-handle base, after briefly clearing that entry in May.Tissue regeneration tech play Polarityte (COOL) jetted 15% higher in massive trade, breaking out past a 19 buy point in a seven-week cup base. The company reported pre-clinical results showing its SkinTE product successfully regenerated hair follicles and skin in third-degree burn wounds. The company said it plans to launch a human trial in the third quarter.Chip stocks were active in premarket trade as Advanced Micro Devices (AMD), a leader in Monday and Tuesday's sessions, added 0.8% at the open. Apple (AAPL) announced at its Worldwide Developers Conference on Monday that its upcoming iMac Pro, a $5000 device, will utilize AMD chips. AMD also reported very strong demand coming from the video gaming and crypto-currency-related markets. AMD capped Wednesday's session 21% above an early May low, back above 10-week support and trying to build the right side of a 3-month consolidation.High-end department store chain Nordstrom (JWN) bolted 15% higher on reports that Nordstrom family members and executives have begun exploring options to take the company private.Mazor Robotics (MZOR) swerved 8% lower. The maker of automated surgical guidance systems had soared 84% from a March breakout to a mid-May high. But it has pulled back for the past two weeks and ended Wednesday just above its 10-week moving average.The number of first-time unemployment claims fell to 245,000 in the week ended June 3, the Labor Department reported.  Economists had projected a deeper dip, to 241,000 filings. The department also revised higher its prior week estimate, to 255,000 claims, vs. its initial 245,000 tally.The Commerce Department's April wholesale inventories numbers are due out at 10 a.m. ET.Oil prices edged further south, with West Texas Intermediate down 0.7% and just above $45 a barrel, after selling off more than 5% on Wednesday. Gold slipped 0.6%, to below $1,286 an ounce. The dollar gained, and bonds slipped, lifting the 10-year-yield 2 basis points to 2.19%.In Japan, a downward revision that put first-quarter GDP at 1% — down from initial estimates of 2.2% — disappointed markets and sent Tokyo's Nikkei 225 down 0.4%. China's markets climbed, with benchmarks in both Shanghai and Hong Kong rising 0.3%.RELATED:3 Big Events, 2 China Plays, 1 Bitcoin Chip Stock: Investing Action Plan

XFor the second time in less than a month, Macy's (M) triggered a big sell-off in department store stocks, after warning on Tuesday that gross margins would be worse than those forecast in February.During the struggling retailer's investor meeting, CFO Karen Hoguet said that full-year gross margin was on pace to come in 60 to 80 basis points lower than margins last year, as Macy's struggles to move inventory from its shelves, according to reports.Macy's tumbled 8.2% to 21.90, crashing to the lowest since February 2011. Kohl's (KSS) lost 5.75%, hitting its worst levels since June 2016. J.C. Penney (JCP) retreated 4%. Nordstrom (JWN) fell 3.7% to its lowest close in 11 months.Sears Holdings (SHLD), which faces "going concern" issues, sank 2.5%.The darker forecast follows another quarter of reckoning for physical stores, as more people shop online, especially at Amazon (AMZN).Macy's bleak Q1 earnings report and guidance last month spurred a big drop in department stores and other retailers, adding to concerns that brick-and-mortar chains can't combat the massive shift in how people shop.Along with Amazon and other e-commerce sites, stores like Macy's, Kohl's, J.C. Penney and Sears have also been gutted by off-price retailers and fast-fashion.During the investor day meeting, Macy's said cost cuts and managing its mix of owned vs. leased properties would help margins in the future.RELATED:Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnMacy's Shocker, Other Results Trigger Broad Retail RoutMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkAmazon's New Wal-Mart Assault: Prime Cut For Government-Aid Recipients

Biotechs and software led a solid Nasdaq advance, while the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 index hit record highs. Boeing (BA) announced a slew of Paris Air Show orders, while oil prices kept falling. The Fed cleared big banks in their annual stress tests while China cracked down on Weibo (WB). Amazon (AMZN) spooked more retailers.X The Nasdaq rose 1.8% for the week as biotechs and other medicals soared on eased fears about price controls and also in reaction to the Senate GOP health bill. Celgene (CELG) was among the biotech breakouts, while Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) soared out of buy range. Desktop software also was a big winner, with Oracle (ORCL) breaking out on earnings. Amazon fears intensified for apparel and sporting goods stories. The Dow industrials and S&P 500 index hit record highs Monday, but pared gains amid weakness in oil and retail stocks. The Dow finished fractionally higher while the S&P 500  rose 0.2%.Biotech stocks surged 10% this week as concerns that President Trump will tamp down on drug prices began to subside. Big winners in the rally included Regeneron Pharmaceuticals (REGN) and Celgene (CELG), which popped 12.5% and nearly 10%, respectively. Clovis Oncology (CLVS) spiked58% after strong trial data suggested a much-wider use for its ovarian cancer drug. Analysts called for "growth" stocks to gain the most and one sees the rally continuing another 15%.Traditional drug giants also fared well, with Novartis (NVS) breaking out to a buy point and Merck (MRK) nearing an entry.Boeing (BA) beat out Airbus (EADSY) on commercial jet orders at the 2017 Paris Air Show, an event typically won by the European aerospace giant. Boeing said it had "incremental orders and commitments" of 571 airplanes, valued at $74.8 billion at list prices. But analysts said "a staggering 64%" of Boeing's orders at the show weren't firm. Airbus said it booked firm orders of 144 planes valued at $18.5 billion and memorandums of understanding for 182 aircraft valued at $21.2 billion. Analysts weren't expecting many deals in Paris, but orders were double the $50 billion seen at last year's show in Farnborough, England. Boeing shares rose about 3% for the week, hitting new highs. Airbus set a record high Monday, but pared its weekly gain to 0.9%.RELATED: Why Boeing's Paris Air Show Orders Are 'Staggering''Hybrid' Design For New Boeing Midrange Jet Could Hit This Sweet SpotWhy Lockheed May Move F-16 Production To India From TexasOracle (ORCL) earnings easily topped views while revenue advanced 3% as the software giant's overall cloud revenue shot up 64% vs. a year earlier. Oracle had been a latecomer to the on-demand, cloud software shift but the transition is in full force now. Shares surged 13%, breaking out to a record high. Meanwhile, two other Software-Database leaders soared to record highs on stronger-than-expected earnings. Adobe Systems (ADBE) raised Q3 guidance after reporting a 44% EPS gain for its fiscal Q2. Red Hat (RHT) EPS climbed 12% in its fiscal Q1 while revenue rose 19%. The open-source Linux software provider also gave bullish current-quarter guidance. Adobe rose 5.5% while Red Hat climbed 13.2%.Crude oil prices fell to 10-month lows during the week amid continued oversupply concerns. Weekly U.S. crude stockpiles fell 2.45 million barrels, the Energy Information Administration said, double what was expected. But domestic crude production nudged up to 9.35 million barrels per day. Meanwhile, Libyan oil production rose sharply after a dispute ended with a German oil company. Exports from Nigeria are expected to hit 226,000 BPD in August vs. 164,000 BPD in July, according to Reuters. Saudi Arabia's Deputy Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman was appointed as heir to the kingdom's throne and is widely expected to continue current oil policies. He was a major force behind Riyadh's Saudi Vision 2030 reform initiative aimed at curbing the country's reliance on crude.RELATED:Oil Reverses Sharply Lower On Supply FearsJPMorgan (JPM), Bank of America (BAC) and the nation's biggest global banks would have enough capital to continue lending in an economic meltdown, the first round of the Federal Reserve's annual stress-results showed. None of the 34 banks tested had key capital levels below the minimum set by the Fed. But bank stocks generally edged lower Friday. Wall Street's attention will turn to results from the second portion of the exam that comes out on Wednesday. That portion will determine what the banks can give in buybacks and dividends and ultimately whether the firms pass or fail the tests on quantitative and qualitative grounds.JPMorgan, BofA, Goldman, Citi, Wells Fargo Pass Fed's Stress TestChina ordered Weibo (WB) and two other online platforms to shut down audiovisual streaming, presumably for user content that violated the country's political standards. Weibo tumbled 6.1% on Thursday, with majority-owner Sina Corp. (SINA), lost 4.8%. Alibaba (BABA), which owns a big minority stake in the Twitter (TWTR)-like Weibo, edged lower. Momo (MOMO) and YY (YY), two social media firms with a lot of streaming video, sold off initially but Momo closed up and YY pared losses. Sina, Momo and YY are all IBD 50 stocks.RELATED:Weibo Crackdown Spurs Selling, But Not Panic, In China InternetsAmazon struck fear in more retail groups, slamming many apparel and sporting goods chains. The e-commerce giant announced Amazon Prime Wardrobe, a home try-on system that lets users have three or more items shipped to them for free to try on at home, then be charged for what they keep. That hit Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN), TJX (TJX) and more. Meanwhile, Bloomberg sources said Nike (NKE) would sell footwear directly on Amazon via a brand-registry program, sending shares of already-reeling Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Foot Locker (FL) and others sharply lower. But Finish Line (FINL) rebounded Friday despite mixed quarterly results.Meanwhile, Whole Foods Market (WFM) pushed a little further beyond the 42-a-share takeover price from Amazon, leading some to wonder if another bidder could be ready to emerge with an even bigger offer than $13.7 billion. Barclays said it "would not be surprised is there is a bidding war," and JPMorgan analysts have pegged Wal-Mart (WMT) as a possible contender. But Reuters reported late Friday that Wal-Mart is not planning a Whole Foods bid. Whole Foods closed the week up 0.6% at 42.94 after hitting 43.84 Friday afternoon.RELATED:Here's The Latest Group Having An Amazon-Induced Anxiety AttackPrime Wardrobe: Is This How Amazon Kills Macy's In Fashion Game?Uber Technologies founder Travis Kalanick resigned as chief executive officer following a shareholder revolt. The ride-hailing company had been exposed as having a workplace culture that included sexual harassment and discrimination. Uber also has been losing U.S. market share to Lyft.Twitter (TWTR) stock rose 11% as a bullish research report said the struggling company has improved its video strategy and execution. The report came on the same day Twitter announced a way for people to earn money by streaming live on its Periscope video service. Snapchat-operator Snap (SNAP) was under increased pressure from the Instagram Stories feature by Facebook (FB), which has grown to 250 million users, vs. 166 million for Snapchat. Snap is trading close to its IPO price of 17.Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) surged nearly 24% for the week as it launched its latest server processors for data centers. AMD's new Epyc server chips will compete with processors from industry leader Intel (INTC). Joining AMD at a launch event in Austin, Texas, were customers and partners backing Epyc, including Microsoft (MSFT) Azure, Baidu (BIDU), Dell Technologies (DVMT) and Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE). Intel shares fell to a 2017 low.Shares of FedEx (FDX) rose 2.3% for the week, hitting a record high and moving out of buy range as the package delivery giant easily topped expectations for its fiscal fourth quarter Tuesday, shaking of EPS misses in the last two quarters. Earnings climbed 29% on a 21% jump in revenue to $15.7 billion. Investments to modernize its aircraft fleet and expand ground operations paid off, FedEx, while guiding full-year profit high. Rival UPS announced Monday that it will charge retailers an extra fee for holiday deliveries, while FedEx said it would consider that. Both shipping giants could be challenged as key customer Amazon (AMZN) expands its own delivery services.RELATED:FedEx Easily Tops Q4 Earnings, Revenue Forecasts; Guides Profit HighStrong SUV and truck sales helped to drive an across-the-board beat Wednesday for used-car superstore CarMax (KMX). First-quarter EPS climbed almost 26% year over year to $1.13 on a 10.1% rise in revenue to $4.54 billion. Total unit sales of used vehicles  jumped 14.1%. But even with large and medium SUVs and trucks accounting for a bigger share of the mix, the average used vehicle price fell 1.9% vs. a year earlier, accelerating from a 1.6% drop in the prior quarter. A flood of off-lease cars is hitting pricing, one reason while new-car sales are slumping. CarMax rose 1.7% in an up-and-down week.MSCI (MSCI) on Tuesday finally greenlighted the inclusion of mainland China stocks in its key emerging markets index. Wall Street had been closely watching the decision, since several funds — including the $32 billion iShares Emerging Markets ETF (EEM) — track or are benchmarked to that index. China's weight in the benchmark will jump to upward of 40% from the current 26%. The move surprised the markets; MSCI had given a red light to mainland stocks or "A shares" on three previous tries.EQT Corp. (EQT) agreed to buy Rice Energy (RICE) for around $6.7 billion. The deal, set to close in Q4, would create the U.S.' largest natural-gas producer and strengthen EQT's position in the Marcellus and Utica shale regions.Accenture (ACN) reported in-line fiscal Q3 profit and reported top-line growth slightly above views as new digital, cloud and security products and services reached 50% of revenue but management commentary on weakness in the health care market sent shares down.

Shares of Sears Canada (SRSC) crashed Wednesday following reports that the ailing retailer could be headed for liquidation after moving to seek protection from creditors, deepening the wounds suffered by brick-and-mortar chains as Amazon.com (AMZN) continues to pluck customers from malls.Sears Canada could have trouble selling off its locations to a single purchaser, as many of those locations are in lower-tier shopping centers, Bloomberg said.Sears Canada earlier this month raised "significant doubt" over its ability to continue operating after struggling to obtain sufficient financing. Meanwhile, Sears Holdings (SHLD), which owns 12% of Sears Canada, warned in March that "substantial doubt" existed over whether it could survive.Sears Canada shares tumbled nearly 20% to 47 cents on the stock market today. Sears Holdings dropped 5.4% to 6.43. J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 5.7%, Dillard's (DDS) dropped 2.3% and Kohl's (KSS) lost 1.3%. Mid-tier Macy's (M) slid 2.3% while upscale Nordstrom (JWN) edged down 0.3% after both sold off Tuesday on news that Amazon will start a service that allows customers to receive clothes at home and try them on before buying them.IBD'S TAKE: Running a retailer in recent years has become a lot more about managing real estate. Macy's is even looking at how to rework its parking lots.A liquidation of Sears Canada would follow Target's (TGT) plans, announced in 2015, to exit Canada, and it would join a growing list of retailers in bankruptcy or on the brink.In March, discount department-store chain Gordmans Stores filed for bankruptcy with plans to liquidate. Wet Seal, BCBG Maxzria and Payless ShoeSource have filed for bankruptcy in recent months as well.In April, women's apparel chain Bebe (BEBE) said it would close all its stores by the end of May to become an online-only retailer, and Vince (VNCE) said it had "substantial doubt about the company's ability to continue" over leverage debt ratio concerns.Sears Canada's potential move toward creditor protection would also come as Sears' legal disputes with suppliers increasingly occur out in the open.Sears Holdings has sued two suppliers of Craftsman tools in the past two months over their agreements to deliver products to the retailer. Sears this month settled with the first of those companies, One World, which Sears CEO Eddie Lampert said had tried to "embarrass us in the media to force us to let them out of their contract."RELATED:Amazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, EateriesWhat Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will Work

XWhole Foods Market (WFM) shares continued to climb Monday, signaling increased belief that someone else could top the $13.7 billion Amazon.com (AMZN) deal for the high-end grocer.Barclays analyst Karen Short said she "would not be surprised if there is a bidding war" for Whole Foods, upgrading the high-end grocer to overweight from equal weight and raising her price target by 26% to 48, well above Amazon's announced acquisition price of 42 a share.A fresh bid could be as high as 57 a share, Short says, giving a big potential upside. Meanwhile, the regulatory risk for Amazon's deal is low, so the potential downside from buying Whole Foods shares is low in her view. And beyond fending off the e-commerce giant, Short added that a strategic retail bidder could create up to $600 million in synergies.Is this a plausible scenario? Barclays isn't the only one that seems to think so. Oppenheimer upped its price target to 45 on Friday, not long after the deal was announced, on the grounds that the deal undervalued Whole Foods' prospects and "powerful brand." Analysts there see a mid-40s-range buyout as more appropriate.Shares of Whole Foods Market rose 1.3% to 43.22 in the stock market today — even after closing up 29.1% on Friday to 42.68.So who, exactly, could pop out of the woodwork to beat Amazon's $13.7 billion offer? In Short's view, the list of suspects is long: "all retailers that sell food and compete with (Amazon) because we think most have too much to lose not to bid." Kroger (KR), Target (TGT) and Wal-Mart (WMT) are on that list.The nation's grocery chains and big-box stores have already lost a lot since Friday, as shares of Kroger, Target, Wal-Mart and Costco (COST) suffered mightily from the merger announcement.(The only grocery retailer that isn't getting further kicked Monday on news of the deal is Sprouts Farmers Market (SFM) — and that's likely because Oppenheimer pegged it as the next possible takeover target. Sprouts rose 3.5% on Monday.)Kroger rose 1.6%, but after crashing nearly 28% last week. Wal-Mart edged up 0.3% while Target fell 1.7%.Costco continues to suffer Monday, falling 2.7% to a 2017 low and undercutting its 200-day moving average. Deutsche Bank downgraded Costco to hold, citing intensifying competition from efforts by Amazon and Wal-Mart to ramp up their in-store and online business.The Whole Foods acquisition "represents a game changer with (Costco's) competitive moat of grocery under greater threat while its digital platform lags peers, putting membership renewal at higher risk for decline," wrote Deutsche's Paul Trussell. He cut his price target on Costco to 172 from 187.Still, the membership warehouse's traffic and margins are solid, he said. And Cowen's Oliver Chen, who has an outperform rating on Costco, believes the retailer's vertical integration and low prices will continue to be brick-and-mortar traffic drivers.For his part, Chen isn't so sure that Costco would be interested in — or Target would be capable of — proposing a buyout for Whole Foods, and Wal-Mart might only have interest insomuch as a buyout would be a defensive measure. But he is wondering about Amazon's next shopping spree."We believe there are likely capabilities, routes to market, and specialized brand propositions at retailers which could be synergistically combined with largely pure-play online retailers such as (Amazon)," wrote Chen.Who? Why, Nordstrom (JWN), Urban Outfitters (URBN), Ascena Retail Group (ASNA) or even RH (RH) (formerly known as Restoration Hardware).Those might be some pretty unexpected names for a potential Amazon takeover — but then again, so was Whole Foods.RELATED:Are These Amazon's Next Five Targets?What Amazon's Whole Foods Deal Means For RetailAmazon-Whole Foods Merger Could Be 'Category Killer' For Food, Eateries

XA bruising session Friday left stocks mostly lower and tech investors recovering from the Nasdaq's second-worst session of the year.The Nasdaq ended down 1.8%, while the S&P 500 held to a 0.1% loss. The Dow held its ground, closing 0.4% higher.A hat trick of negatives hit tech stocks at the end of a confusing news week. A report released late Thursday by Bank of America concluded that the tech sector currently "trades at its highest relative multiple since the Tech Bubble." The BofA report alone wasn't enough to restrain the Nasdaq early progress Friday, with the index hauling in a new high, but peaking in the first 45 minutes of trade.IBD 50 stock and recent highflier Nvidia (NVDA) appears to have helped trigger the slide, after a report from short-selling specialist Citron warned of weakness in the chipmaker's core gaming businesses. It also called the price target hike assessed Thursday by Citigroup on Nvidia "irresponsibly bullish."Nvidia dived 6.5% in heavy trade, despite a rebound off lows in afternoon trade. Shares remained extended above a 121.02 buy point but the reversal came in the highest volume of the stock's run, a bad sign.The move sent chip stocks sprawling, with IBD's three chip-related groups posting three of the session's four worst losses among industry groups. Ichor Holdings (ICHR), Nova Measurement (NVMI) and Brooks Instruments (BRKS) falling sharply. Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) and Cirrus Logic (CRUS) caved more than 5%. Macom Technology Solutions (MTSI) suffered a 7% loss.The tech sell-off broadened on reports Friday that Goldman Sachs called into question the what it named the FAAMG group of stocks — Facebook (FB), Apple (AAPL), Amazon.com (AMZN), Microsoft (MSFT) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) — declaring the group in a "valuation air pocket." Goldman said the group was due for a pause, and had been inappropriately valued as stable, staple issues, acting as key drivers of the Nasdaq 100 and S&P 500 this year.The combination sent technology industry groups to 19 of Friday's 20 worst performances among all 197 groups tracked by IBD.  The only non-technology industry in that lineup, automakers, were dragged by the heavy-volume 3% loss in the industry's most techish name, Tesla (TSLA).There were winners on Friday.The Dow gained ground, hauled higher by Pfizer's (PFE) 3% advance and gains of better than 2% from JPMorgan (JPM) and Chevron (CVX). Apple tanked more than 4%, but found support at its 10-week moving average. Microsoft dropped 2%.Dillard's (DDS) spiked 10%. J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) vaulted 7% each, after the announcement on Thursday that Nordstrom (JWN) was considering a deal to be taken private sent its shares up 10%. The high-end department store gained 6% in heavy trade on Friday.Makers of drilling rigs and equipment, and international oil exploration names rebounded after Thursday's harsh sell-off. Oil prices warmed ever-so-slightly, leaving West Texas intermediate up less than a half percent, still well below $46 a barrel and down almost 4% for the week.Heavy construction firms also found some love on Friday, the last day of President Trump's official "infrastructure week" on the bully pulpit. The President laid out some specific numbers for the first time earlier in the week, proposing to stir $1 trillion in total infrastructure spending by throwing $200 billion in federal moneys into the kitty for projects. Nearly every name in the industry group gained Friday, led by Layne Christiansen's (LAYN) 17% rebound.RELATED:Don't Miss These Three Breakouts: What's Taking Tech Stocks Down? Volatility Fear Gauge Hits 24-Year Low: Why You Should Worry

X A brutal retail earnings season walloped department stores and knocked around the shares of all but a few major names, such as Wal-Mart (WMT) and Target (TGT), as retail's ongoing existential crisis flails on.Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which reports late Thursday, is something of an outlier, with consistent quarterly beats and double-digit same-store sales growth at a time when other stores are posting declines or mild single-digit gains.Shares have generally made modest moves, with the stock rising in line with the S&P 500 over the last nine months. But Ulta has had big swings in the session following after-the-close earnings reports, with shares getting punished for two of the last three quarters, even when the retailer has posted a beat-and-raise quarter.Investors are extra jittery this time around: Ahead of Thursday's results, shares fell 3.5% to 280.51 in the stock market today on a downgrade to hold from buy from Edward Jones, diving below their 289.37 buy point. Before Wednesday's tumble, Ulta stock has nearly doubled since February of last year to an all-time high of 301.40 in early May, with shares testing the 300 price mark in recent weeks."While we expect profit margins still have some room to expand, we do believe it will become more difficult over the longer term as more business shifts to online," wrote Brian Yarbrough of Edward Jones. "Online sales have lower profit margins than sales in the stores."He otherwise sounded positive on the company, calling it "one of the most compelling growth stories in the retail landscape due to its store-growth opportunity and because it operates in an attractive industry and has the potential to realize further profit expansion."For Q1, profit is expected to rise 24% to $1.80 a share on a 19% revenue rise to $1.27 billion. Expect laser-focus on same-store sales growth, a closely watched metric in the retail space.Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy, who rates the stock overweight, expects 11.5% in comparable-sales growth, a tick higher than Street views.IBD'S TAKE: Need a refresher? Ulta Beauty has reported same-store sales growth of 16.6%, 16.7%, 14.4% and 15.2% in the most recent four quarters. Consensus is for 11% comp growth in Q1, says Piper Jaffray. There are reasons why Ulta and other specialty beauty retailers haven't succumbed to the Amazon Effect.Like off-price stores, the beauty sector frequently gets a call-out for being impervious to Amazon's (AMZN) offensive tactics in the retail sphere. Experts chalk it up to the in-store experience, the test-and-trial nature of beauty products and robust rewards programs, among other factors.Murphy cited confidence in Ulta's loyalty program and indicated that Ulta is likely to benefit from the decline of department stores, noting that only J.C. Penney (JCP) and Nordstrom (JWN) are notching cosmetic sales gains. Plus, the firm's biannual teen survey revealed that Ulta was gaining "considerable share" as a go-to shopping hot spot.J.C. Penney in particular has benefited from its Sephora shops-in-shops, and said earlier in the month that it will open another 16 in-store Sephoras in June, with plans to open 70 new locations of the upscale makeup retailer in 2017. That will bring its end-of-year total to 650 shops, in 75% of all J.C. Penney stores.Ulta Beauty offered up light Q1 guidance in March. But that doesn't worry some analysts."Ulta has beaten its sales guidance in all but one quarter since (the first quarter of 2010) as one of the best guiders we cover," wrote Instinet analyst Simeon Siegel in March, following the company's most recent earnings report. "We expect this to prove conservative yet again."RELATED:Why Ulta Beauty Shares Are Sinking Out Of Buy Range Ahead Of EarningsUlta Beauty Shares Break Out As Estee Lauder Pops On EarningsOPEC Meeting, Ulta Beauty, Best Buy, Momo Lead Investing Action PlanIs Ulta Beauty Too Good To Be True?Ulta Beauty Earnings, Sales Strong, But Guidance Isn't Pretty

XThe stock market opened higher, but quickly reversed lower in morning trading as investors digested the European Central Bank's actions early Thursday and ex-FBI Director James Comey began his congressional testimony. The ECB left interest rates unchanged, but removed a reference of possibly cutting rates further. The Nasdaq's early gains turned into 0.1% loss, the S&P 500 also slipped into negative trade, while the Dow Jones industrial average stuck close to its break-even mark. Among the Dow industrials, Nike (NKE) and financial component JPMorgan (JPM) paced the advancers with gains of about 1% each.In early trading, the blue chip index's big laggards were Walt Disney (DIS) and Merck (MRK). Both fell 1%.On the S&P 500, department store retailers were the best performing stocks in the stock market today with Nordstrom (JWN) up more than 16%. Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) rose 3.5% and 2.7%, respectively.On the downside, Borg Warner (BWA) declined 2.2%, while Snap On (SNA) fell 1.9%.Chinese e-commerce giant Alibaba (BABA) announced that it expects fiscal-2018 revenue growth to be in the 45% to 49% range, well above analyst expectations. Shares surged over 11% early Thursday. Other Chinese stocks followed suit, but were volatile. Competitor JD.com (JD) jumped 4.2%. Online gamer NetEase (NTES) moved up 0.9%. But internet stock Sina (SINA) and Weibo (WB) dropped 0.5% and 2.3%, respectively.Recent issue Okta's (OKTA) Q1 results came in above analyst estimates late Wednesday, causing the cloud security software provider to trade almost 6% higher. Shares are just above a 27 IPO-base entry.Action in the IBD 50 was mixed in early trade. New Leaderboard member HealthEquity (HQY) rose 3.3% and Ichor Holdings (ICHR) moved up 1.8%.On the downside, China education stocks New Oriental Education (EDU) and TAL Education (TAL) declined 4.2% and 2.6%. Entertainment eatery Dave & Buster's (PLAY) dropped over 2%.RELATED:Alibaba Soars After Predicting 45%-49% Revenue Growth This YearDow Jones Industrial Average And Dow Stocks: News And AnalysisOkta Beats Views In First Report As Public Company, Stock RisesEuropean Central Bank Takes Baby Step Toward Curbing Stimulus; Draghi To FollowBest Chinese Stocks To Buy And Watch

To the ever-expanding list of Things Uber Is Disrupting, add malls and their parking lots.At Macy's (M) investor day on Tuesday, Doug Sesler, executive vice president for real estate, suggested that the increased use of Uber had led to a decrease in the need for the vast stretches of land reserved for mall-customer parking."We're all talking about driverless cars, we're talking about the increased use of Uber," he said. "The fact of the matter is we don't need the massive parking lots that we needed in the 1970s."Macy's has been bruised by retail's woes in the era of Amazon.com (AMZN) and a reinvigorated Wal-Mart (WMT). It's thrown a variety of ideas at the wall to make use of its stripped-out floor space and 130-plus million square feet of real estate, and half-filled parking lots could offer a new option.Sesler said that when Macy's owns store space, they also typically own parking space with it. He said those swaths of pavement can be used for other retail space – a Starbucks (SBUX) at the corner of a parking lot, he suggested – or residential, office or hotel space.The company has formed an alliance with Brookfield Asset Management (BAM), a real estate company, to look at different ways to use its stretches of real estate.Macy's has also considered bolting restaurants onto the outside of its big-box locations to generate traffic and add atmosphere and rental income. The company has put office space above its stores in Seattle and is marketing the upper portion of its State Street flagship store in Chicago, where it hopes to make similar conversions to office space.The company is overhauling its large Union Square location in San Francisco to create 10,000 square feet for small shops across the front – space the company has just started to market for rent, Sesler said. In New York, the company said it is looking at ways to jumpstart shopper traffic in its Herald Square flagship – possibly with an indoor-and-outdoor rooftop area featuring restaurants and after-work hangouts.IBD'S TAKE: As Amazon and off-price retailers wear down department stores, retailers like Ulta Beauty have gotten by relatively unscathed. Here are five takeaways from Ulta's most recent quarterly earnings. What's more, Sesler said, Macy's department stores are in 72% of the nation's high-end 'A' malls — those most likely to weather the ongoing storm of store bankruptcies and closures.Still, nothing at the 2-1/2 hour presentation could distract Wall Street from the company's gross-margin forecast.Shares finished 8% lower on Tuesday after CFO Karen Hoguet during the presentation warned that gross margins for the year were on track to be 60 to 80 basis points lower than last year. Among the factors she cited were excess inventory following the holidays and heavy promotions in the beauty business. She said she expected inventory levels to even out by the fall season.Macy's fell 0.4% to 21.81 on the stock market Wednesday, sinking intraday to their lowest level since September 2010.Macy's initially rebounded Thursday morning after Nordstrom (JWN) announced that it is mulling a "going private" move, but Macy's closed down 0.2%. Nordstrom shares skyrocketed 10.3%, though that was well off their intraday highs.J.C. Penney (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS), which tumbled Tuesday on Macy's warning, reversed lower Thursday to end down 4.8% and 2.3%, respectively. Sears (SHLD) closed off 1.7%.Still, management on Tuesday said that beauty and home products were doing well within its off-price "Backstage" concept. Within apparel, where Amazon has become a big threat, Macy's is trying to rid its inventory of duplicate items and bring more exclusive items and faster fashion to store racks.CEO Jeff Gennette also emphasized the changes in the way people shop – the way physical stores and websites can play off one another when a consumer weighs what they want to buy – and Macy's opportunities in that evolution."There's a place for both Amazon and Macy's to succeed with our customer," he said.Management said that it was "open to all options" in developing its e-commerce, and said that Wal-Mart's approach to its online business – including buying outlets like Jet.com – was "quite interesting."Cowen analyst Oliver Chen, in a research note Wednesday, said Macy's had done a "good job articulating its challenges" and that if its turnaround succeeded, "America's love for shopping will be reengaged." But he said an epic battle with Amazon would continue."We think customers are 'familiar' with Macy's but don't really 'love' it," he wrote.Wal-Mart edged higher Thursday after rising slightly Wednesday following a retreat Tuesday. Amazon on Tuesday offered discounted Prime subscriptions to people on government aid, going after key Wal-Mart customers.RELATED:This Is Keeping TJX Bullish Amid The Broader Retail MeltdownSears Stock Tanks As CEO Accuses Suppliers Of Exploiting It

X Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 and Nasdaq 100 rose slightly early Wednesday morning.During the regular session, the major averages faded for modest losses late as Facebook (FB), Amazon.com (AMZN), Netflix (NFLX) and Google parent Alphabet (GOOGL) reversed lower or pared gains. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 index slid 0.3% while the Dow Jones industrial average retreated 0.2%.The FANG stocks' market impact is striking, given the modest moves. Facebook fell 0.5%, Alphabet 0.7% and Amazon 0.8%, with Netflix clinging to a 0.1% gain. But because their valuations are so high, those tiny percentage declines translated to a loss of $11 billion market cap, with bigger declines from their intraday highs.Until the final slide in the FANG stocks the major averages were hovering around break-even. That's despite another wipeout for retailers. Macy's (M) warned on gross margins, sending the stock down 8.2% to a fresh five-year high. Kohl's (KSS) tumbled 5.8%, Nordstrom (JWN) 3.6%, J.C. Penney (JCP) 4.1% and Dillard's (DDS) 3.4%. But department stores' market valuations have tumbled over many years, so those big losses shaved little more than $2 billion from their collective market cap.Simply put, despite the still-large presence of department stores for consumers, investors have largely written them off. The merest breeze from FANG stocks is more important to the broader averages than a retail hurricane.(Investors haven't written off discount giant Wal-Mart (WMT), which has been a market leader in 2017. Wal-Mart sank 1.7% on Tuesday, trimming its market cap by $4 billion.)Futures for the Dow industrials and the S&P 500 index rose more than 0.1% vs. fair value Wednesday morning. Nasdaq 100 futures climbed 0.2%. U.S. crude oil futures edged lower, just under $48 a barrel, ahead of U.S. inventory and production data this morning from the Energy Information Administration.Tesla (TSLA) edged down 0.5% in Wednesday's morning after rising fractionally late Tuesday as the company held its shareholder meeting. Tesla rose 1.6% to 352.85 in Tuesday's session, hitting a fresh intraday high of 359.49.Tesla investors voted to keep three-year terms for board members, rejecting a bid by some pension funds for annual votes amid concerns that the board is too beholden and too closely tied to CEO Elon Musk.Musk once again spoke optimistically about the upcoming Model 3, the new solar-roof tiles and the future of a Model Y crossover SUV and a September unveiling of an electric semi-truck.In Asian trading, Japan's Nikkei closed just above break-even, while China's Shanghai composite advanced 1.2%.In European trading intraday, stocks rose modestly. The U.K.'s FTSE climbed 0.3%, France's CAC-40 0.8% and Germany's Dax 0.3% ahead of British elections and a European Central Bank meeting.RELATED:5 Surging Chinese Stocks And What You Could Do: Investing Action PlanMacy's Triggers New Retail Rout On Gross Margins WarningAmazon's New Wal-Mart Assault: Prime Cut For Government-Aid Recipients

Sears Holdings (SHLD) crashed yet again on Monday after the CEO aired grievances with a supplier and said "the recent wave of dire predictions about our company's future have done harm to our business."The remarks, made in a corporate blog post, come after Sears in March said "substantial doubt" existed over its survival prospects.Sears, like other retailers, have struggled to retain sales and store traffic amid competition from value retailers and what analysts have called an "over-stored" retail environment as more people shop online.Sears CEO Eddie Lampert said some companies it does business with were "trying to take advantage of negative rumors about Sears to make themselves a better deal — a deal that is unilaterally in their interest.""In such a case, we will not simply roll over and be taken advantage of — we will do what's right to protect the interests of our company and the millions of stakeholders we serve," he added.Investors, perhaps sensing it was a bad sign that a retailer was publicly haggling with suppliers, bailed after Lampert accused some partners of taking advantage of the company. Shares tumbled 12.4% to 8.31 in the stock market today.Rival J.C. Penney (JCP), whose earnings last week hastened Wall Street's retreat from the industry, fell 4.8% to a fresh record low after diving 17% last week. Macy's (M) lost another 1.7% after plunging 18.5% last week. Nordstrom (JWN) edged up 0.5% following its 15.9% weekly loss.Lampert said that one supplier, One World, which has made tools for Sears' Craftsman brand, has threatened to sue the retail giant and refused to meet the terms of a supply agreement. Sears sold off Craftsman earlier this year.One World, a subsidiary of the Chinese conglomerate Techtronic Industries, seeks "to embarrass us in the media to force us to let them out of their contract," Lampert said, adding that Sears had "nothing to be embarrassed about."He also said that Sears would defend itself against any legal action, ensured that One World met its contractual obligations, and said Sears was able meet its own."Sears has paid and continues to make all payments to One World as they come due, and we are fully capable of continuing to meet our obligations under the Supply Agreement," he said.Sears said that it had paid One World more than $868 million since 2007 and helped the company become a bigger player in the tool industry."If we allowed One World to break their agreement, it would effectively reduce the flow of products they are required to deliver to Sears, harming our ability to sell tools, supply parts, and provide goods to Sears' members and customers," Lampert said. "We won't allow that to happen."RELATED:What To Expect From Target, Wal-Mart In The Wake Of Mall MeltdownHere's One More Thing Amazon May Be Killing

X RH (RH), formerly known as Restoration Hardware, and Lululemon Athletica (LULU) reported Q1 results late Thursday. RH narrowly topped EPS views but slashed guidance while Luluemon beat, sending their shares in different directions.Estimates: Consensus estimates call for EPS of 4 cents in Q1, down 20%, on sales of $556 million, up 25%.Results: RH earned 5 cents while revenue rose to $562 million.Outlook: RH is liquidity inventory as it shifts to a membership model. It raised full-year revenue guidance to $2.4 billion to $2.45 billion from $2.3 billion to $2.4 billion. But it slashed its EPS target to $1.67-$1.94 from $1.78-$2.19.Shares: RH dived 23% to 44.10 in after-hours trading. Shares of the upscale home furnishings retailer closed up 2% to 57.25 on the stock market today.RH shares have more than doubled since the retailer's last report, on Feb. 23, even though its fundamentals haven't been particularly strong. But after hitting a 16-month high of 60.11 on May 10, shares slumped the following day after the retailer tweaked its earnings outlook while forecasting a 23% jump in first-quarter net revenue. RH stock has been consolidating since then.Sales are expected to get a boost from the acquisition of Waterworks as well as higher outlet and warehouse sales.The California-based company completed a $300 million share buyback in Q1.RH has been faring far better than department-store retailers such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN). The relentless rise of Amazon (AMZN) and e-commerce has been bruising traditional brick-and-mortar stores.Estimates: Consensus estimates call for EPS of 28 cents in Q1, down nearly 7%, on sales of $513 million, up 3.4%.Results: EPS rose to 32 cents while revenue climbed to $520.3 million.Outlook: Lululemon raised its full-year EPS range by 2 cents to $2.28-$2.32 but trimmed its full-year sales target to $2.53 billion to $2.58 billion.Stock: Shares rose 14.7% to 55.80 in after-hours trading.Lululemon closed up 0.8% to 48.67, but that's after hitting a 17-month low on Wednesday.Lululemon stock has tanked since its late March report, in which the Canadian yoga apparel maker and retailer's Q4 results and Q1 guidance both missed expectations.Lululemon faces competition from Under Armour (UAA), Nike (NKE) and others, with Amazon a looming threat. There's also the risk that the athleticwear trend will plateau.RELATED:Why The Stock Formerly Known As Restoration Hardware Sold OffLululemon Slashed On Slowing Sales; Conoco, EOG, CyberArk Raised

X Stocks opened in very tightly mixed formation Friday, as retailers took hard hits for a second day and General Electric (GE) and Apple (AAPL) fought a tug-of-war for the direction of the Dow.The Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 opened to very narrow losses, while Nasdaq opened a fraction into positive territory.Apple opened at the top of the Dow industrials, up 1% after a securities filing showed the company had issued $7 billion in corporate bonds due between 2020 and 2027. Apple has used bond markets to fund its shareholder rewards initiatives since 2012, raising its debt from nil to $84.5 billion.The company reported $256 billion in cash held overseas in its second-quarter report, and raised its share buyback program to $300 billion. The company has increased debt more than cash in two of the past three quarters. Apple shares are extended above a four-weeks tight buy point of 141.12.General Electric traded down 1.5% in early action, the Dow's biggest decline. Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to sell, from hold.Trade Desk (TTD) gapped up to a 17% gain at the start of trade, after a big first-quarter earnings beat and guidance increase after Thursday's close. The gain put shares of the self-service advertising platform just above a 46.31 buy point in an eight-week cup base.Retailers appeared headed for another day of pain. Nordstrom (JWN) opened down 7% after reporting weak same-store sales late Thursday. J.C. Penney (JCP) also dived 7% on a steeper-than-expected drop in same-store sales in its first-quarter report.  Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) led an industry sell-off on Thursday. Macy's opened down 0.3%. Kohl's showd a 1.6% opening loss.On the IBD 50 list, Chemours (CC) climbed more than 3% after an upgrade, to overweight, from neutral, from JPMorgan.  Shares are extended, still knocking out new highs, after an April rebound from 10-week support.At the bottom of the list, chip equipment maker Ichor Holdings (ICHR) dropped 4% after reporting a 200% earnings gain and a 103% rise in revenue in its first-quarter report late Thursday.Oil prices reversed to narrow gains ahead of Friday's open: West Texas Intermediate traded just below $48 a barrel and up a bit more than 3% for the week. Gold gained 0.4% to go above $1,228 an ounce, up 3% on the week. The dollar backed off from Thursday's gains, bonds edged higher, trimming the 10-year yield 1 basis point to 2.37%.Consumer prices rose 0.2% in April, the Labor Department reported, up from a 0.3% decline in March and in line with economist expectations. Stripping out energy and food, core prices edged up 0.1%, better than March's 0.1% decline, but below expectations for a 0.2% gain.Charles Evans, Chicago Federal Reserve Bank president, speaks at 9  a.m. ET. At 10 a.m. ET, the Commerce Department delivers its March business inventories report, and the University of Michigan releases its preliminary Consumer Sentiment estimate for May. Philadelphia Federal Reserve Bank President Patrick Harker speaks at 12:30 p.m. ET.  Baker Hughes releases its weekly rig count report at 1 p.m. ET.Europe's markets remained in positive territory as investors there waded through a heavy slate of earnings news. The FTSE 100 in London was up 0.3%, Frankfurt's DAX showed a 0.2% gain and the CAC 40 in Paris traded up 0.1% near midday.RELATED:Buy, Hold Or Sell 3D Systems, Stratasys? Investing Action PlanStock Futures Fall; This Top-Rated IPO Looks Like Nvidia, Not Snap

The major indexes ended all but flat in quiet trade Friday as investors stood down after a tough week of earnings news and politics.The Nasdaq pulled off a 0.1% gain, while the Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 slipped 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. Small caps took a beating, leaving the Russell 2000 with a 0.5% loss. The S&P SmallCap 600 fell 0.8%. Preliminary data showed trading volume ended well below Thursday's levels.A week that opened with the presidential election in France, then moved on to the presidential election in South Korea and the surprise firing of FBI Director James Comey, also moved the market past the zenith of the first-quarter reporting season. S&P Capital IQ reported Friday that 72% of the S&P 500 companies topped consensus estimates for the quarter, topping the historic beat rate of 66% for only the second time in the past six years.The fiber-optics group posted Friday's best gain among industries, with Applied Optoelectronics (AAOI) and Lumentum Holdings (LITE) jumping more than 2% and 3%, respectively. Applied Optoelectronics scored a new high, but passed no buy points. Lumentum is forming a base with a 56.02 buy point.Enterprise software developers also scored well, hauled higher by Trade Desk's (TTD) 31% blowout performance following first-quarter results delivered after Thursday's close. The gap up left the stock extended above a 46.31 cup base buy point, and 197% above its September IPO price.Casino and gold mining stocks also posted two of the day's best moves among industries. Much of the updraft came from small, thinly traded stocks, but Wynn Resorts (WYNN) rose 2.5% to lock up the top spot among S&P 500 stocks, boosted by a Barclays upgrade to overweight from equal weight and a price-target hike to 144.On the Dow, Apple (AAPL) led with a 1.4% gain following a price target hike to 170 from Goldman Sachs. General Electric (GE) took the low spot, slipping 2.1% after Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to sell from hold, and trimmed its price target to 24 from 28. The note cited valuation, and questioned the company's ability to continue funding its dividend and share buyback programs given its cash flow trend.Friday was not the horrific day that Thursday was for retail stocks, but Nordstrom (JWN) nevertheless tanked 11%, despite a relatively strong first-quarter report, the worst performance on the S&P 500 index. JCPenney (JCP) collapsed 14% on its quarterly results, driving share prices below 5.Oil drillers took a beating as the price of West Texas Intermediate oil ended flat on Friday after Baker Hughes (BHI) reported a 17-straight week of increased rig activity.  Crude ended the week up 3% and just below $48 a barrel.RELATED:Alibaba, Salesforce.com, Home Depot, Wal-Mart: Investing Action PlanBest iPhone 8 Chip Plays: Broadcom, Cirrus Logic, Skyworks

X J.C. Penney (JCP) reported better-than-expected earnings, after a raft of adjustments, but revenue and same-store sales fell more than forecast. J.C. Penney shares tumbled to a record low Friday morning, a day after weak results from Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and others sent retail stocks into a black hole.Estimates: A per-share loss narrowing to 21 cents from 32 cents a year earlier. Revenue is expected to be down 1.3% to $2.77 billion. Consensus estimates for same-store sales were for a 0.4% decline.Results: J.C. Penney had a net loss of 58 cents. Adjusted profit appeared to be 6 cents a share, though that included a 38-cent gain from asset sales. Revenue fell to $2.706 billion. Same-store sales fell 3.5%.Outlook: J.C. Penney affirmed its full-year outlook, citing improved sales trends."While February was a very challenging month for JCPenney and broader retail, we are pleased with our comp store sales for the combined March and April period, which improved significantly versus February," said J.C. Penney CEO Marvin Ellison in a statement. "The recent sales trends, combined with the improvement in women`s apparel and our growth initiatives led by Sephora inside JCPenney, jcp.com and major appliances, provide us with the confidence to maintain our sales guidance for the full year.Stock: Shares crashed 14% to 4.55 on the stock market today, undercutting J.C. Penney's all-time low of 4.90 set in February 2014. Shares fell 7.4% to 5.29 on Thursday.J.C. Penney faces the same problems as much of the retail sector — a shift to online and mobile shopping, competition from discounters and fast-fashion and too many stores. In February, the company said it would close 130 to 140 stores in the coming months.J.C. Penney has tried to offset struggles in apparel by selling products from Ashley Furniture, athletic wear and footwear, Deutsche Bank noted. The company's in-store Sephora outlets, which sell makeup, fragrances and other beauty products, have also been a plus.Nordstrom shares plunged 10.8% to 41.20, a nine-month closing low, after tumbling 7.6% on Thursday. Nordstrom late Thursday topped EPS views, but comps fell more than expected.Macy's fell 3% after Thursday's 17% crash to its worst levels since 2011 after it reported a big across-the-board miss. Kohl's (KSS) and Dillard's (DDS) tumbled Thursday on Macy's and their own disappointing results. Kohl's and Dillard's sank 1.8% on Friday.RELATED:   Macy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkDeath Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnNordstrom Beats Earnings Views But Comps Miss After Macy's DisasterThese 3 Retailers Could Reap $1 Billion From J.C. Penney, Macy's Closings

X The stock market was mixed in afternoon trading, but trading off its early intraday lows. The Nasdaq shrugged off early weakness to edge slightly higher, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average remained 0.2% in the red. Volume was tracking solidly lower across both exchanges vs. the same time Thursday. Among the other Dow industrials, Apple (AAPL) paced the advancers, rising 1.3% to fresh highs after several analysts raised their price targets on the iPhone maker. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) and McDonald's (MCD) followed up with gains of 0.5% and 0.7%, respectively.On the downside, General Electric (GE) lagged with a more than 3% drop in heavy volume that is running nearly 100% above usual levels, while Merck (MRK) and Cisco (CSCO) both fell over 1%. General Electric was downgraded to sell by Deutsche Bank, who believes that GE is "overvalued given weak earnings quality."Other analysts actions include Nvidia (NVDA), which moved up 0.9% after its price target was hiked at Canaccord Genuity and RBC Capital Markets. The graphics chip maker remains barely extended above a 121.02 potential entry.Nvidia is also making strong strides in the emerging artificial intelligence, data center and self-driving auto technology markets. Recent IPO Trade Desk (TTD) roared almost 29% higher after a late Thursday earnings release came in well-above analyst expectations. Shares are extended sharply above a 46.31 cup-base buy point.Financial stocks underperformed in the stock market today. Dow component Goldman Sachs (GS) dropped 0.9%, while retail brokerage Charles Schwab (SCHW) fell 1.4% after finding resistance at its 50-day line earlier this week.Within the S&P 500, casino operator Wynn Resorts (WYNN) led the way with a 3.3% rise, while retailers continued their precipitous falls. Nordstrom (JWN) plunged more than 9% despite beating Q1 earnings and sales estimates late Thursday. Nordstrom's same-store sales were weaker than expected. Shares of fellow department store J.C. Penney (JCP) reached a record low, down more than 10%, as revenues and same-store sales fell more than forecast early Friday.Action within the IBD 50 was mixed as leading growth stocks as weakness among financials offset strength in technology names. On the upside, Momo (MOMO) notched a new high, up 4.3%, while fiber-optic stock Lumentum Holdings (LITE) moved up 1.9%.On the downside, chip name Ichor (ICHR) dropped nearly 4% but bounced off intraday lows after reporting earnings that fell short of the Street's estimates, while regional bank Citizens Financial (CFG) and private mortgage insurer Essent Group (ESNT) fell 1.7% and 1.4%, respectively.Ichor is currently trading above its 50-day moving average, a sign of strength.RELATED:Apple Hits Record High On Bullish Wall Street ReportsThese 5 Red Flags On GE Send Stock To 15-Month LowNordstrom Comp Sales Miss But Off-Price Brand Nordstrom Rack SurgesGraphics Chip Maker Nvidia Gets Fresh Price-Target Hikes

X Nordstrom (JWN) beat first-quarter earnings and revenue forecasts late Thursday but weak same-store sales came amid an exodus from retail stocks following grim results from Macy's (M).Estimates: Earnings per share up 4% to 27 cents, with revenue inching up 3% to $3.343 billion and same-store sales coming in flat.Results: Adjusted EPS of 43 cents on revenue of $3.354 billion. Same-store sales fell 0.8%. Sales at off-price Nordstrom Rack jumped 8.7% with comps up 2.3%. For the main Nordstrom brand, sales fell 1.7% with comps down 2.8%.

Outlook: Management backed its full-year EPS outlook of $2.75 to $3.00 vs. consensus views for $2.92, on a net sales increase of 3%-4%, in line with Wall Street views for 3.5% growth, and approximately flat comparable sales.Stock: Nordstrom dropped 5% late. Shares closed down 7.6% at 46.21 on the stock market today, after paring earlier losses and finding support at their 50-day moving average. Macy's sank 17% to its lowest level in nearly six years. Kohl's (KSS), which also reported today, dropped 7.8%.J.C. Penney (JCP), which reports Friday, lost 7.4%, and Sears Holdings (SHLD) tumbled 9.6%.Even as Nordstrom deals with what has been described as its weakest brick-and-mortar traffic since the 1970s, some analysts have been more upbeat about the upscale chain's prospects."The company owns the best house on a bad block," analysts at Gordon Haskett wrote.Deutsche Bank analyst Paul Trussell — while still cautious on the company — noted in a retail earnings preview dated Tuesday that Nordstrom depended less on the discounting that other retailers have resorted to in their rush to clear shelves. Discounting can draw customers, but it means less money for retailers.He also noted the company's unique product lines, its appeal to higher-end customers and the number of ways it has to attract them. That includes the company's e-commerce efforts, which other analysts say are more developed than rivals, and its off-price Nordstrom Rack division.RELATED:Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnThese 3 Retailers Could Reap $1 Billion From J.C. Penney, Macy's ClosingsJ.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales DropKohl's, Macy's Slash Profit Guidance On Weak Holiday Sales: Blame Amazon?

During Macy's (M) first-quarter earnings call on Thursday, the typical analyst refrain of "great quarter, guys" was often replaced with some version of "good luck, guys."Shares of the ailing department store giant crashed 17% to 24.35 in the stock market today as the stock hit their worst levels since late 2011 after Macy's said same-store sales slid 5.2%, badly missing estimates for around a 3% drop. The key measure fell 4.6% on an owned-plus-licensed basis. Earnings per share of 24 cents missed expectations for 34 cents. Total revenue of $5.34 billion fell 8%, short of estimates for $5.469 billion.Macy's grim report triggered a broad, sharp sell-off in the retail sector as investors questioned if brick-and-mortar stores have much of a future.Management didn't exactly answer how it'll turnaround the retail giant's fortunes. Instead, it's trying a variety of initiatives to see what, if anything, works.Executives left open the possibility that store closures could creep higher than the 100 that Macy's has said it would shutter."I'm not going to say that we're not going to close more stores beyond those hundred, but we do feel like we got to the right level when we made the decision that we did in 2016 that we're executing now in '17," said new CEO Jeff Gennette during the call.Still, Macy's said it remained "on track to meet our 2017 guidance." Sensing that analysts would ask how that was at all possible, management tried to address those questions early in the call.CFO Karen Hoguet said that Macy's had expected the first quarter to be its weakest as it rolled out turnaround plans, adding that the benefits of closing stores, and the accompanying going-out-of-business sales, weren't going to kick in until later in March.She also said that weaker trends seen in the first quarter would rebound later in the year, citing expanded pilot programs, a revamped marketing strategy, heightened consumer engagement — something Gennette characterized as a "nexus of technology and the human touch" — and growth in digital and mobile shopping.Macy's has rolled out new offerings including self-service shoe sections, a jewelry pilot program and new furniture and mattress offerings — initiatives that the company wants to introduce nationwide this year and says will clean up what has been a messy few years for an industry struggling to find itself in an ever-digitizing shopping landscape."These are unusual and challenging times for retailers," Gennette said. He later added that "we've known for some time that the United States is over-retailed," so the contraction in square footage was not surprising.The company has tried a variety of ways to make use of vacant store space, converting floors to office space or installing its off-price "Backstage" stores, which have been set up in unused areas of traditional Macy's stores.But analysts at Gordon Haskett, in a research note this week, worried that Backstage was "a defensive move and one that could cannibalize core M sales."Management said it was careful to avoid cannibalizing full-price items. Gennette also tried to position Backstage as an appeal to millennials — many of whom he said came to Macy's to seek bargains.The company said it would add 19 more Backstage locations this year and that it was "encouraged" by those combined stores' performance as well as its new clearance section, called Last Act. Whichever does better will be rolled out "aggressively" next year, Hoguet said.The company said it was encouraged by double-digit growth in digital sales, but said it was difficult to break out what constituted a digital sale, given the increasingly connected way people shop, using a combination of electronic devices and stores.Many brick-and-mortar retailers are seeing big percentage gains in online sales, but the absolute e-commerce activity isn't enough to move the needle as in-store sales deteriorate.When asked how the company could compete with Amazon.com (AMZN), which has been bulking up on its artificial intelligence and Big Data capacity and aimed to push fashion, Gennette insisted that aspects of the department store were as relevant today as ever, and said that exclusive products and the pilot programs, along with working harder to be part of local communities, would help the company maintain relevance.And as more retailers try to make being in a store a memorable experience in and of itself, he said he hoped Macy's would have a store platform that addressed consumers' experience needs by the end of next year.As with the other big middle-class retailers, Macy's has suffered at the hands of higher-end and discount retailers, as well as Amazon.Meanwhile, Kohl's (KSS) reported mixed results early Thursday. EPS of 39 cents beat views for 29 cents. But revenue of $3.84 billion slightly missed expectations as same-store sales slid 2.7% vs. forecasts of a 0.6% dip.  Shares for Kohl's tumbled 7.8% to 47.77.Regional department store chain Dillard's (DDS) dived 17.5% on its mixed results Thursday.Nordstrom (JWN) closed down 7.6% to 46.21. After the close, the upscale department store topped EPS views, but comps fell more than expected. Nordstrom shares fell sharply late.Thursday's results follow a disastrous fourth quarter for many retailers, as well as announced bankruptcy filings, liquidations and buyouts in an industry with too much real estate and not enough mall traffic.J.C. Penney (JCP) reports quarterly earnings on Friday. J.C. Penney shares fell 8% intraday.RELATED:Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives OnNordstrom Beats Earnings Views But Comps Miss After Macy's DisasterThese 3 Retailers Could Reap $1 Billion From J.C. Penney, Macy's ClosingsJ.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales DropKohl's, Macy's Slash Profit Guidance On Weak Holiday Sales: Blame Amazon?

X Retail stocks, which had stabilized at low levels in recent weeks, plunged yet again as Macy's (M) shockingly weak first-quarter results reignited concerns that mainline department and apparel stores can't compete with Amazon (AMZN) and a reinvigorated Wal-Mart (WMT).Macy's sizable miss — on earnings, sales and same-store sales growth — crashed 17% Thursday to the worst levels since October 2011.Kohl's (KSS) profit beat couldn't save the stock from getting slammed: After missing on revenue and comps, shares reversed lower, erasing early gains. Kohl's tumbled 7.9% in the stock market today.Dillard's (DDS), which also turned in mixed results, slid 17.5%, breaching support at its 50-day moving average.The morning's earnings dragged down Nordstrom (JWN), which fell 7.6% at the close. Nordstrom reported much-better-than-expected earnings after the close, but comps dipped 0.8%. Shares edged lower in initial late trading.IBD'S TAKE: For a broader look at retail, check out IBD's recent cover story on brick-and-mortar chains' bleak prospects in the age of AmazonJ.C. Penney (JCP), which reports early Friday, sank 7.4%.The Retail-Department Store group, already the ranked dead last out of IBD's 197 industries, crashed 9.7% intraday, by far Thursday's worst performer so far. Retail and apparel groups account for nine of the 12 biggest losers today.Luxury RH (RH) (formerly Restoration Hardware), which upped its revenue guidance but tweaked profit outlook, tumbled more than 9%.The retail slump is being felt across apparel brands, too. Retail stocks got thumped Thursday as Wall Street weighed sluggish results from a couple of department store operators, but selling in the broad market was much more subdued as major stock indexes rallied off lows but still showed modest losses in late-afternoon trading.The Dow Jones industrial average pared a 0.7% intraday loss to just 0.1% with a little more than one hour remaining in the session. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 eased 0.2%. Volume on the NYSE was tracking slightly higher than Wednesday's levels. Nasdaq volume fell a bit.In the stock market today, Macy's (M) crashed 16% to its lowest level since 2011 after reporting another quarter of disappointing sales. Group peer Kohl's (KSS) also sold off on earnings, slumping 6%. Nordstrom (JWN) reports after the close. Shares were down 7% ahead of the results.The selling wasn't just limited to department store operators as about half of the day's worst performing industry groups were in the retail sector. Home furnishings name RH (RH) gapped down after the company updated its earnings guidance. Shares were down 7% in late trading.Weakness in retail names came ahead of April retail sales data due Friday at 8:30 a.m. ET.Before the open Thursday, wholesale inflation in April came in hotter than expected, but higher prices aren't a major concern for the Fed right now as the core PCE deflator, the Fed's preferred inflation gauge, is still below the 2% level.Elsewhere, good news from Delta Air Lines (DAL) wasn't much help to the stock Thursday as shares lost 0.3%. The company lifted its annual dividend to $1.22 a share and also announced a new $5 billion share repurchase program.Inside the IBD 50, Nvidia (NVDA) extended gains after Wednesday's gap up in price, fueled by strong earnings. Shares rose another 6%. Nvidia on Thursday announced new graphics processing units for data centers and a deal to provide systems to Toyota Motor (TM) for autonomous driving.Meanwhile, another strong earnings report from NetEase (NTES) lifted the stock back above the 50-day moving average but not by much. Shares added 0.9%, recovering from an intraday loss of 2.8%.At the New York Mercantile exchange, oil extended gains, rising 1.1% to $47.83 a barrel, after OPEC members said oil producers are willing to extend recent production cuts.RELATED:Death Stalks Retail Stocks, But Hope Lives On Oil, Gold ETFs Shine, But Retail Gets Slammed As Macy's DivesNvidia Surges More Than 25% In Two Days After Conference NewsDelta Air Lines Raises Dividend By 51%, Approves $5 Billion Buyback
