TJX (TJX), the parent of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, disappointed investors with a first-quarter revenue and profit guidance miss early Tuesday, but shares started creeping back up during the call as management announced plans to introduce a new home-decor concept, Homesense, to American shoppers and expressed bullishness in the face of broader retail combustion."Home is a driver for TJX," said CEO Ernie Herrman in response to an analyst query, adding that the company's home businesses have been "a little stronger than apparel." He also alluded to home goods being less susceptible to the impact of poor weather, which weighed on comparable sales during the quarter."We think nobody can replicate the fashion and the quality level we have at our home businesses," he said on the call. "We think strategically this is not a short-term vision."Herrman was fairly mum about the details, but said that there would be an "extremely visible difference" between Homesense and its American sister, HomeGoods, that would propel customers to shop at both stores.While Homesense shares the same name as TJX's home-goods stores in Canada and Europe, spokespeople told Investor's Business Daily that the U.S. Homesense would be different.In Canada, the self-described "home fashions off-price" store can be found as stand-alone locations or as superstores, in which a HomeSense is teamed up with a Winners or Marshalls store, according to the HomeSense site. There are currently 106 stores across 10 Canadian provinces.The U.S. concept is slated to debut toward the end of the summer, said Herrman.While TJX's Marshalls and T.J. Maxx locations in the U.S. logged flat comparable sales, HomeGoods comps grew 3% during the April-ended quarter, better than FactSet views for 2.4% growth.Aware of the broader troubles of the retail sector, management brushed off the threat of e-commerce and Amazon (AMZN). People are still shopping for clothes at TJX-owned stores, was the message.Herrman said Q2 is "off to a solid start," with inventory in a good position, and later added that the company is "still gaining apparel market share in the U.S."Shares of TJX tumbled 4.1% to 73.76 on the stock market today after falling to a six-month low of 73.17 earlier. On May 10, TJX tried to break out of a consolidation resistance area. But shares have sold off since then in the wake of grim news from other retailers. Off-price rival Ross Stores (ROST), which reports earnings on Thursday, was down 1.4%.In Q1, TJX's profit rose 8% to 82 cents on 3% revenue growth to $7.78 billion, vs. consensus for 79 cents a share and $7.88 billion in sales. Same-store sales rose 1%, below some estimates.Management sees Q2 EPS of 81-83 cents vs. 84 cents a year earlier. Analysts had expected 92 cents. TJX sees full-year profit of $3.71-$3.78, up 5%-7%, also below views. The company said currency effects and wage increases weighed on its guidance.Off-pricers like TJX and Ross enjoyed a reputation for being untouchable by Amazon, thanks to the in-store treasure-hunt nature of bargain-rack shopping. But Tuesday's weak sales and guidance raised concerns that status may be under threat as the rest of retail suffers a face-melting sell-off.Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), J.C. Penney (JCP), Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS) plunged last week amid grim results and a growing fear that department stores don't know how to stop the bleeding. Macy's and Dillard's have hit their lowest levels in more than five years, while J.C. Penney is at record lows.And Sears Holdings' (SHLD) CEO has resorted to blasting vendors in a blog post, in a bid to un-smear the long-ailing retailer's name in the press. That's sent Sears shares tumbling 12.3% on Monday.RELATED:Home Depot Is One Retailer That Isn't Falling Apart: Earnings StrongMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkHere's One More Thing Amazon May Be KillingWhat To Expect From Target, Wal-Mart In The Wake Of Mall Meltdown

X Futures for the Dow Jones industrial average, S&P 500 index and Nasdaq 100 were little changed early Tuesday. Home Depot (HD) and TJX (TJX), two Amazon.com (AMZN)-resistant retail giants, are on tap with earnings Tuesday morning. Meanwhile, Cisco Systems (CSCO) is nearing a buy point ahead of its quarterly results as analysts and investors see it as a cybersecurity play amid the WannaCry global ransomware attack.Futures for the Dow industrials rose about 0.1% vs. fair value. Nasdaq 100 futures were fractionally above fair value. S&P 500 futures edged lower.On Monday, the Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 index both rose 0.5% to record highs, with cybersecurity and energy stocks leading the way. The Dow industrials gained 0.4%.In Asia trading Tuesday, Japan's Nikkei rose 0.25%, hitting a 17-month high. China's Shanghai composite advanced 0.75%. Hong Kong's Hang Seng fell 0.1%. In European trade intraday, the U.K.'s FTSE rose 0.6%, hitting an all-time high. Germany's Dax lost 0.1% while France's Cac-40 sank 0.3%Home Depot, a Dow component, reported better-than-expected earnings Tuesday morning, sending shares toward a record high. Home Depot has been rallying more or less for the past three months, trading at record highs, with no potential buy point in sight for now.Improving housing and job markets are fueling demand for the home improvement giant. Building supplies is an area where Amazon has not made huge inroads for now.TJX, an off-price apparel and home goods retailer, also is set to report before the opening bell early Tuesday. TJX and other off-price chains were seen as relatively safe from Amazon because they offer branded goods at deep discounts with a treasure hunt aspect.TJX stock broke out past resistance in a consolidation on May 10. But shares have sold off sharply since then in the wake of brutal reports from Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and J.C. Penney (JCP), followed by Sears Holdings' (SHLD) public feud with a key supplier.Cisco Systems, another Dow stock, doesn't report until Wednesday night. But shares rallied 2.3% to 34.23 on Monday in heavy volume, just below a 34.63 buy point. Morgan Stanley upgraded the networking giant on Monday, citing its faster-growing software and security businesses. Computer security stocks have soared in the wake of the global cyberattack.IBD'S TAKE: Amazon is uprooting more and more businesses, from its bookstore origins to cloud computing. Here's one more thing Amazon may be killing with its remorseless expansion.Cisco's security business is just 6% of its total revenue, but that's enough to make it a significant rival to some pure-play companies. Still, Cisco revenue has been declining as the lumbering giant transitions.Meanwhile, Ford (F) plans to cut 10% of its global workforce, which is about 200,000 people, the Wall Street Journal reported late Monday, citing sources.Meanwhile, Chinese internets Weibo (WB) and majority owner Sina (SINA) both topped first-quarter estimates early Tuesday. Weibo, a short-messaging social media operator, has already broken out to a new high, while Sina is near a buy point. Stratasys (SSYS) also is on tap as 3D printer stocks have skyrocketed since 3D Systems (DDD) reported recently.RELATED:The Big Picture: Why Are Growth Stocks Outperforming?Cisco Near Buy Point As Analyst Touts New Efforts Before EarningsAmazon: Dot-Com Survivor Turned River Monster Has Fueled 64,000% GainStratasys Earnings Up Next As 3D Printer Stocks Take Flight

The major market averages held firm despite political furor over President Trump's abrupt firing of FBI Director James Comey, a Macy's (M)-led retail meltdown, bad news from Walt Disney and a Snap crash. On the upside, Nvidia (NVDA), OLED play Coherent (COHR) and new IPO Trade Desk (TTD) were big winners.The Nasdaq composite rose 0.3% for the week, hitting a new record high Wednesday as Apple (AAPL) and Netflix (NFLX) were among the big-cap techs setting all-time bests. The Dow industrials sank 0.6% and the S&P 500 0.4%. Higher oil prices lifted energy stocks, while bad news from Macy's, J.C. Penney (JCP) and several other retailers sent the broader sector tumbling. Snap fell close to its IPO price as Facebook (FB) competition takes its toll. But Nvidia skyrocketed to record highs on huge demand for its chips for graphics, artificial intelligence and more.Delivering its first earnings report since coming public, Snapchat-operator Snap missed on the top and bottom line. Snap said average revenue per user rose 181%, to 90 cents, but fell from $1.05 in the prior quarter. User growth was weaker than expected, with Facebook successfully cloning Snapchat's most popular features. Shares plunged more than 21% on Thursday to a post-IPO trading low, though they did rise 6% on Friday.3 top-rated IPOs also reported earnings. Digital ad platform Trade Desk (TTD) spiked Friday morning on better-than-expected earnings and revenue. Chip-equipment play Ichor (ICHR) reported results in line with bullish preliminary figures, but gave weak guidance. IT services firm Presidio (PSDO) fell after its results.RELATED:Snap Laughs Off Facebook Competition As Stock Plunges On Earnings MissGraphics chip maker Nvidia (NVDA) earnings rose 85% and sales surged 48% to $1.94 billion, beating views and helped by strong demand for processors for cloud computing data centers. Nvidia shares shot up 23% in the two days after the late Tuesday report. Microchip Technology (MCHP) and MaxLinear (MXL) also rallied on better-than-expected quarterly results.RELATED:Nvidia Surges 23% In Two Days On Earnings, GPU ConferenceWalt Disney (DIS) was forced to defend ESPN again as the premium sports cable network's subscriber losses accelerated slightly from the prior quarter; the timing of the call, not long after ESPN laid off about 100 mostly high-profile employees, put the channel back in the spotlight and CEO Bob Iger back in the hot seat. Results were mixed as revenue growth of 3% to $13.34 billion missed estimates and profit gains of 10% to $1.50 a share topped. 21st Century Fox (FOXA) turned in mixed results, topping on profit views, but cable ad revenue was weak. Ad revenue softness and subscriber declines have put media stocks under scrutiny lately.RELATED:21st Century Fox's Weak Cable Ad Revenue Follows Disney's ESPN WoesMacy's (M) led retailers after reporting weak quarterly results, as the department store operator is trying a variety of initiatives, hoping to find a solution to the long-time decline in brick-and-mortar retailer. Macy's sold off 17% on Thursday, then continued falling Friday, hitting its worst levels since 2011. Nordstrom (JWN) tumbled on disappointing same-store sales, while Kohl's (KSS) sold off mixed results. J.C. Penney (JCP) crashed to a record low Friday on its weak comps while Dillard's (DDS) also plunged. Many retailers are trying an array of things — from better e-commerce services to new beauty offerings to stores-within-stores — to prop up sales as more people buy things online or at discounters.RELATED:J.C. Penney Threatens All-Time Low On Weak Sales As Retail Woes ContinueMacy's Doesn't Know How To Fix Its Stores, Hopes Something Will WorkOPEC production fell in April thanks to decline in output from Libya, Iraq and Iran. But Saudi Arabia's production increased by nearly 50,000 barrels per day, according to OPEC's report. The increases come as OPEC and its allies debate extending the current production deal. On Tuesday, the International Energy Agency said an extension would reduce supply even further in the second half of the year. But U.S. shale is curbing the effectiveness of the cuts. On Wednesday, the Energy Information Administration said U.S. stockpiles fell by 5.2 million barrels last week, a larger-than-expected drop. On Tuesday, the EIA raised its full-year U.S. oil production forecast for 2018 to 9.96 million barrels per day. U.S. crude futures rallied after tumbling 6.3% in the prior week.EOG Resources (EOG) said it could hit its targeted 18% production increase and operate with in cash flow if oil averages $47 per barrel. It plans to operate three more rigs than previously expected, but keep capital spending at $3.7 billion to $4.1 billion. EOG, sometimes called the "Apple (AAPL) of oil," touted its Big Data and proprietary mobile apps in helping cut costs while new wells in the Permian basin "shattered" industry records for early production. Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) raised its 2017 production outlook and Sanchez Energy (SN) said current Q2 production levels are already 46% higher than Q1 levels. Oasis Petroleum (OAS) said Q1 production soared 25.6%.Coherent (COHR) earned $2.91 a share, up 180%, in its fiscal Q2. Revenue rose 112% to $422.8 million. Shares skyrocketed to a new high. Coherent makes laser parts used in making OLED displays for TVs and increasingly smartphones. CEO John Ambroseo sees "unprecedented demand" across many of the company's verticals.E-commerce giant JD.com (JD), one of China's top performing internet companies, reported first-quarter results that topped estimates and guided second-quarter revenue above views, a week before rival Alibaba (BABA) reports. China online auto site Bitauto (BITA) reported first-quarter earnings that fell short of views, but a competing online auto website, Autohome (ATHM), topped expectations. China social networking company YY (YY) also beat the consensus estimate.Marriott (MAR) reported first-quarter earnings that topped estimates and gave a rosier outlook for revPAR — or revenue per available room — a reflection of postelection optimism. Several hotel operators have delivered strong earnings and big stock gains. Travel-information websites Priceline (PCLN) and TripAdvisor (TRIP), however, reported results that missed views.The video game publisher earned 85 cents a share excluding items, up 69% year over year, far above views, as sales grew 18% to $1.09 billion. Electronic Arts (EA) was helped by continued strong sales of its World War I shooter game "Battlefield 1" and growth in pro soccer game "FIFA 17." An industrywide shift to higher-margin digital game downloads boosted profit. EA shares soared to record highs.Online home furnishings retailer Wayfair (W) reported first-quarter results that topped analyst estimates and sent shares to all-time highs, putting the squeeze on short sellers in the process. A large amount of Wayfair shares are sold short, equivalent to almost 17 days' worth of trading.Target (TGT) is pilot-testing a next-day home-delivery service for "essentials" such as detergent and coffee in the Minneapolis area. The Target Restock service will be available to REDcard users for an unspecified flat fee as the big-box retailer seeks to catch up with Amazon (AMZN) and Wal-Mart (WMT) moves in the delivery space. Amazon, for its part, cut its free-shipping minimum to $25 from $35, after trimming that from $49 earlier this year in reaction to Wal-Mart.M.D.C. Holdings (MDC) earned 43 cents a share, up 126% vs. a year earlier. Revenue swelled nearly 43% to $581.71 million vs. estimates of $509.9 million. LGI Homes (LGIH) earned 52 cents a share vs. 57 cents a year earlier. Revenue edged up 0.9% to $162.9 million. Shares of MDC rocketed 11% Tuesday to the highest in nearly four years. LGI Homes shot up 13.2%. Larger peers such as Lennar (LEN), D.R. Horton (DHI) and KB Home (KBH) also rallied after the sector had turned spotty in recent weeks.Sinclair Broadcast Group (SBGI) agreed to buy Tribune Media (TRCO) for $3.9 billion, or $43.50 a share, creating a TV station powerhouse after the FCC lifted ownership caps. Sinclair Broadcast, which will also assume $2.7 billion in debt, fell 5.55% for the week. Tribune Media, which had been rallying on buyout buzz, rose 2.7%.Coach (COH) will buy struggling handbag rival Kate Spade (KATE), to boost its appeal with younger women. Coach will pay $2.4 billion, or $18.50 a share, less than some had speculated.Yelp (YELP) crashed 18.4% Wednesday after the local search-and-reviews site reported weak revenue and gave guidance that was far below analyst estimates.

The major indexes rebounded off early-morning lows despite a bullish report in smaller jobless claims last week, yet stocks still traded moderately in the red Thursday. Given the market's strong gains in recent weeks, it would not be a surprise to see the averages finish lower for the week.However, the market continues to show elements of strength as well. The Nasdaq composite and S&P 500 major averages are all still well above their rising 50-day moving averages. Watch to see if the Dow Jones industrial average can hold above its 50-day line.The Dow Jones industrial average at 1 p.m. ET shaved its loss further down to just 0.2%. The 30-member blue chip index hit as low as 20,798, just 11 points above its 50-day line.The Nasdaq composite whittled its initial large decline of nearly 0.9% to less than 0.5% while the S&P 500 was off 0.4%. The NYSE composite, down 0.5%, is also facing a fresh test of support at the 50-day moving average. Snap (SNAP), meanwhile, suffered its worst single-day decline since going public March 2 at 17 a share. The stock dropped more than 18% to 18.76 and skidded to as low as 17.59. The stock would now need to rally more than 56% just to match its all-time high of 29.44.The 18% drop represented a $5.4 billion hair cut in market value for Snap, which has 1.157 billion shares outstanding, including Class A, B and C shares.Investors were clearly disappointed by the much bigger than expected net loss of $2.31 a share for the Snapchat social networking site operator, vs. a net loss of 14 cents in the year-ago quarter. Research and development costs ballooned to $805.8 million vs. $28.1 million. A lot of that likely had to do with high stock-based compensation expense, which totaled almost $2 billion for the quarter.Another concern: Snap showed a $155 million drop in operating cash flow. But the company does have $1.43 billion in cash and $1.82 billion in marketable securities, which usually tend to be highly liquid bonds. Elsewhere in the market, Essent Group (ESNT) continued its rebound, rising nearly 2% to 37.30 in light trade. The mortgage insurance firm retook a 36.91 buy point in a shallow double-bottom base.Coherent (COHR), a specialist in industrial-use lasers, also defied the market's decline, rising more than 1.4% to 254.37 in heavy turnover.Other top-rated growth stocks to keep watching for potential entry points include IPG Photonics (IPGP) and Grubhub (GRUB), formerly on IBD Sector Leaders. Grubhub, which enables restaurants to attract more customers by being on the company's popular food service app, edged slightly up to 45.03, extended 6% past a 42.35 buy point in a long double-bottom base.Grubhub, currently No. 26 in the IBD 50, was featured as early as mid-January in IBD's Sector Leaders column, which noted that the software firm's 22% decline from head to toe in a new base was well within the appropriate range for a good cup base or double bottom.IPG gained nearly 1% to 136.73 and volume is running slightly ahead of its normal pace. The stock, which gapped up sharply on May 2 on a strong Q1 report (adjusted earnings up 50%, revenue up 38%), is for now well extended past a 124.37 flat-base entry.Meanwhile, certain retailing stocks got pummeled, reaffirming the problems that some brick and mortar store chains continue to have amid big gains in e-commerce.Macy's (M), which had joined the Leaderboard Short Sales list on March 6 when it crossed back below its 50-day moving average near 31.72, got slammed on Thursday with a 14% drop to 24.99. Volume has already shot well beyond 29 million shares vs. its 50-day average of 5.7 million. The department store chain, which already has plans to close 100 locations, reported a 40% drop in earnings to 24 cents a share, missing views by 31%, as revenue dipped 8% to $5.34 billion.That marked the ninth straight quarter of falling revenue.Luxury furnishings firm RH (RH) and Nordstrom (JWN) also fell hard in the stock market today, losing 8% and 7%, respectively. Unlike Macy's, however, both stocks continue to tread on the north side of their 50-day moving averages.RH, formerly known as Restoration Hardware, has generally been acting well since it cleared a first-stage deep bottoming base pattern with a 39.38 buy point on March 29 in triple average turnover.RELATED:Where Is The Market Headed?
