Last week, we learned from Piper Jaffray that teens love Apple (AAPL) iPhones, Nike (NKE) and Disney (DIS) movies.This week, a Conde Nast-Goldman Sachs report reveals the fashion, retail and beauty brands that their slightly older millennial peers love. L Brands' (LB) Victoria's Secret, LVMH-owned Sephora and Nike make the top three in favorability rankings, said Bloomberg, which acquired the results.And unsurprisingly, what millennials like and what Wall Street likes doesn't always overlap. Despite the recent softness in handbag trends, all three major purse makers made the list.Rounding out the top 10 favorites list were Coach (COH), Kate Spade (KATE), Michael Kors (KORS), Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Lululemon (LULU), DSW (DSW) and Nordstrom (JWN).Still, it's perhaps worrying for brick-and-mortar-based retailers that their greatest online nemesis is also climbing the ranks.IBD'S TAKE: The Conde Nast-Goldman Sachs study is but another reflection of the ongoing existential crisis faced by retailers — but the situation has created potential shorting opportunities for investors.Amazon (AMZN) topped the list as men's favorite retailer across all categories, said Bloomberg, citing the report, which also bestowed Amazon with the title of "Most-Loved Brand" overall.The recent Piper Jaffray teen survey showed similar results: Amazon gained ground as the No. 1 preferred shopping website among teens, reaching 43% share, said analysts."(Amazon) Prime adoption has increased across all income brackets in each of the past six surveys," said Piper Jaffray analysts in last week's note.L Brands rose 1.5% on the stock market today. Nike fell 0.45%. Kate Spade lost 0.6%. Michael Kors dipped 0.1% while Coach fell 0.3%.Ulta Beauty fell 1.2% to 279.46, still above a 274.09 buy point but dipping below its 50-day moving average after undercutting that support level for the first time this year.Amazon slipped 0.5% to 899.20, just in range from an 860.96 four-weeks-tight entry. (The 5% chase zone ends at 904).RELATED:The Strongest Evidence Yet For An iPhone 'Supercycle'?Nike Is No Longer The Top New Apparel Brand For Teen Boys: Piper Jaffray SurveyWalt Disney Is In Buy Range, And You Can Thank Teens

If March went out like a lamb, the lamb was toting a shopping bag. Retail groups posted the three largest gains among industries over the past week. Home furnishings retailers turned in the second-largest gain among industries in March. Department stores were the week's long strider, up more than 9% in their best week since the 17% rally following the…

The retail industry is facing an existential crisis — and not while mired in the depths of recession, but as the economy notches its eighth year of expansion.XIn March alone, Sears Holdings (SHLD), the parent of Sears and Kmart stores, said "substantial doubt" exists about its survival prospects after losing more than $10 billion over six years and watching sales fall for even longer. Urban Outfitters (URBN) likened the troubled industry to a housing bubble that has popped. And Bloomberg reported that women's apparel chain Bebe Stores (BEBE) plans to close all its 168 stores and go online only. (On Wednesday, it said it will close 21 stores and explore options for the rest.)As retailers take a hard look at the future in the age of Amazon.com (AMZN), investors face a big question of their own: Are retail stocks just flat-out doomed?No analyst interviewed for this story was ready to declare the physical store dead. But retail's wounds still run deep, and there are almost certainly too many stores in the U.S. Many stocks of top chains, while not as low as during the Great Recession, are rolling over into pronounced downtrends. The weak stock action creates short-selling opportunities for investors who believe the worst for retail is yet to come.A Yardeni Research report estimated that online shopping has grown to 29.1% of retail sales of items like general merchandise, apparel and accessories, and furniture — but not autos and fuel. That's up from less than 10% in the late 1990s. Over the same period, department stores' share of sales withered to 12.6% from around 30%.Still, companies that sell things within walls, floors and ceilings still have options in a $4 trillion market."There's no way Amazon becomes a $4 trillion e-tailer in 10 years," said Jeff Roster, vice president of retail strategy at IHL Group. "That's just not going to happen."Analysts say physical stores can still be vital in a connected, buy-anywhere, retail-everywhere world, with chains experimenting with new uses for their locations and even e-commerce companies seeing the value of in-store experiences."There's plenty they can do," Roster said of retailers. "The question is: Will they do it?"Meanwhile, the weight has accumulated on retail stocks. Take Macy's (M), which earlier had been praised for its aggressive efforts to integrate online and in-store operations. The department store's shares have lost more than half their value since July 2015. Earnings and sales have fallen for eight consecutive quarters.L Brands (LB), whose Victoria's Secret brand ought to be more insulated from e-commerce, has seen its stock halved since late 2015. The SPDR Retail ETF (XRT) has fallen some 20% over the past two years.IBD'S TAKE: Retail stocks trending below their declining 200-day moving averages offer shorting opportunities. For example, Macy's is struggling to get back in the 30s, but that would set up yet another test of the 50-day average and a possible short entry. Dillard's has stumbled this year, down as much as 25%, and just got turned away from its 50-day. See if it can hold support at 46.56.As those trends have solidified, Berkshire Hathaway (BRKB) CEO Warren Buffett, who prides himself on being a long-term investor, divested almost all his stake in Wal-Mart (WMT) in Q4. He told CNBC in February that "the online thing is very hard to figure out, you know?"Amazon, Buffett said, was a company "that's gonna have everybody in their sights. And they've got delighted customers.""Now, Wal-Mart's pushing forward online themselves and they've got all kinds of strengths," he later added. "But I just decided that I'd look for a little easier game."For much of the past 60 years, retail was an easier game. The postwar population explosion held consumerism aloft for years, says Doug Stephens, founder and CEO of retail advisory service Retail Prophet. When baby boomers' spending slowed as they reached their 50s, growth in personal credit — spurred by financial deregulation — helped pick up the slack, or at least masked weaker trends, he says."It allowed a lot of retailers to get away with being pretty average," Stephens said. "The average American aspired to be average. They aspired to the middle-class average lifestyle, and retailers like JCPenney (JCP) and Sears and others were happy to accommodate them by selling average goods and average prices with average experiences."Then the financial crisis and recession hit. The resulting consumer flight to either luxury or deep discounting hollowed out retail's middle-of-the-road set, he added.That has left the retail industry with too many stores, not enough shoppers, and more bankruptcies. Sports Authority was liquidated last year. Payless ShoeSource filed for bankruptcy on Tuesday and disclosed plans to close 400 stores. Markets are wondering if Sears and JCPenney are next.U.S. retail square footage per capita is more than six times that in Europe or Japan, Urban Outfitters CEO Richard Hayne said in March. Deutsche Bank in February estimated that among the retailers it follows, more than 13,100 stores will have closed during the decade ending this year. The analysis indicated that 6,400-plus locations could still be pruned from those companies' store counts.With more companies clearing out of their store space, malls can try to re-anchor their properties with grocery stores and fill in other spots with restaurants and fitness centers. The anchor stores tend to draw foot traffic, but their long stretches of square footage make those spaces hard to fill, Deutsche Bank analysts say."Fewer retail stores should translate into a direct decline in the number of viable retail properties, including malls," Deutsche Bank analysts Ed Reardon and Simon Mui wrote in February. "An enclosed mall can quickly reach a 'tipping point' where a decline in foot traffic leads to further closures and rent declines (aka the mall death spiral)."And yet the store persists, with even e-commerce companies recognizing its value. In fact, the physical store is still an efficient way to grab customers, especially as the cost of acquiring them online has gone up, Cowen analyst Oliver Chen said.Nordstrom's (JWN) Trunk Club, an e-commerce site that delivers clothing according to the wearer's tastes, has opened physical stores in recent years. Amazon has opened pop-up stores and plans to launch grocery stores.The pop-up, often backed by heavy online promotion, can also lend brick-and-mortar retailers flexibility and intrigue."When you start to see a pop-up store by Amazon, that to me validates (the idea) that there is still a place for a brick-and-mortar, touch-and-feel type of retail experience," said Tom Caporaso, CEO of Clarus Commerce.Newcomers to the business, particularly in clothing, also found different ways to retail, like using real-time data and greasing their supply chains to respond more quickly to fashion trends, said Peter Dixon, who runs a number of consumer discretionary-focused funds at Fidelity, noting that it was shortsighted for some retailers to blame their problems solely on the rise of e-commerce."Hiring star merchants to forecast fashion trends 12 months ahead of time and then commit to inventory orders nine months in advance of a season?" he said. "It just doesn't seem to work on a consistent basis anymore."IBD'S TAKE: Other potential shorts include Ralph Lauren, whose stock is bumping up against its 50-day moving average. A decisive move below 75 would dump it at the lowest levels in nearly seven years. And L Brands last touched its 10-week moving average in December. Wait for an attempted rebound to that line before betting on another plunge.What may work, after retailers shrink their real-estate footprint, is a hybrid approach to stores that accommodates online orders and has more attractive floor space.Analysts say vacant stores could be used as warehouses and pickup spots for online orders. Or, in existing stores, a smaller floor space might be used to display merchandise, while a larger back area would serve the e-commerce end.Macy's and Target (TGT) are already considering such a store layout. Target has said 55% of online orders are completed at its stores, potentially strengthening the case for the strategy.Wal-Mart, meanwhile, has tried to stay digitally relevant through acquisitions. The company last year shelled out $3 billion for online discounter Jet.com. In March, Wal-Mart acquired ModCloth, which sells indie-and-retro-leaning women's apparel. Wal-Mart in February also bought online outdoor-gear retailer Moosejaw.Long-term, the ratio of apparel retailers' physical-store and online purchases could reach 50/50, Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar says. Along with a bigger focus on e-commerce, analysts stress the importance of shrinking store-counts and using the remaining stores as areas that are more "experiential."Several chains are trying different things along those lines, though their ability to replicate such formats on a large scale is questionable:"Specialty stores often know their customers on a personal level more closely than big-box stores do, but retailers like Target, Sears, and Wal-Mart also break up their stores into departments," Caporaso said over email. "They can therefore create experiential services in those areas that target specific subsections of their customer bases."Stephens, of the Retail Prophet, said stores could apply the pop-up approach to the way they handle in-store experiences, replenishing them several times a year to give consumers a reason to return.Such experiential offerings also speak to one of Amazon's weaknesses, especially as it picks up more merchants."If you want a white T-shirt, and you search for a white T-shirt, you're going to get thousands of results at all different price points, and no one wants to weed through that," Weishaar said.She and others say that retailers that can both build out their online infrastructure and maintain a unique identity are the most likely to weather the current storm of falling sales and fleeing investors."They'll be fine as long as they have a coolness to them," said Ross Gerber, CEO of Gerber Kawasaki Wealth & Investment Management. "Amazon will never be cool. It's just efficient and easy."

Macy's (M) stock plunged to its lowest level since 2011 on Tuesday, reflecting a broader market sell-off and an ongoing plunge for department stores and many other brick-and-mortar retailers as they deal with an ever-larger Amazon.com (AMZN) and a reinvigorated Wal-Mart (WMT).The department store chain's stock was down 3.2% to 28.42 in the stock market today, tumbling through its January support levels. Shares closed off their session lows but are nearing their next level of support — 22.66 — the low point of a cup base formed in the summer and fall during that year.J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 3.8% to a fresh 3-year low, Dillards (DDS) 3.6% to a five-year low. Nordstrom (JWN) lost 1.9% and Kohl's (KSS) 2.4%, both hitting their lowest levels since last August. IBD's Retail-Department Store group, ranked dead last out of 197 industry groups, is one of Tuesday's big losers after being Monday's worst performer.The SPDR S&P Retail ETF (XRT) stabbed through the bottom of a flat base, falling 2%.IBD'S TAKE: After a wave of grim holiday-quarter reports, retailers have been rushing to invest more in e-commerce. The existential crisis among brick-and-mortar retailers has grown more acute in recent months.Grim holiday-quarter results, bankruptcy filings and planned store-closures have piled up as Amazon sucks the life from malls and a younger generation of shoppers spends its money on experiences rather than things. Home-improvement and off-price retail, which are seen as more immune to e-commerce, are among the few bright spots. Meanwhile, Wal-Mart, a member of the Dow Jones industrial average, has begun a new price war — pinching discounters, department stores and grocery stores. Wal-Mart had strong online sales, and has continued an e-commerce buying spree and expansion.Amazon fell 1.6% after hitting an all-time high in morning action. Wal-Mart edged down just 0.1%.Department stores are working to develop their own small-but-fast-growing e-commerce sales, but closing physical stores also limits the omnichannel pickup and return options.RELATED:Department Stores Continue To Dive As Investors Doubt Viability Vs. AmazonTrump Seeks Retail Growth As CEOs Try To Block Border TaxBurlington Rebrands Itself To Show It's More Than Just Coats

Stocks bucked up from a weak start to end on solid ground Thursday, as economic data and oil prices drove some of the day's widest gains.The Dow Jones industrial average, the S&P 500 and the Nasdaq Composite all ended up 0.3%, a solid finish after all three indexes traded flat-to-lower for the first 15 minutes of the day. Preliminary data showed volume mixed, higher on the Nasdaq, lower on the NYSE, vs. action on Wednesday.Bank and financial groups comprised seven of the 10 largest gains among industry groups, buoyed by the Commerce Department's revision of its fourth-quarter GDP estimate, to 2.1% growth, up from 1.9%. Foreign banks and gold miners were two of the five worst industry declines on the stock market today.A half-dozen stocks on the Dow industrials clocked gains of better than 1%. Exxon Mobil (XOM) topped the group, rising 1.8%, aided by a second straight 2% gain in oil prices that sent West Texas Intermediate prices back above $50 per barrel.Nike (NKE) was the only Dow Jones industrial average play that dropped more than 1%.ConocoPhillips (COP) led the S&P 500 with a 9% advance. The Houston-based energy producer announced Wednesday plans to sell its Canada tar sands assets to Calgary-based Cenovus Energy (CVE) for $13.3 billion. The move earned Conoco an upgrade to buy, from hold, along with an 8% price target increase from UBS. Cenovus shares dived 13%.Akamai Technologies (AKAM) slumped 4% in big trade. The network solutions leaders said late Wednesday that it would acquire software startup Soasta for an undisclosed cost. Soasta reportedly counts Apple (AAPL), Target (TGT) and Nordstrom (JWN) among the customers for its performance testing and analytics program CloudTest. The loss sent Akamai to a test of support at its 40-week line.IBD 50 stock Momo (MOMO) hammered out a 5% gain, sending shares to new highs and up more than 7% for the week. Shares are up 49% since clearing a 23.96 cup-with-handle buy point in February.Also taking out new highs among IBD 50 stocks was Commscope Holding (COMM). The provider of telecom connectivity services bumped up 3% in above-average trade. Shares are up 11% since topping a 38.10 flat-base buy point in February.RELATED:5 Dow Index Stocks That Are Near Buy Points: Investing Action PlanWill Snap, Mulesoft IPOs Kick Up A Stampede Of Tech Unicorns?

The Dow industrials stumbled at the finish Wednesday as the major indexes posted a mixed close.The Nasdaq led by strides, up 0.4% and lifting the index to a 1.2% gain so far for the week. The S&P 500 managed a 0.1% gain, while the Dow Jones industrial average backed off 0.2%.Trading volume was weak Wednesday in a session complicated by bleed-through from overseas, where the U.K. officially set in motion its two-year deadline to negotiate an exit from the European Union. U.S. legislators also weighed in, approving a bill late Tuesday that would permit much broader use of consumer data by internet service providers. Rising oil prices, analyst upgrades and downgrades, and the season's slowing trickle of earnings reports also had their say on today's stock market action.Department stores, ranked dead last among IBD's 197 industry groups, scored Tuesday's best gain among industries. Dillard's (DDS) surged 8%, JCPenney (JCP) jumped 6% and Nordstrom (JWN) rung up a 5% gain.Home-furnishings retailers posted the second-largest gain among industries. RH (RH), formerly Restoration Hardware, was the big winner here, marking up a 15% gain. The high-end-furnishings retailer reported fourth-quarter revenue and earnings declines slightly better than its pre-announced guidance. Management's first-quarter revenue guidance was well above consensus projections.Williams Sonoma (WSM) caught some of the updraft, posting a 4% gain in heavy trade — enough to retake support at the stock's 200-day moving average.Chevron (CVX) led the Dow industrials, up 0.8% and aided by a 2% pop in oil prices. UnitedHealth (UNH) notched the Dow's weakest move, down 1.1%.The S&P 500's top dog Wednesday was Vertex Pharmaceuticals (VRTX). The Boston-based biotech vaulted 20% higher after reporting positive results from clinical trials of its experimental cystic fibrosis treatment pill combining tezacaftor and ivacaftor. The gain sent shares beyond buy range above a double-bottom-base buy point of 98.03Amazon.com (AMZN) led the FANG group of big tech names, rising 2.2% in firm trade. Barclays initiated coverage on Amazon, Facebook (FB) and Alphabet (GOOGL) with overweight ratings. Facebook rose 0.6%; Alphabet jumped 1.2%.Amazon's move lifted the IBD Leaderboard stock past an 860.96 buy point in a four-weeks-tight pattern.Among IBD 50 stocks, China-based Weibo (WB) swatted a 4% advance after Barclays also launched coverage of the microblogging site with a 66 price target. Shares ended in buy range above a prior buy point of 52.59.RELATED:The Other NATO Faces This Threat: Investing Action PlanCrude Nears $50 On Weak Inventory Gain, Gasoline Supply Drop

Shares of Macy's (M), Kohl's (KSS), Nordstrom (JWN), J.C. Penney (JCP), Costco Wholesale (COST) and other retailers are getting slammed Monday, but it's not yet clear what exactly is weighing on the sector.Macy's closed down 3.4% at 30.69 on the stock market today after losing 4.4% on Friday. Kohl's also lost 3.4%, Nordstrom 1.8%, J.C. Penney 4.8%. IBD's Retail-Department store group fell 3.3% Monday, one of the very worst performers out of 197 industries that IBD tracks.IBD'S TAKE: Macy's has been added to IBD's Leaderboard, which provides annotated chart analysis of actionable stocks. Leaderboard typically focuses on growth stocks at or near buy points, but Macy's is among a new crop of possible short sales.February store sales sank 17%, said Business Insider on Monday, citing Bloomberg and First Data. That data appeared to be public last week, per a tweet from Bloomberg reporter Jodi Xu Klein:U.S. department store Feb sales downs 17%, tax refunds may help, says Bloomberg Intelligence #retailers— Jodi Xu Klein (@jodixu) March 3, 2017Meanwhile, the New York Post reported late Friday that Macy's bidder Hudson's Bay isn't pleased with the "high price" being asked for the nation's largest department store chain. Hudson's Bay also hasn't lined up financing yet for a Macy's bid, Reuters reported on Friday.And NPD Group said Monday that apparel sales grew 3% in 2016 to reach $218.7 billion, but were struggling to rise beyond that."The industry had positive overall performance with growth in most categories, but it has struggled to exceed 3% sales growth since 2013, as significant gains in select consumer and retail segments were offset by declines in others," said NPD.Costco and Target (TGT) are also swept up in Monday's downward action. Costco fell 2.1%, undercutting its 50-day line intraday. Costco gapped down 4.4% on Friday following its report of weaker-than-expected earnings and sales.Target, which crashed 14% last week on its own weak results and guidance, lost 2.2%. But Wal-Mart (WMT) dipped just 0.2%.Retail Metrics head Ken Perkins says there's "no specific reason" he's aware of for the broad sector decline, though "you can probably take your pick."Among those issues he cited: delayed tax refunds, broader Q4 earnings weakness — down 2.1% year-over-year, he said — concern over the border adjustment tax, high levels of distressed debt in retail, and of course, Amazon (AMZN).Perkins also noted that retail earnings pre-announcements "are running 5-1 negative-to-positive so far this earnings season."RELATED:Target Dives To 2014 Levels: 'We're Slow And Have Too Much Inventory'Costco To Raise Membership Fees After Fiscal Q2 Earnings, Sales MissJ.C. Penney To Close 130-140 Stores After Mixed Q4, Comp Sales DropAs 'Amazon Effect' Barrels On, Here's How Big Box Retailers Are Faring OnlineMacy's Eyes 'Entertainment Options' After Profit, Sales Fall For 8th Quarter

Nearly a week after Nordstrom (JWN) said it would stop selling Ivanka Trump-branded merchandise — reportedly due to poor sales performance — President Trump has finally weighed in on the matter.My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a great person — always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 8, 2017He, like many others in the social media sphere, appears to believe that politics motivated the brand drop. Campaigns such as #GrabYourWallet and others have been urging consumers to boycott retailers that sell merchandise affiliated with the Trump family brands.It is widely reported that Nordstorm has decided not to sell the Ivanka Trump brand for this season, ostensibly leaving the door open to picking up the label in the future.The upscale department store reiterated on its own Twitter page the reasons for its decision.@TimmyLupusbased Based on the brand's performance we've decided not to buy it for this season.— Nordstrom (@Nordstrom) February 8, 2017The White House doubled down, with spokesman Sean Spicer saying that Trump "has every right to stand up for his family," accusing Nordstrom of making a "direct attack" on the president's policies.Nordstrom touched a six-month low intraday, but closed up 4.1% at 44.53 on the stock market today, marking its biggest one-day gain in two months.IBD's TAKE: Predictably, the #BoycottNordstrom hashtag took on a different flavor last week following Nordstrom's decision: "#BoycottNordstrom Swings From Left To Right After Ivanka Trump Drop."There are now just three styles of Ivanka Trump shoes on the Nordstrom site, down from four late last week. That's a sharp drop, however, from the 71 styles reportedly available as of early December, according to Grab Your Wallet.Fashion news site Racked.com reported that Neiman Marcus, Belk, HSN and ShopStyle have also dropped Ivanka Trump's label in recent days.

Dow Jones Industrial Average component Goldman Sachs (GS) was downgraded Friday, while Acacia Communications (ACIA), Kohl's (KSS), L Brands (LB) and Nordstrom (JWN) had their price targets lowered.The investment banking giant was downgraded to sell from hold at Berenberg, which said that all of Goldman's positives were already priced in the stock.Goldman shares fell 1.5% to 247.35 on the stock market today, with falling 10-year Treasury yields also weighing on the Dow stock.Acacia's price target was lowered to 100 from 125 at Needham, but did keep a buy rating, after the fiber-optic gear maker gave first-quarter earnings guidance of 63-70 cents per share, below the 78 cents analysts expected, and also offered a weak revenue outlook. But its Q4 results beat Wall Street expectations.Acacia shares plunged 14.8% to 54.04 after sinking as low as 52.60.Acacia Plummets On Weak Guidance, But Analysts Rise To DefendKohl's price target was cut to 43 from 47 at Telsey Advisory Group. Victoria's Secret parent, L Brands' price target was lowered to 51 from 62 at Mizuho and to 60 from 83 at Telsey.Telsey also cut Nordstrom's price target to 50 from 52, after the department store chain reported mixed Q4 results and gave weak earnings guidance late Thursday.Earlier Thursday, Kohl's reported quarterly earnings above analyst views but revenue was in line with expectations. On Wednesday, L Brands reported mixed Q4 results and gave weak Q1 and full-year guidance as it warned of a 20% plunge in February same-store sales at Victoria's Secret.Kohl's shares rose 5.1% Friday after falling 2.1% Thursday. L Brands rallied 4.2% after tumbling 16% on Thursday to its lowest level in nearly four years. Nordstrom shares climbed 5.7% to 46.46.Retailers struggled over the important holiday season as shoppers continued to avoid crowded malls to shop online instead. So Kohl's, Macy's (M) and others have expanded their online offerings to help compete against Amazon (AMZN).RELATED:

The White House on Friday denied a report that President Trump economic advisor Gary Cohn told CEOs Friday morning that the Trump administration opposes House Republicans' border adjustment tax plan."There is no daylight between Gary Cohn and the President ... At no point during this conversation did Gary make a statement of support or opposition to the House border adjustability plan," reported Axiom, which also issued the original news on Cohn's comments at a private meeting of The Business Council.It's a new a layer of contradictory statements and signals from Trump and his administration on a border adjustment.  On Thursday, Trump told Reuters that he supports "some sort" of border tax.Before he took office, Trump panned the idea of a border tax, saying it would be too "complicated" and push up the dollar.Trump will have a new opportunity to clarify his position on a border tax —  or add to the confusion — in a speech before Congress Tuesday night.But a 20% border tax would raise some $1 trillion in revenue, helping to pay for a cut in the federal corporate tax rate to 20% from 35%.Chiefs at General Electric (GE), Boeing (BA) and four other members of the Dow Jones industrial average are among 16 CEOs who recently endorsed a House GOP plan. But fellow Dow stock Wal-Mart and many retailers are strong opposed, saying it will send prices soaring for consumers. A border tax faces a tough fight in Congress.The initial Cohn report helped lift big retailers such as Macy's (M) and Dow industrials component Wal-Mart (WMT) sharply higher Friday.Wal-Mart rose 1.5% in afternoon trading on the stock market today. Macy's climbed 2.4%. Fellow department stores Kohl's (KSS) and Nordstrom (JWN) rallied 5% and 6%, respectively, helped by post-earnings analyst calls. J.C. Penney (JCP), which Friday announced big plans for store closures, after reporting mixed Q4 results, tumbled 5.5%.General Electric and Boeing shares edged higher.RELATED:Trump Backs Border Tax: Here's How To Make It LegalThese Six Dow Components Back Border Tax, But Shallow Support Shows Why It's In TroubleIf Border Tax Dies, Trump Corporate Tax Cut May CollapseThe Trump Economy

J.C. Penney (JCP) reported mixed fourth-quarter results before the open Friday and announced the closure of 130-140 stores — about 13%-14% of its locations — in the next few months.Estimates: EPS to jump 56% to 61 cents while revenue dips 0.3% to $3.98 billion.Results: EPS of 64 cents on revenue of $3.96 billion. Same-store sales fell 0.7%, worse than the 0.5% drop forecast from Consensus Metrix.J.C. Penney's home, salon, fine jewelry and Sephora segments were its top performers.The department store chain said it will release a full list of planned closures in mid-March. Those stores will shutter in Q2 2017.Outlook: Full-year EPS of 40-65 cents, with the midpoint below consensus of 56 cents, and same-store sales down 1% to up 1%. J.C. Penney is also offering voluntary early retirement to 6,000 employees. The company's store closures, payroll reductions and other moves should results in annual savings of $200 million.Stock: Shares sank 5.8% to close at 6.46 on the stock market today, after dropping 2.7% to 6.86 on Thursday.Kohl's (KSS) and Macy's (M) both reported sales and comparable sales declines in the key holiday quarter, and Macy's plans to shutter 34 more stores over the next few years.Wal-Mart (WMT) revenue grew but still missed forecasts. Late Thursday, Nordstrom (JWN) reported mixed Q4 results and gave weak full-year earnings guidance.While Amazon (AMZN) has been threatening to eat up more market share, sending brick-and-mortar foot traffic down further, retailers now face the prospect of a tax on imports.President Trump told Reuters Thursday that he "certainly support(s) a form of tax on the border," though he did not endorse the current House Republicans' plan. The primary concern over a tax on imports is that it would ultimately raise prices for shoppers.But on Friday, Trump economic aide reportedly told CEOs that the White House opposes the House GOP border tax plan.Wal-Mart stock finished 1.5% higher, with Macy's up 2.3%. Kohl's and Nordstrom climbed 5.1% and 5.7%, respectively, helped by postearnings analyst calls and comments from a White House economic adviser downplaying a House proposal for an import tax.RELATED:White House Opposes House GOP Border Tax Plan; Retailers RallyAs 'Amazon Effect' Barrels On, Here's How Big Box Retailers Are Faring OnlineMacy's Eyes 'Entertainment Options' After Profit, Sales Fall For 8th Quarter

Stocks staged a late rally Friday to lift the major market indexes to a positive finish. The Dow Jones industrial average extended its win streak to 11.The Nasdaq led with a 0.2% advance, the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Dow eked out a fractional gain. Small caps underpeformed with the Russell 2000 slipping 0.1%. Volume was lighter across the board vs. Thursday, according to preliminary numbers.Oil, banks and gold miners led the downside in the stock market today, while department stores, apparel retailers and heavy construction stocks outperformed. West Texas intermediate crude futures slid nearly 1% to $54.03 a barrel.Wal-Mart (WMT) and Johnson & Johnson (JNJ) were the Dow's biggest winners, rising 1.5% apiece. Financials and energy lagged with Goldman Sachs (GS), JPMorgan (JPM), Chevron (CVX) and Exxon Mobil (XOM) each down nearly 1% or more.Apple (AAPL) fell nearly 1% early but pared its losses to close 0.1% higher. The iPhone maker's shares have rallied 16% since breaking out from a cup-with-handle buy point early last month with a 118.12 buy point.Nvidia (NVDA) also staged an upside reversal, gaining nearly 1%, after slumping as much as 5% early. Shares plunged 9% Thursday after several analysts cut their ratings and price targets, saying the graphics chipmaker was overvalued. But Mizuho Securities and UBS reiterated their buy ratings and called the pullback a buying opportunity.Universal Display (OLED) surged 20% to an all-time high after the company reported Q4 results that beat forecasts and initiated a dividend of 3 cents a share. Shares are now more than 20% extended from a 67.98 handle buy point, in profit-taking range.Nordstrom (JWN) popped 6% to reclaim its 50-day line in fast trade after announcing mixed Q4 results and weak earnings guidance after the close Thursday. The department store retailer shrugged off a price target cut from Telsey Advisory Group to 50 from 52.On the downside, Acacia Communications (ACIA) gapped down 15% to a seven-month low as it continues its descent from a September peak. Needham lowered its price target to 100 from 125. The fiber optics products maker's Q4 results topped views, but its Q1 earnings outlook disappointed.Mobileye (MBLY), down more than 2% in heavy volume, was one of the IBD 50's biggest losers. No sell signals were triggered; the stock is just 8% below its 52-week high. Shares slipped back into a buy range from a 45.03 handle entry. Short-seller Citron Research gave the driver assistance technology company, which on Wednesday beat Q4 earnings and sales estimates, a 35 price target.Economic data on tap for Monday include durable goods orders and the pending home sales index, both for January. The Fed's Robert Kaplan is also slated to speak.Oil producer EOG Resources (EOG), Priceline (PCLN) and Workday (WDAY) are among companies scheduled to report quarterly earnings Monday.RELATED:Mobileye Becomes A Citron Short-Sale Target For Second TimeNvidia Fall Stemmed By Reassuring Analyst Comments

Stocks sagged early Friday with the Dow industrials poised to break a 10-day winning streak as Caterpillar (CAT), Goldman (GS) and Apple (AAPL) weighed.The Nasdaq fell 0.4%, the S&P 500 shed 0.3% and the Dow Jones industrial average gave up 0.2%. Small caps lagged with the Russell 2000 down 0.5%. Volume was tracking higher across the board vs. the same time Thursday.Automakers, fiber optics and oil plays were among the biggest decliners in today's stock market action, while gold miners, department stores and other retailers outperformed. West Texas intermediate crude futures slid nearly 1% to $54.06 a barrel, still up more than 1% for the week. Gold prices climbed 0.2% to $1,254.00 an ounce, also up more than 1% for the week.Goldman Sachs and Caterpillar led Friday's downside on the Dow with losses of about 1.3% each. Berenberg cut Goldman to sell from hold. Shares are trading near their all-time highs from October 2007.Caterpillar slipped below its 50-day line for the first time in two weeks. The construction equipment maker fell 3% Thursday amid reports President Trump is mulling a delay of a big infrastructure bill until 2018.Apple fell nearly 1% in above-average volume but is just 1% off its all-time high. The iPhone maker's shares are well extended from a 118.12 cup-with-handle buy point cleared early last month.Nvidia (NVDA) opened 4% lower in heavy trade, extending its 9% plunge from the prior session. But the stock cut its losses to less than 1%. Shares remain well above their 200-day moving average and are 17% off their recent high. The stock triggered a second sell signal Thursday as it breached the 50-day line in huge volume; before that, it had fallen more than 8% from a 120.03 buy point.  BMO Capital and Instinet downgraded the graphics chip designer on Thursday.Acacia Communications (ACIA) slumped 15% to a seven-month low as it continues its descent from a September peak. Needham lowered its price target to 100 from 125. The fiber optics products maker's Q4 results topped views, but its Q1 earnings outlook disappointed.On the upside, Nordstrom (JWN) popped 6% to reclaim its 50-day line in fast trade after announcing mixed Q4 results and weak earnings guidance after the close Thursday. The department store retailer shrugged off a price target cut from Telsey Advisory Group to 50 from 52.Universal Display (OLED) surged 20% to an all-time high after the company reported Q4 results that beat forecasts and initiated a dividend of 3 cents a share.RELATED:Dow Stock Goldman Sachs Downgraded; Acacia Comm., Nordstrom PTs CutSteel, Materials, Mining Stocks Dive As Trump Mulls Infrastructure Delay To 2018

Acacia Communications (ACIA), Nordstrom (JWN), Gap (GPS), Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) and MercadoLibre (MELI) reported earnings after the close.Estimates: Wall Street expects the fiber-optic gear maker to report fourth-quarter earnings per share of 90 cents on revenue of $139.72 million.Results: EPS of 94 cents on revenue of $142.4 million.Outlook: Q1 EPS of 63-70 cents, below consensus for 78 cents, on revenue of $108 million-$114 million, below views for $137.4 million.Stock: Acacia sank 18% late. Shares closed up 1.9% at 63.43 in the stock market today, reversing higher and retaking their 50-day moving average.The company, which went public in May, makes silicon circuits, digital signal processors and other equipment to help data flow more freely through the nodes that connect a fiber-optic network.Acacia has grappled with an explosion of demand as the U.S. and China upgrade their communications infrastructure and big tech companies try to strengthen connections between massive data centers. However, Acacia's shares fell in November after the company forecast fourth-quarter sales that were only modestly above expectations.Estimates: Fiscal Q1 EPS of 44 cents, up 7% on revenue of $12.068 billion, down 5%.Results: EPS of 45 cents on revenue of $11.4 billion.Outlook: Full-year EPS of $1.88-$1.98, below consensus for $2.05.Stock: HPE tumbled 6.5% late. Shares finished 0.5% lower at 24.66, close to a 24.89 buy point of a cup base.Hewlett Packard Enterprise was created after Hewlett-Packard in 2015 split into two companies, the other being HP Inc. (HPQ), whose fiscal Q1 beat late Wednesday was helped by PC sales. HPE focuses on selling hardware and services for businesses transition to the cloud.RELATED:Splunk Q4 Earnings Easily Beat, But Stock Dives On Q1 OutlookEstimates: Fourth-quarter EPS of $1.15, down 2%, with revenue rising 4% to $4.35 billion.Results: EPS of $1.37 on revenue of $4.2 billion, and same-store sales fell 0.9%.Outlook: 2017 EPS of $2.75-$3.00, below consensus for $3.06, on a 3%-4% rise in net sales, with comp sales roughly flat.Stock: Nordstrom rose 2.7% late. Shares finished 3% lower at 43.94. The upscale apparel retailer's 50-day line undercut its 200-day line in recent days, a bearish cross.Nordstrom has been among the companies that President Trump has attacked since his election. Earlier this month, he accused the company of treating his daughter, Ivanka, "so unfairly" after the company opted not to sell Ivanka Trump-branded merchandise for now. Nordstrom said the decision was about weak sales, not politics.Politics aside, the company — like many middle-end and higher-end retailers — has foundered as Amazon (AMZN) drains the life from the U.S. mall and retail landscape.A JPMorgan analyst last year said that during talks with management, the company "cited full-line brick and mortar traffic levels as the worst since 1972 with the accelerating model shift from brick and mortar to online yet to reach equilibrium citing 'no easy answer' to restimulating foot traffic."Kohl's reported holiday earnings early Thursday, following Macy's on Tuesday.RELATED:Estimates: Fourth-quarter EPS of 51 cents, down 10.5%. Revenue is seen inching up to $4.394 billion.Results: EPS of 51 cents on revenue of $4.43 billion. Same-store sales rose 2%.Outlook: 2017 same-store sales to be flat to up slightly.Stock: Gap edged up 0.5% late. Shares ended down 3.6% at 23.97 as Gap consolidates above its 50-day and 200-day moving averages.The apparel retailer has also struggled with more vacant malls and thriving e-commerce, but has had a less contentious public relationship with Trump. CEO Art Peck was among those who attended a meeting last week at the White House between the president and retail executives.Retailers say border tax of some kind backed by the president could force them to raise prices, potentially hurting sales.Estimates: Wall Street expects the Latin America online marketplace to grow fourth-quarter EPS by 6% to 93 cents. Revenue is seen jumping 38% to $248.92 million.Results: EPS of $1.16 on revenue of $256.3 million.Stock: MercadoLibre rose 2% late. Shares closed down 0.3% at 199.82 after hitting a record high intraday. MercadoLibre broke out of a base on Jan. 24, continuing to climb steadily since then.RELATED:

The "Amazon (AMZN) effect" is well documented. Foot traffic at brick-and-mortar stores across America are declining as people spend their dollars online.But it's also shaping what is perhaps the new normal among department stores and other retailers as they fight for market share through a beefier online presence.At Kohl's (KSS), sales for the key holiday quarter were "weak," said CEO Kevin Mansell in the company's earnings release Thursday, as brick-and-mortar traffic declined. But that softness was "offset somewhat by strength in online demand."Kohl's shares fell 2.1% to 40.91 in the stock market today. For the key holiday quarter, total sales fell almost 3% to $6.21 billion, missing views for $6.22 billion, as comparable store sales drooped 2.2%. Per-share profit fell 9% to $1.44, besting expectations by 11 cents. Kohl's also raised its dividend by 10% to 55 cents.Fellow department store Macy's (M) logged similar Q4 results on Tuesday, with sales and comps down but "double-digit growth" in its online business.Wal-Mart (WMT) on Tuesday boasted a 29% U.S. e-commerce gain as its overall 1% revenue gain came up short.Soft in store, strong online is a recurring theme. Target's (TGT) November-December comparable store sales fell 3% as digital sales popped 30%. (That discounter reports next week.)But online sales are still a fraction of traditional stores' business, so it's hard for even strong e-commerce gains to move the needle.IBD'S TAKE: In an e-commerce-driven consumer landscape, the raison d'etre of malls is waning. Some shopping arenas are calling on mayhem and drama to boost foot traffic.Reducing store count is one way to combat crummy foot traffic. Kohl's said it closed 19 locations in 2016 and opened nine small-format locations, as well as a number of outlets.Macy's is 66 stores into its 100-store closure plan. The rest will be shuttered over the next few years. That will give the department store operator a "healthy physical portfolio" that will complement its growing online sales, said CEO Terry Lundgren on the Macy's earnings call on Tuesday.But the kicker is: as department stores close more stores, that may only in turn weigh on their e-commerce sales."Our customers buying online love to return in store," said Macy's CFO Karen Hoguet on the same call. "They love to shop in store, buy online. So we are, I think, forever going to lose some of that Macys.com business when we close a single-store market."Macy's shares rose 0.3% on Thursday but are continuing to find resistance at their 50-day line.Wal-Mart has taken a slightly different tack with its acquisition of smaller Amazon rival Jet.com and its push into online groceries. That helped drive its strong online sales gain as the big box retailer also gave bullish overall revenue guidance. Wal-Mart's 29% online sales gain is faster than Amazon's overall revenue growth of 22%, and that's flattered by its Amazon Web Services cloud division."We're the second-largest U.S. online retailer by revenue, one of the top three online retailers by traffic and our Wal-Mart app is among the top three apps in retail," said Wal-Mart CEO Doug McMillon on the call Tuesday.Wal-Mart shares fell 0.6% on Thursday but are still up solidly for the week.Wal-Mart recently dropped its Amazon Prime membership rival and announced that it would offer free two-day shipping for minimum orders of $35. Amazon this week dropped its free shipping minimum order to $35 for non-Prime members, but deliveries will take five to eight business days.Meanwhile, faster fashion and athleisure — two other ongoing trends — appear to be on the minds of Kohl's execs going into the new fiscal year."In 2017, we will accelerate our focus on becoming the destination for active and wellness with the launch of Under Armour (UAA) in early March," said Mansell. "We will also extend our efforts on improving our speed to market across all of our proprietary brands into all apparel areas and home."Kohl's said it expects $3.50 to $3.80 in diluted per-share earnings for fiscal 2017 and a 1.3% decline to 0.7% growth in total sales, vs Wall Street forecasts for $3.73 EPS on flattish sales.Comps are expected to range from a decline of 2% to flat sales for the year.Nordstrom (JWN) reported so-so results and guidance late Thursday. The upscale department store said Nordstrom.com sales topped $2.5 billion in 2016, more than 17% of total revenue. Nordstrom shares closed down 3.1% during the regular session, but recouped those losses late.RELATED:Wal-Mart Gives Strong Revenue Guidance As Q4 Online Sales Soar 29%Macy's Eyes 'Entertainment Options' After Profit, Sales Fall For 8th Quarter

Here's your Investing Action Plan for Thursday: what you need to know as an investor for the coming day. Although tomorrow will likely be dominated by breathless reactions to Tesla's (TSLA) quarterly report this evening, reports from Acacia Communications (ACIA), Baidu (BIDU), Gap (GPS), Nordstrom (JWN), Carrizo Oil & Gas (CRZO) and Parsley Energy (PE) also deserve attention. Data on…

Macy's (M) earnings and sales continued to decline in the holiday fourth quarter as the struggling department store gave cautious guidance.  The Terry Lundgren-led retailer vowed to invest in the shopping experience as e-commerce erodes its customer base.Macy's, which also operates the upscale Bloomingdale's chain, earned $2.02 a share, down 3% vs. a year earlier. Revenue fell 4% to $8.52 billion. It was the eighth straight quarter of year-over-year declines on the top and bottom line. EPS did top estimates for $1.96 but analysts had expected $8.62 billion in sales.Same-store sales fell 2.7% on an owned basis and were down 2.1% when also including licensed stores. Online sales grew at a double-digit pace, Macy's said.Macy's sees EPS for the current year of $2.90-$3.15, below consensus of $3.20. It expects sales to sink 3.2%-4.3%, in line with Wall Street forecasts. Company-owned comps are seen falling 2.2%-3.3%, with total same-store sales off 2%-3%."We will be investing for the future in 2017. Looking at the continued challenges in the retail environment and changing consumer shopping behaviors, we know we must evolve our strategy and execute faster," said Lundgren in a statement."Key to this is enhancing the customer experience in our stores where we are developing and testing concepts that feature new merchandise and entertainment options alongside enhanced technology to make shopping simpler. Additional initiatives that we believe will improve sales trends in 2017 include continued omnichannel improvements, an updated marketing strategy and a simplified pricing structure."Macy's said its off-price Backstage brand as a store-within-a-store format is boosting productivity. The retailer also is working on a plan to revive its beauty business.Macy's plans to invest $900 million this year.RBC Capital Markets analyst Brian Tunick called Macy's report a "non-event.""We continue to be intrigued by M's real estate optionality but believe business trends will remain challenged despite the company's ongoing initiatives," he wrote.But Cowen analyst Oliver Chen called the profit beat "encouraging, given that we believe investor sentiment and expectation bar was low heading into the quarter."Macy's stock rose as high as 33.49 in morning trade, but found resistance at its 50-day line. Shares fell 1 cent to 32.29 on the stock market today.Nordstrom (JWN), which reports results Thursday, advanced 0.4%, also well off morning highs. J.C. Penney (JCP), which reports Friday, added 0.4% as well. Kohl's (KSS) fell 0.45%.IBD'S TAKE: In an e-commerce-driven consumer landscape, the raison d'etre of malls is waning. Some shopping arenas are calling on mayhem and drama to boost foot traffic.It's been quite the roller coaster for Macy's stock in recent months. Department stores got a postelection bump, but that rally was short-lived after Macy's, Kohl's and others reported disappointing holiday-period sales figures. Shares have been trading below their 50-day moving average since mid-December.Macy's shares rose in recent weeks on reports that Macy's might be looking to sell itself, according to reports. Saks Fifth Avenue parent Hudson's Bay approached Macy's about a potential acquisition, said the Wall Street Journal in early February, although real estate talks were also said to be on the table.Macy's said it would not discuss "rumors or speculation," but executives did say they would "work closely" with its real estate team and "get a lot done" this year.Broadly, department stores have been in a rut, to put it gently. Amazon (AMZN) and e-commerce alternatives threaten to pressure brick-and-mortar stores even further, and retailers are stuck in a vicious cycle of heavy discounting that's tough to escape.Macy's insists that brick-and-mortar stores can thrive, with the goal of grabbing a larger of share of a declining pie."There's enough customers in the mall," CEO Lundgren said on the conference call. "It's just a matter of where they are shopping."Meanwhile, Dillard's (DDS), which also disclosed results Tuesday, reported diluted per-share earnings of $1.72 a share, including a 13-cent-per-share after-tax asset impairment, on 6% in revenue declines to $1.98 billion. Analysts had expected $2.26 a share on $2.01 billion in revenue."Our operating results reflect another quarter of mall traffic declines from continued retail industry challenges," said Dillard's CEO William Dillard II, in a statement. "In response, we are ramping up our efforts to bring more distinctive brand and service experiences to Dillard's, both in-store and online."Shares of Dillard's tumbled 8.3% to 53.55, hitting a five-year low intraday.RELATED:How Mayhem, Drama Can Help The American Mall Cheat DeathAmazon Expected To Introduce Line Of Private-Label Intimate ApparelSears Could Sell More Brands, Real Estate To Cut $1 BillionMacy's For Sale? Report Says Maybe; Investors Get Giddy

Once the cool new kid, Under Armour (UAA) is now sitting solo at the proverbial high-school cafeteria table after being perceived as getting chummy with the school bully.Following high-profile backlash to seemingly pro-Trump remarks in a recent CNBC interview, Under Armour CEO Kevin Plank has since clarified his statement, even taking out a full-page ad in the Baltimore Sun on Wednesday to highlight the company's values, which include equal rights, job creation, and a pro-immigration stance."We are publicly opposing the travel ban," detailed the letter. "With an anticipated new executive order on immigration set to come out, we will join a coalition of companies in opposition to any new actions that negatively impact our team, their families or our community."Last week, Plank told CNBC that having a pro-business president was "a real asset to this country," sparking headlines that the Under Armour chief was in favor of Trump, while leaders from Netflix (NFLX), Starbucks (SBUX) and elsewhere have been vocal in criticizing the president's actions, particularly on immigration.Nevertheless, the damage seems to have been done, and according to one analyst, it's going to take a while for the Nike (NKE) rival to shake off its newly acquired bad rap."Commentary by the CEO in a CNBC interview in a polarized political climate, and pointed response by Stephen Curry, The Rock, and Misty Copeland make it nearly impossible to effectively build a cool urban lifestyle brand in the foreseeable future," wrote Susquehanna analyst Sam Poser, referring to the brand's endorsers who have spoken out against Plank's comments.Poser, a longtime bull on Under Armour, has downgraded his rating twice in less than three weeks.Disappointing Q4 results last month spurred Susquehanna's initial cut from positive to neutral, but the latest slash to negative (read: sell) is mostly driven by the "reputational risk" that the athletic apparel brand now faces in the wake of those comments.In a report that was written and published prior to seeing Plank's Baltimore Sun letter, Poser also highlighted the high anti-Trump political sentiment at the Grammy Awards on Sunday, noting that Nike and Adidas both ran commercials "celebrating each brand's relationship to the community.""It is clear to us and UAA management that Under Armour needs to build its casual and lifestyle business in order to return to historical growth rates," said Poser. "Unfortunately, the brand's cool factor is generally dictated by the style influencers who were likely insulted by CEO Plank's comments, or at least the media's characterization of his comments."Poser also called for Plank to get "on air, in person, and fully address the issues facing Under Armour," adding that corporate releases lack perceived sincerity.Shares of Under Armour edged up 0.6% to close at 21.89 on the stock market today. Nike shares rose 0.3% to 56.64.IBD's TAKE: Shoppers threatened to boycott Under Armour for Plank's comments. The brand isn't the only retailer finding itself at the center of a Trump-related controversy. Nordstrom and Sears have both made headlines for dropping certain Trump-affiliated items from their product assortments.The Susquehanna analyst also cited challenges in building a lifestyle brand and said Under Armour's $55 hoodies and other items are "too basic." He slashed his price target on the stock to 14 from 24.Conversely, Morgan Stanley analyst Jay Sole — a longtime Under Armour bear — on Tuesday upgraded the stock to equal weight from underweight, in light of the lower valuation. He has a 20 price target on Under Armour."The stock price suggests the market now believes (Under Armour) is a much more mature brand than it previously thought," wrote Sole.RELATED:Sears Dumps Some Trump-Branded Goods But Aims To 'Leave The Politics To Others'President Trump Attacks Nordstrom To Defend Daughter's Business

A yawning trench of dirt, wood and exposed cables currently sits at the mouth of the Westfield Century City in west Los Angeles. The Apple (AAPL) store is still open and the Tesla (TSLA) showroom has been moved to a different spot, but much of the shopping center remains under construction.When it reopens this year, it will have expanded into a glamorous 1.2-million-square-foot beast of a mall — 422,000 square feet larger — complete with Italian food emporium Eataly, hip burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK) and "new high-fashion streetside boutiques."XIn fact, the Century City mall won't just be a mall, it will be "an immersive sensory experience unprecedented in the modern retail space," according to a 2015 Westfield press release. This location hardly needs a tuneup. With $1,457 in sales per square foot, it is the ninth-most productive mall in the country, according to a CNBC story from May, citing real estate research firm Green Street Advisors. So why spend $800 million on a makeover?Looks matter more than ever, particularly as social-media bragging rights become an essential part of the millennial shopping experience. So these days, every retailer has to put on a good show, ramping up the drama to boost foot traffic and cheat death as Amazon (AMZN) spells doom for more and more American malls."(Young people are) very into cataloging everything they do via social media, and so these more luxury experiences have more social currency," said Talmage Advisors CEO Liz Dunn.That could mean Snapchatting from inside a Tiffany (TIF) — regardless of whether you buy something — or taking a topside photo of your artisanal lunch. (Never has flat lay photography been so popular.)"Whatever it is, there's a lot more social currency to that than saying 'I'm at a TGI Friday's,' " she said.The mall's transformation into an "immersive sensory experience" contrasts with the post-World War II bloom of malls, which attracted Americans to cookie-cutter hubs with their one-stop-shopping convenience. That has since given way to the splendid isolationism of two-day shipping via Amazon Prime, hollowing out traditional malls and forcing the survivors to become purveyors of experiences that can be shared online.Fellow L.A.-based shopping center The Grove, owned by Caruso, underscores the trend and is a social-media maven's dream.It houses many of the same stores as a regional mall does — like Banana Republic, J. Crew and Anthropologie — but also features a fountain, trolley and live music, helping put it at No. 2 on CNBC/Green Street Advisors' list with a $2,200 in sales per square foot. The photogenic plaza was even once the backdrop for Hollywood-gossip show "Extra," which has no doubt upped its social cred among tourists who want a glimpse of glam."This is where all the B-list celebs, YouTube stars, and Instagram influencers shop (I saw an Instagram male model there myself when I went)," gushed one Yelp reviewer visiting from Toronto.The lure of exclusivity, that close cousin of luxury, is another way retailers have amped up the theatrics.It's a tactic long employed by an athletic-footwear industry that routinely releases shoes in small batches, driving up demand from sneakerheads and high-schoolers alike. There's even a sneaker stock exchange, StockX, devoted to the resale of Jordans, Kobes and anything Kanye has ever designed for Adidas.Other retailers have since caught on. Coach (COH) and Disney (DIS) last year introduced a limited-edition House of Mouse-themed handbag line. Spice Girl-turned-fashion designer Victoria Beckham is behind Target's (TGT) upcoming capsule collection. And H&M seems to have an endless series of designer linkups in the pipeline.The New York Times even declared 2016 "the year of the drop," referring to the slew of limited-edition releases and pop-up shops, like Kylie Jenner's blink-and-it's-gone store, designed to create shopper frenzy.The Hollywood Reporter called the December opening of Jenner's pop-up, located within the Westfield Topanga Mall in Los Angeles' San Fernando Valley, "mayhem."Mayhem is the antithesis of convenience, when it comes to shopping. But that is the point. No one wants to stand in line outside for hours waiting for laundry detergent. A Kylie Lip Kit, however, is not long for this world.To get a teen or 20-something to the mall — and most "drop" shoppers are under 30, noted the Times — the mall must act a little more like a nightclub, velvet ropes and all.Even supermarkets are in on the action: Some Whole Foods Market (WFM), Kroger (KR) and Gelson's locations feature wine bars, a premium add-on meant to keep grocery shoppers in stores longer.Such theater may seem gimmicky, but it works, and is also being seen in actual theaters. The local cineplex, a requisite component of any shopping mall, is also undergoing a revamp.On the defensive from Netflix (NFLX) and massive TVs, theaters have been making screens bigger, audio better, and seats more spacious. And as an alternative to grabbing popcorn from the concession stand and trying to find a decent seat, more theaters now serve cocktails and dinner to your reserved Barcalounger while that summer blockbuster plays in Imax 3D.AMC (AMC), for example, embarked three years ago on a $600 million reseating project to rip out traditional chairs and replace them with recliners.AMC, which has called its collective upgrades a "winning playbook," outlined at a recent presentation that attendance has grown 53% and revenue leapt 70% in its 1,500 or so reseated theaters. It has thousands more theaters in line to be updated.Top exhibitor chain Regal Cinemas (RGC) also recently attributed recent outperformance to plush seating, calling out recliner sites as the "biggest driver.""Theaters have to do something to differentiate themselves from the in-home experience," said RBC analyst Leo Kulp. "That's really what's driven these investments over the past several years."Theaters, full-service restaurants and other bells and whistles have woven themselves into a successful mall's narrative, but it may be a while before the experiential stuff surpasses retail stores that sell shirts and shoes."The future will certainly bring less retail, but it will take a few years to tip the scale" so that retailers become a mall's minority residents, said NPD Group retail analyst Marshal Cohen.There is also some hope for once-reliable mall anchors like Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), even as Macy's reportedly considers selling itself after a brutal holiday season.The Grove has a Nordstrom, and the revamped Westfield Century City is actually adding a department store to the mix, for a total of three major names. It will now house a two-story Macy's, three-story Bloomingdale's and a three-story Nordstrom that is being relocated from the next mall over.But the massive upgrades being made to shopping arenas could even further widen the gap between top-market malls and their less-moneyed brethren.Of the more-than-1,000 malls in America, the 300 or so top-market "A-malls" account for 75% of mall value (a metric comprised of sales productivity, size and other factors), according to Green Street Advisors.So what's a midtier mall to do? For developers, the answer may be: Change or die.Strong anchors are "imperative" for a shopping center's long-term viability, according to Green Street's 2017 mall outlook report, since income-generating tenants want malls with "vibrant," traffic-driving anchors.As department stores waver, Green Street's research points to restaurants, movie theaters and "traditional power-center tenants" — like Ulta Beauty (ULTA), Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS) and pet stores — as rising power players.But Talmage Advisors' Dunn is not optimistic."The problem is, it's a little bit of a self-fulfilling prophesy," she said. "The landlords aren't willing to invest in the lower-tier centers, and the thing that would potentially take a lower-tier center to help it jump a bracket is investment. But it's hard to justify the investment if the center's performance isn't in that top-tier range."

Add Sears Holdings (SHLD) and Sears-owned Kmart to the list of companies that are shedding some Trump-branded products — but the company insists that politics has nothing to do with it.The major retailer said on Saturday that Sears and Kmart would no longer carry several dozen Trump Home products, according to Reuters."As part of the company's initiative to optimize its online product assortment, we constantly refine that assortment to focus on our most profitable items," said Sears Holdings spokesperson Brian Hanover, according to a statement acquired by the outlet."Amid that streamlining effort, 31 Trump Home items were among the items removed online this week," he said. Those products were reportedly sold only online and not in brick-and-mortar Sears and Kmart stores.But responding to recent headlines via blog post, Sears said Monday that the changes reflect a routine shuffle of its product assortment and that "hundreds" of Trump and Ivanka Trump items are available on Sears.com through third-party marketplace sellers."I think any fair observer can understand why this confusion was generated and why we prefer to remain focused on serving our members and our marketplace sellers and leave the politics to others," wrote Sears Holdings Vice President of Corporate Communications Chris Brathwaite.Sears shares plunged 8.1% to close the regular trading session at 6.40 on the stock market today. But the stock rose nearly 26% Friday as the ailing retailer said it will slash costs further and could sell more core brands and real estate. The stock hit its lowest level since 2003 on Wednesday.Meanwhile, the Wall Street Journal reported Saturday a 32% sales decline of Ivanka Trump-brand merchandise at Nordstrom (JWN) in the prior fiscal year, citing internal Nordstrom data. The data also reportedly shows a more-than-70% sales tumble of the brand's footwear and clothing items in the second, third and fourth weeks of October vs. prior-year sales. Those weeks marked the period leading up to the election.IBD'S TAKE: With or without scrutiny from the president, retailers have been facing challenges, and malls have been forced to ramp up the drama in the age of Amazon (AMZN). Here's what that looks like.Boycotts of Trump-branded goods have surfaced in the form of the Grab Your Wallet campaign and criticism online. The President fired off a tweet at Nordstrom on Wednesday, less than a week after reports emerged that the upscale department store was dropping his daughters line of merchandise.My daughter Ivanka has been treated so unfairly by @Nordstrom. She is a great person -- always pushing me to do the right thing! Terrible!— Donald J. Trump (@realDonaldTrump) February 8, 2017Nordstrom said the change was a reflection of sales performance.While this is far from the first time that Trump has singled out an individual company on Twitter (TWTR), his tweet at the department store has raised concerns about ethical conflicts of interests and a blurred line between his roles as president and businessman.Despite the attack, Nordstrom shares rose sharply on Wednesday to notch its biggest one-day gain in two months. But Nordstrom dipped 2.3% Monday morning.Fashion news site Racked.com has reported that Neiman Marcus, Belk, HSN and ShopStyle have dropped Ivanka Trump merchandise.Meanwhile, Wal-Mart (WMT)-owned Jet.com also appears to have pulled Trump-branded goods, Mic reported, though Wal-Mart itself still offers Trump merchandise.T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, both owned by off-priced retail specialist TJX Cos. (TJX), also seem to be pulling back on Ivanka clothing.In other news, Under Armour (UAA) CEO Kevin Plank is under fire from his own brand's endorsers after calling Trump "a real asset to the country" in a recent CNBC interview.RELATED:President Trump Attacks Nordstrom To Defend Daughter's Business Sears Could Sell More Brands, Real Estate To Cut $1 Billion

Look up "sad mall" or "dead mall" online and you're likely to be confronted with images of desolate, shuttered shopping centers that have been left for dead. Overgrown plants crack through abandoned storefronts; crumbled tile litters broken-down escalators. It's a common-enough phenomenon that entire photography projects revolve around the state of the country's retail centers.Is this what 2017 holds for American shoppers?Not quite, but the upcoming year isn't exactly going to be a cakewalk, either. The hundreds of collective store closures (from Macy's (M), Wal-Mart (WMT) and others, combined) and bankruptcies (Sports Authority, Sports Chalet) in 2016 are enough to make even the most devoted shopaholic wonder if the future of commerce is one big Amazon.com (AMZN) screen."It's going to be a year of transition and a year of reckoning and a year of awakening for retailers," said Marshal Cohen, NPD Group's chief industry analyst.Retail sales excluding autos and gasoline rose 4% from Nov. 1 to Dec. 24, according to MasterCard's SpendingPulse. That suggests a stronger-than-expected holiday season, perhaps reflecting more optimistic consumers. But while digital sales continued to boom, with Amazon grabbing an ever-larger e-commerce share, brick-and-mortar locations faced declining traffic. And those trends are likely to intensify into the new year.The big discounts offered at apparel stores this holiday season echoed prior sales-heavy years, particularly 2015's. While retailers generally went into this important shopping period claiming that inventories were lean, stores feel they have no choice in an already cutthroat environment."Consumers have been trained that if they hold out, they will get a promotion," said Morningstar analyst Bridget Weishaar. "The other problem is that it's a really overcrowded space with no barriers to entry. A lot of retailers are choosing to compete on price."IBD'S TAKE: What's holding Amazon back from becoming a major player in beauty? For an in-depth look, read: "Why Amazon Has Been Powerless Against Beauty Stores."Retail Metrics President Ken Perkins said that outside of a few busy hours on the weekends, Holiday 2016 was "somewhat eerily quiet" at the mall.During store checks, his research firm observed but a "handful of people" at Foot Locker (FL), Abercrombie & Fitch (ANF) brand Hollister, American Eagle Outfitters (AEO) and Macy's. L Brands' (LB) Bath & Body Works "always seems to have a buzz," he said, but even Apple (AAPL) stores seemed less bustling than in years' past."Each year it feels like that lull is a bit deeper and deeper," said Perkins.Some of the lag can be attributed to holiday promotions being pushed up earlier in November, said NPD's Cohen, spreading out the spending. But the perhaps greater problem is the lack of product innovation and uniqueness on shelves, he said.In other words, there's not enough new, fun stuff to buy — for other people or for self-gifting purposes.NPD, which tracks the November-December shopping period week by week, said in its latest report that as of the week ending Dec. 10, dollar sales in the first six weeks of the holiday retail season were lagging the prior-year period by 4%.Brick-and-mortar traffic fell about 10% at stores through Dec. 17, according to Prodco Retail Traffic Index.One saving grace for brick-and-mortar locations: Christmas Eve — also the start of Hanukkah this year — was on a Saturday, while Dec. 26 was also a day off.The issues that faced retailers in 2016 are likely to continue to face them in 2017, without much abatement. Perkins highlighted the ongoing shift to online and mobile spending, a consumer taste for experiences instead of products, high promotional activity and a "hollowing out" of the middle class that leaves less disposable income on the table.And, of course, Amazon's insistent gains. On top of Prime shipping and Prime Video, the company's smart-home device, Alexa, can help Prime members place orders."(Alexa) cuts retailer out of the equation for consumers that are pressed for time," he said.Upper-tier malls — the kind that house Tiffanys (TIF) and Louis Vuittons and Shake Shacks (SHAK) — are expected to continue to perform well enough. But the average mall might still see some individual stores close up shop, say experts, unless they go out of their way to attract more foot traffic."Mid-tier malls are going to need to step up their game" with restaurants, movie theaters and lifestyle stores, said NPD's Cohen, adding that "the food court won't be good enough."Simon Property Group (SPG), a major mall operator, has tumbled 24% over the last five months, sinking Wednesday to the lowest level in nearly 16 months.That young people are doing more mobile shopping and are craving experiences is no surprise. But how retailers respond may foreshadow the brick-and-mortar industry's fate.Wal-Mart (WMT) investments (which include its e-commerce efforts) may weigh on short-term income growth but lead to foreseeable rewards in the future, said Perkins, whose store checks found that Wal-Mart has been "one of the busier stores" this season.In 2017, the top-performers list should feature some familiar names, by Perkins' estimate. Home Depot (HD) and Lowe's (LOW) are "two of the strongest performers in retail." He also sees off-price trio TJX (TJX), Ross Stores (ROST) and Burlington (BURL) continuing to do well, as well as Ulta Beauty (ULTA), which is "obviously a standout player."Home improvement, off-price and beauty all involve some element of in-store necessity: looking for just the right part, digging through bargain racks and trying on new makeup brands are usually best done in person.Department stores have had a choppy year, though Nordstrom (JWN) frequently gets a shout-out from analysts for being an "omnichannel" retailer that knows how to engage its customers across platforms. And unlike Macy's or Kohl's (KSS), which compete "with Amazon and everyone else on the internet," says Morningstar's Weishaar, Nordstrom has differentiated itself by catering to more affluent shoppers with a highly curated selection."If you go to Amazon and type in 'red dress,' you're going to get literally hundreds of pages of results to sift through that (are) not useful," she said. "If you go to Nordstrom, you're going to get 10 (products in line with) your price points and brands."Even so, Nordstrom was recently handed a downgrade from JPMorgan after the department store's management team said brick-and-mortar levels hadn't been that bad since 1972.In the future, being omnichannel might not be enough, particularly in a world increasingly populated by Alexa and Google Home devices.Retail "omnipresence" is key, said NPD's Cohen.That is, instead of simply giving customers a way to buy products both in-store and online, it would behoove retailers to latch onto shoppers before, during and after the transaction, he said. Educate them and anticipate their needs ahead of potential transactions, allow them different ways to buy, then stay in touch via product reviews or other methods following the purchase.The goal, said Cohen, is "that the store becomes the epicenter for the entire process."RELATED:Amazon's Top Selling Holiday Products Came From ... AmazonE.l.f. Beauty CEO Amin On Social Cosmetics And The Ageless Beauty BoomNordstorm's '1972' Warning Is Another Sign Of Dying Malls

Chains like Wal-Mart (WMT), Target (TGT), Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), which…

Nordstrom (JWN) shares tumbled Friday after JPMorgan (JPM) downgraded the department store, another dire sign for the dying mall industry.Nordstrom was cut to underweight from neutral and had its price target cut to 48 from 55 by the investment bankAnalysts, citing discussions with management, said the upscale department store didn't have enough "multiyear silver bullets" to boost sales growth. Further, the increasing costs to handle online traffic and online shopping is continuing to cannibalize the company's brick-and-mortar sales."Management cited full-line brick and mortar traffic levels as the worst since 1972 with the accelerating model shift from brick and mortar to online yet to reach equilibrium citing 'no easy answer' to re-stimulating foot traffic," JPMorgan analysts wrote in their note.Nordstrom shares plunged 8.7% to 50.48 on the stock market today, after closing just below its 50-day line on Thursday.On CNBC's "Mad Dash," host Jim Cramer said the JPMorgan note was a "very damning piece about the mall." It adds to a prior warning from Starbucks' (SBUX) then-CEO Howard Schultz that the mall is dying.IBD'S TAKE: Will holiday sales get their own Trump bump and which retailers will have the brightest holiday season?Other mall-based retailers were down.Macy's (M) stock fell 6.7% to 37.47. Value department store Kohl's (KSS) was off 7.9%. J.C. Penney (JCP) fell 7.1%. And Victoria's Secret parent L Brands (LB) dropped 2.9%. Macy's, J.C. Penney and L Brands undercut their 50-day lines.Department stores had rallied in November following third-quarter earnings reports and Donald Trump's election win. But shares have been retreating recently.The Nordstrom downgrade is good news for online retailers like Amazon.com (AMZN), according to Cramer. Amazon shares dipped 0.4% to 757.77.Meanwhile, a cold snap in the Midwest and East coast will likely boost December apparel sales vs. 2015 according to a report from Planalytics, cited by Marketwatch. But last December saw some of the warmest temperatures on record for this time of year. RELATED:Bullish Jewelers And Department Stores Lead Retail SectorJ.C. Penney Prefaces Cyclical Turn For Department Stores
