Massacre in Paris France Pounds ISIS with AirstrikesFrance Widens Crackdown at Home as Bombs Rain on Islamic StateFrance Strikes Back as Hunt Widens

These are just some of the headlines that hit the papers over the weekend and this morning- constant media coverage keeping the pressure on as President Hollande and the civilized world vows revenge....Asian mkts - the first to react - came under pressure as investors/traders initial reaction was to hit the SELL button.....but as the night progressed and word got out that France took control and started to drop bombs on the ISIS stronghold mkts reversed course....more to follow.   As a survivor of 911 - My  thoughts go out to all of those who suffered and those families who mourn the death of fathers, brothers, sisters and mothers.....#PrayforPeace......________________________________________________________________

Stocks closed lower on Friday finishing the week on a sour note — the selling violated the second level of support leaving the mkt in limbo with only the final support level needing to be tested at S&P 2005.  The Dow lost 202 pts while the S&P lost over 1%, closing lower by 23 pts….led by a continued free fall in commodities and the glaringly weak reports on retail sales and PPI (producer price index)…For the week — the S&P lost over 3.5%, the energy sector lost 6%, retailers lost 9%, Tech lost 4.7% , Consumer Discretionary lost 5.1%. Well you get the picture.  The PPI at -0.4% was so bad it is now indicating DEFLATION….but no worries — Janet and her band of merry men and women are singing about the benefits of that still strong NFP report from two weeks ago — in fact on Friday — Cleveland Fed Pres Loretta Mester said that the time to hike rates was ‘quickly approaching’….suggesting that the time is now for rates to rise…and so what we are seeing is a re-pricing of risk assets across the spectrum — why?  Because they (the FED)  clearly missed that opportunity 2 or 3 times already and the mkt is telling us that NOW is not the time to move on rates - especially in light of the weekend's events…..what’s the rush?  I mean the DATA is really not cooperating...but she is trapped - trapped like a rat..... (Remember December is a ‘self imposed’ deadline.)

And it was a very disappointing day for retailers on Friday — in fact the retailers rolled over and played dead…..October retail sales rose by 0.1% vs. the 0.3% expectation and if you look at retail sales EX autos, gas, building materials and food services rose by 0.2% vs. the 0.4% expectation.  Add in some weaker than expected earnings and the retailers got slaughtered…..JW Nordstrom (JWN) gave up 15% on horrific earnings, terrible revenues and a cut in full year sales and profit forecasts…. JC Penney  (JCP) also closed down 15% on terrible earnings, but the silver lining for them was that comparable store sales rose by 6.4%......The Gap, Inc. (GPS) -3%,  Kohl's (KSS) -3.2%, Macy's (M) gave up another 2% on top of the 24% in the last week alone.....Target (TGT) lost 2.5%......not a pretty picture by any stretch.....

Now Friday afternoon also brought word of a terrorist attack in Paris….and the chaos and confusion that that event created only served to put more pressure on an already weak mkt as investors/traders tried to understand the extent and impact of this horrific event.  As the day drew to a close — more information became available — and the selling pressure picked up into the bell.  Over the weekend — we learned of the very horrific events that engulfed the ‘City of Lights’ — the world mourned — allies stood together, world leaders who had gathered in Turkey for the G20 meeting denounced the actions of those pathetic souls that call themselves ‘jihadists’ — calling this an ‘attack on the civilized world’……. and then President Hollande of France declared ‘war’ on Isis…..Sunday night unleashing a barrage of French bombs — (neatly packed in French air force Rafale Fighter Jets…)  upon the nerve center in Raqqa, Syria — wiping out a command center, a weapons facility, and a training ground… and this is only the beginning…..there is now a global commitment to intensify and eradicate this terrorist organization…… and so it begins - the instability, the fear, the bombs and the continued threats of chaos will now become some of the directional drivers in the global mktplace. Asia was the first mkt center to open — and stocks moved lower as mkts react to the worst terror incident in over a decade…..investors kneejerk reaction is to hit the SELL button (fear) as they assess the impact that this event will have on the European economy and the global economy…. Weaker macro data in Japan also did not help the tone — GDP for the 3rd qtr fell by 0.8% on top of the -0.7% in the 2nd qtr.  Sending that country into RECESSION — this is the second recession since PM Shinzo Abe took office in December 2012.  This news put renewed pressure on Abe and the BoJ Governor Kuroda to do MORE! Over the weekend - the Chinese gov't raised margin requirements (bearish) but at the same time indicated possibly more accommodation as the gov't pursues pro-mkt reforms (bullish)......Japan - 1%, Hong Kong -0.89%, China + 0.48% and ASX -0.9%. In Europe this morning — mkts are mixed but marginally higher after initial selling pressure subsided.....Investors/traders now digesting news of French attacks on ISIS is sending mkts into positive territory.....As you would expect - travel, hotel, airlines and leisure stocks will take it on the chin a bit, but expect that defense stocks will benefit as the civilized world gears up to destroy those cowards.    Macro data in the Eurozone showed inflation data in October to be 0.1% up from 0%.   FTSE +0.44%, CAC 40+0.03%, DAX +0.34%, Eurostoxx +0.20%, Spain +0.01% and Italy flat.   Now US futures had a wild ride overnight......opening down 11 pts at 2007 - only to test 2000 then rally as the bombs dropped.  Currently - US futures are higher by 5 pts indicating that investors/traders will not allow ISIS to dictate capital flow and investor reaction.  CNBC puts  Billionaire Wilbur Ross on the television to tell us that these latest attempts on humanity will be 'unlikely to cause a mkt correction' and I agree...what will cause a mkt correction is the inability of the global economy to fire on all cylinders and a pre-mature move by the FED to raise rates at a time when the data is not confirming 'escape velocity'.  Now last week we broke S&P intermediate support at 2034....closing lower at 2023.....Overnight we tested support at 2000 and held.....I suspect that we are now stuck in the 2000/2034 trading range as the week begins.   The talk  will be about  broken technical's, attacks on ISIS, and more eco data this week.....

Today  we WON'T get any FED speak but we will get the Empire Manf Survey - exp of -6.3 - which would be an improvement over last month's -11......Mortgage foreclosures and delinquencies round out today....later in the week Traders/Investors will keep an eye on CPI exp of +0.2%, Industrial production of +0.1%, Cap Util of 77.5%, housing starts of 1.1 mil which would be a decline of 4%..... On Wednesday we get the FED mins and although I do not think we will learn anything new - it will be a key to the action amid concerns over what the FED will decide to do in 4 weeks.  On the earnings front, retail giants Wal-Mart  (WMT), Home Depot  (HD), Target (TGT), Staples (SPLS), and Best Buy  (BBY) are among the companies due to report their quarterly results this week.
Take good care. Kp

(Remember December is a ‘self imposed’ deadline.) Target (TGT) topped on revenue and boosted its profit outlook, but that wasn't enough to fortify investor confidence in the big-box retailer as online sales slowed ahead of the holiday shopping season.

Online sales grew 20%, a deceleration from the previous quarter's 30% growth. Target's Q3 digital sales missed management's earlier guidance for 30% year-over-year growth, said Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen in a Wednesday report.
But he also noted that Wal-Mart's (WMT) digital sales growth slowed to 10% in Q3, "so TGT is clearly gaining share."

The slowdown comes amid a key online push. In a bid to compete with Amazon (AMZN) — and every other retailer that allows shoppers to order online — Target is offering free shipping on all Target.com orders made between Nov. 1 and Christmas Day, the second year in a row it has done so. Last year, the company offered free shipping on all online orders through Dec. 20.
Shares tumbled 4.3% by Wednesday's close in the stock market today, after rising as much as 3.9% before the opening bell. Wal-Mart rose 1.7%, and Amazon climbed 3.2%.

Target raised the lower end of its full-year earnings guidance range to $4.65-$4.75 a share, up from $4.60-$4.75 a share. Analysts predict EPS of $4.72. For the current holiday quarter, the company sees $1.48-$1.58 in per-share earnings, with the midpoint a penny shy of forecasts for $1.54 a share.
In the third quarter, profit jumped 8.6% to 86 cents a share, meeting analyst predictions, as revenue edged down less than 1% to $17.61 billion, topping forecasts for $17.57 billion.

"We would be aggressive buyers on potential weakness if investors choose to sell on solid numbers," added Chen, who maintains an outperform rating on the stock. "Investor focus could be on weaker (gross margin), slower growth in the digital channel, and the slight inventory build, but we believe TGT outperformed in the current retail environment."
Q3 gross margin was 29.4% vs 29.5% in Q3 2014.

On Monday, rival Wal-Mart turned in mixed results but encouragingly reported its fifth consecutive quarter of U.S. same-store sales growth, while TJX (TJX) bested Wall Street projections, reaffirming investor faith in the off-price model.
But last week's gloomy forecasts from Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) appear to have soured sentiment going into the holiday shopping season, a vital time for retailers.

Target logged 1.9% same-store sales growth, "near the high-end" of its expectations, as traffic rose 1.4%. The company said that sales and traffic growth were "stronger in the third quarter than either of the first two quarters of the year." Its "signature" categories continue to perform well.

"The third quarter marked the fourth consecutive quarter in which we have grown traffic, and Target's sales growth continues to be led by our signature categories: Style, Baby, Kids and Wellness," said CEO Brian Cornell in a statement. "Our momentum is encouraging, especially in the face of stiffer prior-year comparisons."
Earlier in the month, Reuters reported that the company was "seriously considering" teaming up with outside firms in an effort to boost the reliability of its fresh-food supply chain.
Off-price retailer Ross Stores (ROST) reports Thursday.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

Despite climbing almost 10% in premarket trading, JCPenney (JCP) stock fell Wednesday after the struggling department store reported better-than-expected third-quarter same-store sales and announced the $50 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit over false advertising.Same-store sales for the quarter grew 6.4%, said JCPenney, above the FactSet consensus for 5.7%.The 2012 lawsuit alleged, among other things, that JCPenney did not comply with California law on price comparison advertising of certain products.The retailer denied the claims but said it is settling "to eliminate the uncertainties, burden and expense of further protracted litigation.""Despite the financial impact of the settlement, the majority of which was accrued prior to the third quarter, we are pleased with our third-quarter results, including a comparable-store sales increase of 6.4% and gross margin and earnings performance that exceeded our expectations," CEO Marvin Ellison said in a statement.JCPenney reports third-quarter results on Friday. Analysts expect the company to narrow its per-share loss to 56 cents from last year's 77-cent per-share quarterly loss. Revenue is seen rising 4% to $2.87 billion.Shares closed down 1.8% to 8.52 in the stock market today. Retailers collectively tumbled Wednesday, as Macy's (M) Q3 revenue fell short of forecasts.Macy's shares plunged 14%, earlier hitting their lowest level since March 2013. Kohl's (KSS) lost 5.35% and Nordstrom (JWN) 3.7%. Kohl's and Nordstrom also report earnings this week.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.

On the heels of last week's lackluster retail earnings, off-price retailers TJX (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST) are both expected to report a slowdown in second-quarter earnings and revenue, according to analysts polled by Thomson Reuters.Ross' Q2 per-share earnings are seen climbing 9% to 62 cents, which would put a halt to a streak of five consecutive quarters of accelerated EPS growth. Revenue is expected to grow almost 8% to $2.94 billion, down from 10% growth last quarter.The Dublin, Calif.-based company, which operates more than 1,200 Ross Stores and more than 150 dd's Discounts, reports Q2 earnings Thursday after the close. Last month, Ross opened 27 new stores, in line with its overall target to add 90 new locations in 2015.Shares rose 0.8% to 54.16 in the stock market today. The stock is currently in buy range after breaking out of a cup-with-handle base with 53.60 buy point earlier in the month.TJX, the parent of T.J. Maxx, HomeGoods, Sierra Trading Post and Marshalls, reports before the open Tuesday. The company operates more than 3,400 stores in seven countries, in addition to three e-commerce sites.Analysts expect Q2 earnings to edge up a penny, or a little over 1%, to 76 cents a share, continuing a deceleration from 8% and 15% EPS growth in the two previous quarters. Revenue is seen as rising about 5% to $7.25 billion, down from 6% growth in Q1.Last week, JPMorgan raised its price target on the company to 81 from 75 a share with an overweight rating.TJX shares rose 1.7% to 71.82 in the stock market today.The expected slowdowns come as department stores mostly disappointed last week. Macy's (M) and Kohl's (KSS) missed views, while higher-end peer Nordstrom (JWN) pulled ahead of forecasts. J.C. Penney (JCP) lost money but topped estimates, prompting shares to surge Friday.RELATED:IBD 50's Foot Locker, Ross Earnings: No DiscountsJ.C. Penney, Nordstrom Surge After Macy's Free Fall.
Stocks traded quietly near the flat line in late-morning trade Friday.

The Nasdaq lagged a bit, falling 0.3%, but the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were virtually unchanged. Volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq tracked lower than Thursday's levels in the stock market today.
Among the day's gainers, Tesla (TSLA) rallied 1% after it priced a share offering at 242. Tesla will use the cash in part to fund development of its Model 3, a lower-cost electric car due in 2017.

Meanwhile, department stores outperformed as Wall Street cheered earnings reports from Nordstrom (JWN) and J.C. Penney (JCP). Heavy-volume sellers were in the group earlier in the week after Macy's (M) reported disappointing earnings.
Generic drugmakers, biotechs and chip equipment makers lagged.
Inside the IBD 50,Ebix (EBIX) and Zebra Technologies (ZBRA) were top gainers, but both are troubled from a technical perspective.
Mobileye (MBLY), meanwhile, outperformed with a 1% gain. It's testing its 10-week moving average for the first time after a recent breakout over a 48.88 buy point.

In economic news, the Labor Department reported prices paid to producers rose 0.2% in July, half of June's pace, but above the 0.1% gain projected by economists. Core prices, minus energy and food, gained 0.3% — even with June's increase, but well above the 0.1% consensus estimate.

Meanwhile, the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index clocked a reading of 92.9 in August, just below the consensus estimate of 93.5. Earlier this month, the IBD/TIPP Economic Optimism Index slipped 1.2 points, or 2.5% in August, posting a reading of 46.9 vs. 48.1 in July. Readings above 50 signify optimism; below 50 pessimism.Stocks traded quietly near the flat line in late-morning trade Friday.The Nasdaq lagged a bit, falling 0.3%, but the Dow Jones industrial average and S&P 500 were virtually unchanged. In a bid to rev up sales following news of a second-quarter slump, Macy's (M) will begin selling merchandise on Alibaba's (BABA) Tmall Global in China later this year.

The nationwide department store said it has formed a joint venture with Hong Kong's Fung Retailing Limited, with plans to bring their e-commerce pilot to Alibaba's online marketplace. Shoppers will be able to pay for their purchases using Alipay, a mobile payment system akin to Apple (AAPL) Pay.
During the post-earnings conference call, Macy's management said it has no plans to open brick-and-mortar stores in China, but would consider it in the future, according to Reuters.
The move is just one of Macy's sales growth initiatives, which include expanding same-day delivery to more markets, and opening off-price stores and 10 more Bluemercury beauty and spa locations.

During the quarter, earnings fell 20% to 64 cents a share, well below analyst forecasts for 76 cents per share. Revenue dipped almost 3% to $6.1 billion, missing views for $6.23 billion. Management blamed internal and macroeconomic factors for Q2 weakness.
"In the second quarter, we removed a major Friends & Family promotional event from Macy's calendar," said CEO Terry Lundgren.

"In addition, as a result of the previous port slowdown, planned markdowns in many departments were delayed into the second quarter to clear merchandise that arrived late. Moreover, throughout the first half of the year, overall consumer demand has been restrained in many of the categories of merchandise we sell, and the strong U.S. dollar has led to significantly lower international tourist spending."
Shares closed down 5.1% to 64.11 in the stock market today.
Lackluster sales prompted Macy's to cut its full-year same-store sales. It now expects flat comps vs. previous guidance for 2% growth.
The company trimmed full-year sales growth to a decline of 1%, down from prior outlook for growth of 1%. It sees per-share earnings of $4.70 to $4.80.
Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect 0.7% revenue growth to $28.29 billion and $4.67 in per-share earnings for the year.

Macy's also said Wednesday that it will sell part of its nine-story Fulton Street property in downtown Brooklyn to Tishman Speyer, following reports in June that the department store was feeling pressure to let go of some of its real estate. Macy's said it will receive $170 million in cash for the assets, plus an additional $100 million over the next three years for renovations.
Alibaba disclosed results Wednesday as well, missing Q1 revenue estimates.
Expect other department stores to report this week. Kohl's (KSS) reports before the open Thursday. Nordstrom (JWN) reports Q2 results after the close Thursday.

Stock indexes on Friday limped to their fourth loss in five sessions. The Nasdaq, though, scored a positive reversal, trimming a 1% deficit to less than 0.3%. The S&P 500 reversed a 0.8% loss to 0.3%. The IBD 50 gained 0.3%. Volume fell across the board. The decisively lower volume suggested there was little institutional interest in piling on to…

Following a week of discouraging earnings from the likes of Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and others, TJX (TJX) continues to stand out like a vintage Chanel bag in a bargain bin with strong Q3 results, though full-year guidance was a little light.The off-price leader, which owns T.J. Maxx, Home Goods and Marshalls, logged better-than-expected same-store sales growth of 5%, up from 2% in the same period last year, led by robust customer traffic that has eluded other chains."It has consistently been one of the best performing retailers since the Great Recession taking advantage of consumers' increasing desire to maximize every dollar by selling top national brands at significantly discounted prices," wrote Ken Perkins on Tuesday.Earnings notched up over 1% to 86 cents per share, 2 cents above forecasts. Revenue rose over 5% to $7.75 billion, topping views for $7.73 billion.TJX shares gapped up 3.9% to 68.18 in the stock market today."We are delighted that strong customer traffic drove our entire consolidated comp and was the primary driver of our comp increases at every division," said CEO Carol Meyrowitz in a statement. "Our excellent traffic gains and strong performance across our apparel, accessories and home categories, demonstrate that our brands globally are offering the right values and merchandise mix."Traffic continues to be up in the current quarter, she said, asserting confidence that TJX will grow to a "$40 billion-plus" company.But guidance for the crucial holiday quarter and for fiscal 2016 fell short of expectations, as the company accounted for foreign exchange rates, pension costs, TJX's wage initiative and its $57 million acquisition of Australian off-price retailer Trade Secret, among other items, which all weighed on EPS growth by 9%.For Q4, management expects 2%-3% comp growth and 91-93 cents in diluted per-share earnings, vs. analysts' 98 cents per share.For the year, TJX expects 4%-5% in same-store sales growth and $3.26-$3.28 diluted per-share earnings, below consensus estimates for $3.32 a share.Off-price retailers are seen continuing to outperform, according to RBC Capital Markets analyst Brian Tunick, who two weeks ago outlined his reasoning for the sector's growth potential.Meanwhile,Wal-Mart (WMT), which also reported Tuesday, logged its fifth consecutive quarter of positive U.S. same-store sales but Q3 results were mixed.Target (TGT) and Ross Stores (ROST) also report this week.Wal-Mart shares were up 3.5%. Target gained 0.8%, and Ross added 1.2%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Wal-Mart U.S. Comps Rise For 5th Straight QuarterHoliday Retail Fears Intensify As Dillard's SlammedWill TJX, Target Survive Amid Crushed Retail Stocks?4 Reasons TJX, Off-Price Retailers Will Keep Surging.

Fear rippled through Wall Street that Macy's disappointing results and massive drop in shares Wednesday could be just the tip of the iceberg for consumer spending as the holiday shopping season starts to hit full stride.

Prospects for heavy markdowns and slow tourist trade discounted not only Macy's, but also the shares of department store rivals Wednesday and extended to other players in the retail sector — regardless of whether they had good news to report.

While Macy's (M) dropped 14% of its value, upscale retailer Nordstrom (JWN) stumbled to end the trading session down 3.7%. That wasn't the worst of it, though. Value-priced department store operator Kohl's (KSS) plunged 5.4% while JC Penney (JCP) ended the day off 1.8%. JC Penney fell despite an early-morning surge after it reported better-than-expected Q3 same-store sales and announced the $50 million settlement of a class-action lawsuit.

Further, concerns about holiday spending hit shares of apparel retailers, including Gap (GPS), which issued its profit warning late Monday. Apparel and shoe makers also skidded, including market leader Nike (NKE).
Department stores were the worst performing group out of the 197 industries tracked by IBD, falling 7.1% Wednesday.
Retailers Are Overstocked

A myriad of problems are hitting the sector, analysts say. Unusually warm weather in September and October may well have caused inventory problems for other department stores and for retailers trying to sell seasonal goods like coats and boots. Macquarie Capital analyst Laurent Vasilescu says inventory buildup from warm weather is impacting wholesalers as well.

"Macy's is probably the first retailer to call it out as a big problem," Vasilescu said. The retailer reported a third straight quarterly decline in sales early Wednesday, prompting it to slash its full-year profit and sales forecasts.

Ultimately, it all could lead to heavy markdowns to move products off the shelves during the holiday, a trend that could hurt margins and profits. A highly promotional environment would lead to increased pressure on the likes of Kohl's, JC Penney and Nordstrom during the holidays.
It won't stop there, analysts say. Not even luxury retailers are immune as the lack of tourism has been a drag on sales for retailers like Tiffany & Co. (TIF) and Ralph Lauren (RL), Vasilescu adds.
"It's going to be a very promotional holiday," he said. "November is likely to be a black November this year where promotions will start well in advance of the normal kickoff on Black Friday."

At Macy's, the concerns over inventory were the center of attention when the company reported earnings. Macy's Chief Executive Terry Lundgren told analysts Wednesday that the inventory glut would lead to markdowns in the fourth quarter.

"We're selling fashion apparel and so we're going to mark that inventory down," he said. "That will be good for consumers, but it will obviously put pressure on our own margins in the fourth quarter."

Lundgren went on to say: "We believe that the retail industry is going through a tough period, that we seem to experience something like this every five to seven years or so, and this one feels familiar in that regard."
That statement alone raised red flags, analysts say.
"He's clearly saying the economy is turning," said Macquarie's Vasilescu. "That's why you (see) the stocks down so meaningfully."

Cowen and Co. analyst Oliver Chen says because Macy's will need to liquidate inventory in the fourth quarter, it means that the promotional environment could "intensify, particularly in apparel," for all retailers.

"That put up some red flags around the promotional environment, which is why you're seeing the weakness in the stocks," he said. "It's too early to tell if (Macy's being more promotional) says anything about the holiday, but if Macy's is going to be promotional then other retailers are going to (have to) be promotional, which will negatively impact profits."Fear rippled through Wall Street that Macy's disappointing results and massive drop in shares Wednesday could be just the tip of the iceberg for consumer spending as the holiday shopping season starts to hit full stride.Prospects for heavy markdowns and slow tourist trade discounted not only Macy's, but also the shares of department store rivals Wednesday and extended to other players in the retail sector — regardless of whether they had good news to report.While Macy's (M) dropped 14% of its value, upscale retailer Nordstrom (JWN) stumbled to end the trading session down 3.7%. Upscale burger joint Shake Shack (SHAK), solar installer Sunrun (RUN) and Tesla (TSLA) chipmaker Nvidia (NVDA) rallied on strong quarterly earnings after the close Thursday. Nordstrom (JWN) became the latest department store chain to crash on earnings and guidance that was well below expectations.Upscale apparel retailer Nordstrom reported first-quarter EPS that slid 60% to 26 cents, including 10 cents for severance costs and higher credit chargeback costs, badly missing estimates for 45 cents. Sales rose 2.5% to $3.2 billion, missing forecasts for $3.3 billion.The company slashed its full-year EPS outlook to $2.50-$2.70, well below consensus for $3.20, from $3.10-$3.35, and trimmed its sales growth view to 2.5%-4.5% from 3.5%-5.5%, while Wall Street sees 3.4% growth. Nordstrom now sees its same-store sales ranging from a 1% dip to a 1% gain, down from a prior view of 0%-2% growth.Shares crashed 18% in late trade. Nordstrom had closed down 0.4% after hitting a 4-year low intraday, after falling 7% on Wednesday.Nordstrom has spent heavily on its online presence and has had to keep apace with rivals’ aggressive discounts. As with other apparel retailers, balmier winter has also hurt sales of seasonal items.E-commerce giant Amazon (AMNZ), tepid holiday sales and insufficient discretionary spending despite lower gas prices have also hurt retailers' shares. Concerns about the space were heightened Wednesday by Macy’s (M), among the biggest retail chains, which led retailers downward after cutting its full-year outlook and reporting weak quarterly results. Kohl's (KSS) followed with a weak report Thursday, closing down 9%.Macy’s fell 0.5% Thursday while Amazon rose 0.7%, hitting another record high.Graphics chipmaker Nvidia reported Q1 EPS minus items rose 38% to 33 cents, beating by a penny. Revenue grew 14% to $1.31 billion, topping views of $1.26 billion on strong growth in all platforms including gaming, professional and auto. Nvidia works with Tesla and many other automakers, and should benefit from the move  toward more-autonomous vehicles.Nvidia forecast $1.35 billion Q2 revenue, topping Wall Street’s $1.28 billion target. Shares rose more than 5% late after closing down 1.4% at 35.57.Higher-end burger chain Shake Shack reported that first-quarter EPS doubled to 8 cents, beating views for 5 cents. Sales rose 43.3% to $54.2 million, above estimates for $52 million.Same-store sales – or Same-Shack sales, as the chain calls the key metric – rose 9.9%.The company also boosted its full-year sales outlook to $245 million-$249 million, above views and up from an earlier forecast of $237 million to $242 million.Shares rose 4% late after falling 0.1% at the close.With a number of rivals focusing more on higher-quality hamburger ingredients, Wall Street has remained wary of Shake Shack’s ability to compete and expand in a crowded fast-casual dining industry.Solar systems installer Sunrun reported first quarter revenue of $98.7 million, better than the $87.7 million analysts expected. Sunrun recorded 13 cents diluted earnings per share, vs. estimates for a 48 cent loss. No comps are available for the August 2015 IPO.Shares shot up 18% in extended trading after closing down 3.5% at 6.15. Rival SolarCity (SCTY) reported weak guidance earlier in the week.

A strong back-to-school season and a late October sales rebound gave value-priced department store Kohl's (KSS) a needed sales lift for its third quarter, the company reported Thursday. The news sent shares soaring more than 6% at the close. But after department store and off-price retailer Nordstrom (JWN) reported disappointing third-quarter results after the market close, sending its shares plunging…

Stocks were off their lows of the day in early afternoon trading Friday as leading financial stocks struggled to hold above buy points.The Nasdaq fell l.8% while the S&P 500 and the Dow Jones industrial average tumbled 0.6% each. Volume was running higher than the same time Thursday on both exchanges in the stock market today.Financial stocks, especially regional banks, that broke out of bases within the past week were having trouble staying above buy points. Signature Bank (SBNY) dropped below a 154.50 buy point from a cup-with-handle base. It was down 1%.Nashville, Tenn.-based Pinnacle Financial (PNFP) likewise slipped below a 55.58 buy point from a cup-with-handle base, also down less than 1%.Bank of America (BAC) slipped 1% and Citigroup (C) was down 0.4%, recovering much of an earlier loss.Despite financial sector weakness, investors are still prepared for a interest rate increase at the Fed's Dec. 16 meeting. The CME FedWatch tool calculates a 68% chance of action, based on trading in the Fed funds futures contracts.Carnage in the retail sector was Friday's big story. Nordstrom (JWN) was the disaster de jour, gapping down 15% in furious volume after reporting disappointing earnings and sales. Macy's (M) was down 2% and has lost nearly 19% this week on the heels of its own earnings disappointment.
Continuing last week's spate of retail disappointments, shares of Dillard's (DDS) closed down 6% after the department store chain missed earnings and revenue forecasts for the third quarter.
Earnings fell 8.5% to $1.19 per share, short of consensus views by a penny, as revenue dropped 1.8% to $1.47 billion. Analysts had expected $1.49 billion in sales.
Same-store sales fell 4% in Q3.

Shoes, juniors' and kids' apparel, cosmetics and ladies' apparel were the better-performing categories, said the company, while men's apparel and accessories and ladies' accessories and lingerie, as well as home and furniture, were weaker.

As retailers find themselves in the midst of the holiday quarter, the mounting concerns are that this important shopping season will yield lighter results than hoped. October retail sales from the Commerce Department fell short of expectations last week with a mere 0.1% gain, while Amazon (AMZN) and other online retailers logged a 7.1% climb.
Fellow department stores Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) offered grim results and cut forecasts last week, and even retailers that topped Wall Street estimates fell sharply.
J.C. Penney (JCP) shares lost over 15% Friday even after coming out ahead of views, and Kohl's (KSS) has quickly given up gains from its Thursday consensus beat.
Kohl's stock rose 2.5% Monday afternoon, and J.C. Penney gained 2.55%. Amazon rallied 0.85%.
Macy's shares fell 1.2%, while Nordstrom rose 1.4%.
More retailers report this week, with Wal-Mart (WMT) and T.J. Maxx and Marshalls parent TJX (TJX) on tap for Tuesday, and Target (TGT) and Ross Stores (ROST) report later in the week.
RELATED:
Will TJX, Target Survive Amid Crushed Retail Stocks?

Did department stores Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) move their earnings out of the doldrums and back onto the growth track in the third quarter?Investors will learn the answer when the two top department stores kick off retail earnings season and report quarterly results this week. If analysts' expectations are on target, both companies will see their earnings decrease.So far, the signs aren't good, analysts say. The department store group saw their shares get hammered on Monday as several negative reports came out on the segment.Macy's shares tumbled after Citigroup lowered its price target on the retailer. Deutsche Bank also issued a negative report on Macy's and other mid-tier department store operators Kohl's (KSS) and Dillard's (DDS), noting they "may be about to limbo underneath what is already a very low bar as they report potentially very underwhelming Q3 results and Q4/holiday guidance."Macy's shares closed down 5.4% on the stock market today.JPMorgan also issued a negative report on several department stores on Monday noting Macy's, Dillard's, Kohl's and Nordstrom have "too much cold-weather inventory," among other things. Nordstrom shares closed down 4.7% on Monday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Macy's to see earnings decline 13% from a year earlier to 53 cents a share when it reports third-quarter results on Wednesday before the opening bell. That comes on top of a 20% drop in the second quarter.They see a 1.6% decline in sales to $6.1 billion, following a 3% decrease in the second quarter, to mark the third straight quarter of year-over-year earnings declines.Macy's is generally regarded as a well-run chain, with a strong sales channels, but it has reported lower year-over-year revenue in five of the last seven quarters.The sales trend comes as spending has been shifting from traditional shopping-mall department stores and apparel chains toward experiences and non-tangible goods such as wireless services and entertainment, amid ever-growing competition from Amazon (AMZN) and other online players.Investor's Business Daily's department store industry group ranks retailers No. 192 out of 197 industry groups.Macy's has recently undertaken a number of initiatives to propel growth, including entering the lucrative off-price retail arena, where it would compete with operators such as TJX Cos. (TJX) and Ross Stores (ROST). In September, Macy's debuted its new off-price retail brand, Macy's Backstage, with three New York City metro area stores and three more set to open in 2015.Nordstrom is also generally regarded as a well-run chain with a strong omnichannel presence. The company has fared particularly well with its growing chain of Nordstrom Rack off-price stores.Nordstrom is expected to see earnings slip 0.7% vs. a year earlier to 72 cents a share when the high-end department store operator reports third-quarter results on Thursday after the close. That would follow a 2% decline in adjusted earnings in the second quarter and mark the fourth-straight quarterly drop in earnings.Analysts expect the upscale department store operator to see a 7.4% rise in revenue to $3.4 billion. That would follow a 9% gain in sales in the second quarter.On Oct. 1, Nordstrom announced that it closed the sale of its credit card portfolio to TD Bank USA for $2.2 billion. The agreement also makes TD Bank the exclusive U.S. issuer of Nordstrom-branded Visa and private-label consumer credit cards.In connection with the closing, Nordstrom's board authorized a special cash dividend and an additional $1 billion share repurchase program. The company said it would pay a special cash dividend of $4.85 a share on Oct. 27, to shareholders of record on Oct. 12.Follow Marilyn Much on Twitter @IBD_MMuch.
Fashion and lifestyle licensing company Sequential Brands (SQBG) surged 12% Friday following better-than-expected second-quarter earnings and a bullish report from at least one analyst.
The analyst, Eric Beder of Wunderlich Securities, raved that Sequential is "setting the bar higher and turning into a powerful licensing company."
Sequential will get a lot more powerful when its pending acquisition of Martha Stewart Living Omnimedia (MSO), for more than $300 million, closes.
Earlier this year it acquired the Jessica Simpson brand, adding to a licensing roster that also includes Ellen Tracy, Avia and And1, among others.
Sequential reported Q2 earnings of 8 cents per share, double from a year earlier and three cents above analysts' views, as polled by Thomson Reuters. Revenue rose 189% to $20.2 million.
CEO Yehuda Shmidman said the company has "fully integrated" the Jessica Simpson brand, which was acquired in April.
Sequential reaffirmed its revenue forecast for the full year of $78-$81 million, excluding the pending impact of the Martha Stewart acquisition.
Beder noted that Martha Stewart will allow Sequential a "deeper relationship" with Macy's (M), while adding new partnerships with Home Depot (HD), PetSmart and Staples (SPLS).
Ellen Tracy, he added, is rolling out this fall in Nordstrom (JWN), Lord & Taylor and Dillard's (DDS), among other venues.

Macy's (M) shares perked up after Starboard Value's Jeffrey Smith reportedly disclosed that he has taken a position in the department store chain and thinks the stock could be worth over 125 a share, nearly twice its current price.Shares rose 5.8% to 70.61 in the stock market today.At the Delivering Alpha investor's conference in New York City, co-hosted by CNBC and Institutional Investor, the activist investor noted Macy's real estate value, and said the company could split up its real estate and retail businesses."We believe there is an opportunity to create two leading companies . . . while maintaining the dividend," Smith reportedly said, according to CNBC's live blog of the event.On Monday, Macy's said it had sold its 1.2 million-square-foot downtown Pittsburgh property to Core Realty. Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen said he believes the sale, worth $15 million, "signifies (management's) willingness to sell properties for the right price."In a July 6 note, Chen noted that "In our view, M has greatest potential to unlock real estate value (est. $19B), but large-scale event unlikely given complexity, control loss & higher rents."Reports emerged in early June that the company was under some investor pressure to consider its real estate options.Fellow department store Nordstrom (JWN) shares rose 0.8% to 78.65. J.C. Penney (JCP) rose 1.2% to 9.11. Kohl's (KSS) fell 0.5% to 64.46.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Macy's Downgraded On Same-Store Sales 'Rut'Macy's Reportedly Urged To Sell NY Flagship, Property

A year after reports surfaced that Nordstrom (JWN) might be looking for a buyer for its private-label credit card portfolio, TD Bank said it will acquire the department store's existing U.S. Visa (V) and private-label credit card portfolio in a deal worth $2.2 billion in receivables, the companies said Tuesday. As part of a separate long-term agreement, TD Bank, a…
Macy's (M) first-quarter results missed Wall Street expectations because of delayed shipments from a port slow down and lower spending by international tourists to the U.S.
The department store said Q1 earnings fell 6.7% to 56 cents per share. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters were expecting 62 cents. Sales dipped 0.7% to $6.2 billion, under views for $6.3 billion.
Shares were being pressured down about 1% before the open of the stock market today.

"We had expected our first-quarter sales to grow at a rate lower than our guidance for the full year. We fell short because of a confluence of factors," said CEO Terry Lundgren. "Delayed merchandise shipments from the West Coast port slowdown and severe winter weather early in the quarter restrained business levels. Moreover, sales were negatively affected by lower levels of spending by international tourists visiting major U.S. cities."

Macy's board of directors raised the department store's quarterly dividend to 36 cents per share from the current 31.25 cents. The board also increased the company's share repurchase authorization by $1.5 billion to $2.1 billion.

Last week Macy's announced plans to debut four pilot off-price stores in New York this fall, under the Macy's Backstage moniker. The off-price stores will offer clothes and shoes, in addition to housewares, home textiles and other items and are expected to compete with T.J. Maxx (TJX) and Nordstrom's (JWN) Rack stores. Macy's is locating the new 30,000-square-foot shops in Brooklyn, Queens, New Hyde Park and Huntington and each store will feature free Wi-Fi and large fitting rooms, and one spot will include a cafe.
Looking ahead, Macy's continues to expect comparable sales growth to rise 2% for the year and reiterated its full-year EPS guidance of $4.70 to $4.80. Analysts expect $4.75.

Goodbye to "Mod" boy brand Ben Sherman, a relic from London's swinging '60s.

Hello Lilly Pulitzer, another name from that era, but from another continent and generation — in this case, Palm Beach, Fla.'s affluent resort set, which took up the brand's breezy pastels as its casual-attire uniform.

While apparel company Oxford Industries (OXM) tries to find a buyer for its struggling Ben Sherman brand, it plans to step up nationwide expansion of Lilly Pulitzer, now popular among women across generations as well as incomes.
It will also keep growing Tommy Bahama, its No. 1 brand, globally.
'Foundation Brands'
Oxford, with roots in men's suits and button-down shirts, is all about beachy casual wear now.
In the firm's fiscal fourth-quarter earnings release on March 26, CEO Thomas Chubb called Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer "foundation brands."
And in a conference call that followed, he said: "In both Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer, we believe we have cultivated a deep and powerful emotional connection with our customers."

After Oxford announced in the Q4 report that it was looking for a buyer for Ben Sherman — and that earnings in the quarter grew 21% from the prior year — the company's shares jumped 19% the next trading day.

Tommy Bahama is targeted to an older and more affluent demographic than Ben Sherman's edgy, young male demographic. It markets to men and women 35 and older who, as Oxford likes to say, "embrace a relaxed and casual approach to daily living."
Ben Sherman "is a little bit out of their wheelhouse," said Pamela Quintiliano, an analyst with SunTrust Robinson Humphrey, who described the brand's heritage as "60s rocker working class."
"It's more of a mid-tier brand and they tried to stretch the price point too high and alienated customers," she said.
If Lilly Pulitzer was alienating to certain women outside of Palm Beach in its early years, that's not the case now.

"There is a feeding frenzy for the (Lilly) product," Quintiliano said, driven by its "aspirational" appeal from its tony heritage and limited distribution in full-priced stores, largely in the East. "Lilly has almost a cult following."
Lilly also happens to be in the "sweet spot" of current fashion trends, which are all about "color, prints and patterns," said Quintiliano. "And obviously that's what Lilly Pulitzer is about."

Analyst Eric Beder of Wunderlich Securities notes that Lilly "has pretty much been a winner for Oxford from the get-go." He also says that Oxford added much-needed retail expertise after it bought the brand in 2010.
Lilly's growing appeal is partly the result of a national ad campaign launched this year by Target (TGT) .

The campaign counted down the days until Target's April 19 launch of Lilly Pulitzer products. Target's limited, one-time launch gave customers the chance to buy into the brand for prices as low as $10 to $20.
Too Hot To Handle
The promotion essentially ended the same day it started. Items sold out within minutes at besieged Target stores as well as on the company's website, which went down from too much traffic.
Target got bad press for being unprepared (again) to handle heavy volumes. But Oxford ended up sitting pretty. It got free publicity and enhanced consumer awareness for the brand.
"Target spent more on the ramp up of that launch than Lilly spends in a year," said Beder. "To get the Lilly name in front of consumers positions Lilly for more aggressive growth."
The Target promotion also lets Lilly know where demand is strongest for potential store openings and test how well certain products for the home did, Quintiliano says.

Lilly Pulitzer operates 28 company stores. Another 70 "Signature" stores are franchised. All sell resort-wear-inspired apparel and related merchandise for women and girls. Many items in the new summer collection are priced from $100 to well over $200.
Oxford plans to push Lilly stores farther West. Six store openings are planned for this year, the most that Oxford has ever opened in a year since it bought the brand.
"Lilly Pulitzer has a lot of runway to go beyond the East Coast," Quintiliano said.

Oxford also intends to open eight to 10 Tommy Bahama stores in the U.S. and internationally, including Japan and Australia. A planned store in Honolulu's Waikiki neighborhood will include a restaurant.
Tommy Bahama ended last fiscal year with 157 retail stores globally, up from 141 a earlier year.
Its stores carry casual apparel and beachwear as well as sandals, home goods and gift items. Most are full-price stores; 15 have linked restaurants.
Tommy and Lilly also license various products. Both brands are also sold wholesale to select specialty and department stores, including Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN).
Chubb noted in the conference call that the company has stayed focused on its full-price strategy, bucking a trend toward discounting, and said that it has "worked."
Same-store sales at Tommy were up 8% year over year in the fourth quarter, which ended Jan. 31. Same-store sales at Lilly rose 9%.
Oxford's total revenue during the quarter rose 10% from a year earlier to $274.5 million, with Tommy Bahama accounting for $186 million and Lilly Pulitzer $34.8 million.
The rest came from Ben Sherman and Lanier Clothes' branded and private-label men's suits, sportcoats, separates and dress slacks.
Oxford has been trying to fix Ben Sherman ahead of the brand's sale. Though Ben Sherman's sales have improved, it's still losing money, just not as much as before.
Better Times Ahead?

Oxford's total revenue for the full year climbed 9% to $997.8 million. Earnings also rose in the single digits but are expected to climb in double digits this year with Ben Sherman out of the picture.

Oxford excluded Ben Sherman from this year's forecast, which calls for net sales of $965 million to $980 million and adjusted per-share earnings of $3.45 to $3.60. That's up from an adjusted $920.3 million and $3.46, respectively, in 2014, excluding Ben Sherman.

Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect earnings to rise 19% this year, to $3.55 a share, and climb another 10% the next year.Goodbye to "Mod" boy brand Ben Sherman, a relic from London's swinging '60s.Hello Lilly Pulitzer, another name from that era, but from another continent and generation — in this case, Palm Beach, Fla.'s affluent resort set, which took up the brand's breezy pastels as its casual-attire uniform.While apparel company Oxford Industries (OXM) tries to find a buyer for its struggling Ben Sherman brand, it plans to step up nationwide expansion of Lilly Pulitzer, now popular among women across generations as well as incomes.It will also keep growing Tommy Bahama, its No. 1 brand, globally.'Foundation Brands'Oxford, with roots in men's suits and button-down shirts, is all about beachy casual wear now.In the firm's fiscal fourth-quarter earnings release on March 26, CEO Thomas Chubb called Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer "foundation brands."And in a conference call that followed, he said: "In both Tommy Bahama and Lilly Pulitzer, we believe we have cultivated a deep and powerful emotional connection with our customers."After Oxford announced in the Q4 report that it was looking for a buyer for Ben Sherman — and that earnings in the quarter grew 21% from the prior year — the company's shares jumped 19% the next trading day.Tommy Bahama is targeted to an older and more affluent demographic than Ben Sherman's edgy, young male demographic. Macy's (M) is going head-to-head with Nordstrom (JWN) Rack and others by debuting four pilot off-price stores in New York this fall.Under the Macy's Backstage moniker, the off-price stores will offer women's, men's and children's clothes and shoes, in addition to housewares, home textiles and other items. Merchandise will include clearance and discounted brand-name items, the company said. Macy's is locating the new 30,000-square-foot shops in Brooklyn, Queens, New Hyde Park and Huntington.The off-price stores will offer free Wi-Fi and large fitting rooms, and one location will include a cafe concept.As clothing buyers flock to fast-fashion retailers like Forever 21 and H&M, and shoppers spread their dollars to e-commerce one-stop-shops such as Amazon (AMZN), the competition for brick-and-mortar retail is fierce.Several full-price Nordstrom stores are testing curbside pickup for online orders, according to the Puget Sound Business Journal.Macy's Backstage test stores will likely vie for the same customers that shop at Nordstrom Rack, Ross Stores (ROST) and TJX's (TJX) Marshalls and T.J. Maxx, which also offer discounted designer goods and off-price home furnishings.Macy's shares were down 0.9% at 64.68 in early afternoon trading in the stock market today, Tuesday.Department store Kohl's (KSS) shares were down 1%. JC Penney (JCP) shares were off 0.8%.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.9%. The Nasdaq and S&P 500 climbed 0.7% apiece. Volume was soft, down 2% on the Nasdaq and 14% lower on the NYSE, compared with trade at the same time Wednesday.

As mall REITs head into 2015, retail outlet centers continue to take center stage as the name of the game in new development.The push comes at a time when the focus for regional mall owners and operators has been on redevelopment rather than ground-up projects and many retail tenants are expanding their off-price store presence as a way to feed the consumer appetite for value and lift sales and profits."It appears that the environment for outlet centers remains strong, or at least the enthusiasm on the part of developers and owners remains," Ryan Severino, senior economist for commercial real estate tracker Reis, told IBD via email. "Outlet centers are a much more prominent part of the retail landscape than they were just 10 or 15 years ago."While high-end mall owners and quality shopping center operators are expected to perform well this year, in a recent report Stifel analyst Nathan Isbee said most of the new development among the mall REITs has been focused on outlet centers."The outlet center industry is experiencing a building boom, delivering eight outlet center openings in both 2012 and 2013 and another six in 2014, well above the historical average of (two to three) centers," he wrote.Simon Property Group (SPG) and Tanger Factory Outlet Centers (SKT) are the two "dominant" outlet center developers, he adds, noting both have "robust" development pipelines in the U.S.Last month, Tanger and its 50/50 joint venture partner started construction on the newest Tanger Outlet center in Southaven, Miss., which is located four and one-half miles south of Memphis, Tanger said in a press release announcing fourth-quarter results Tuesday. Tanger expects the center to be completed in time for a holiday 2015 opening.Construction of the other new developments the company intends to open in 2015 is "ongoing," it said.  Current plans include an April 2015 opening at Tanger Outlets Savannah; a May 2015 grand opening at Tanger Outlets Foxwoods, at Foxwoods Resort Casino in Mashantucket, Conn.; and a third-quarter 2015 grand opening at Tanger Outlets Grand Rapids, in Grand Rapids, Mich.The company and its 50/50 joint venture partner expect to be able to start construction of Tanger Outlets Columbus, a pre-development stage project in Columbus, Ohio, in time to complete construction and open the center during the first half of 2016.Most of Simon Property Group's new development activity is concentrated in the outlet center sector, Isbee said. The REIT opened three outlet centers in 2014. It has four new outlet centers currently under construction, including ones in Gloucester, N.J.; Tucson, Ariz; Tampa, Fla.; and Vancouver, British Columbia, which will come online in 2015, Isbee says.High-end retailer Nordstrom (JWN) is among the store operators expanding its off-price concept, Nordstrom Rack. Nordstrom has 167 Nordstrom Rack stores and has announced plans to open 26 new stores in 2015, spokesman Dan Evans Jr. told IBD in an email interview.Among the openings planned for this year is a Nordstrom Rack at The Mall of Louisiana in Baton Rouge, La. The roughly 30,000-square-foot store is scheduled to open in fall 2015. The mall is owned and managed by General Growth Properties (GGP)."The Rack is a great fit for our overall strategy to serve more customers in more places in more ways," said Evans. "The Rack also allows us to introduce the Nordstrom brand to customers who have never shopped with us. We serve customers through four channels: Nordstrom and Nordstrom Rack stores, online full price at Nordstrom.com, and online off-price at Nordstromrack.com and HauteLook. We hope that by focusing on the customer and making it as easy, convenient and relevant for them, we are able to improve their experience with Nordstrom wherever they choose to shop with us."While the Rack is a "growing part" of Nordstrom's business, online — primarily Nordstrom.com — continues to be the fastest-growing, Evans said.Simon Property Group, General Growth Properties and Tanger Factory Outlet are part of IBD's Finance-Property REIT industry group. Simon Property Group has an 86 Composite Rating out of a possible 99 and General Growth Properties has a Composite Rating of 85, while Tanger Factory Outlet has a 62. The ratings factor in several metrics, such as earnings growth and stock price gains.Nordstrom is in IBD's Retail-Department Stores industry group and has its second-highest Composite Rating, 84, after Dillard's (DDS) at 85.

Friday the 13th turned out to be bad luck for the stock market as stocks ended with ugly losses, weighed down by another big drop in oil and weak retail sales data.The Nasdaq lost 1.5%, the Dow Jones industrial average fell 1.2% and the S&P 500 gave up 1.1%. Small caps were relatively unscathed as the Russell 2000 eased 0.6%. Preliminary data showed volume on the NYSE and Nasdaq coming in higher than Thursday's levels.At the New York Mercantile Exchange, December crude oil futures settled at $40.74 a barrel, down $1.01, or 2.8%. For the week, oil lost 8%.Money flowed into bonds as the 10-year Treasury yield fell 3 basis points to 2.28%.The selling seemed intense in the stock market today, but breadth wasn't too bad as declining stocks outnumbered advancers by less than 2-to-1 on both exchanges.Carnage in the retail sector was Friday's big story after October retail sales data disappointed. Retail sales rose 0.1% in October, below the consensus estimate of 0.3%. Excluding autos, sales rose 0.2%, also below expectations of 0.4%.Nordstrom (JWN) was the disaster de jour, gapping down 15% in furious volume after reporting disappointing earnings and sales. Macy's (M) shed 4% and has lost 20% this week on the heels of its own earnings disappointment.Eight of the 10 worst-performing groups in IBD's database were from the retail sector. Losses ranged from 3% to 13%. Jewelry retailers were particularly hard hit. Signet Jewelers (SIG) slumped 3%, bringing its three-day decline to nearly 9%. Nasdaq 100 retailers Ross Stores (ROST), Dollar Tree (DLTR), Bed, Bath & Beyond (BBBY) and Tractor Supply (TSCO) ended with losses of 5% to 7%.Cisco Systems (CSCO) plunged 6% after the networking gear leader reported earnings and issued disappointing guidance.Fitbit (FIT) wasn't so fit as shares cratered 12%. The company priced a secondary share offering at 29. Shares closed at 27.44. Elsewhere,Follow Ken Shreve on Twitter @IBD_KShreve and on Facebook .

Macy's (M), Nordstrom (JWN) and Dillard's (DDS) have issued grim results over the past week, putting extra scrutiny on other chains. Investment bank RBC Capital Markets on Monday turned Best Buy (BBY) into a "best sell" as it cut its rating on the stock to sector perform from outperform and lowered its price target to 36 from 42.Best Buy shares were down over 1% to below 32 in midday trading on the stock market today."We have become increasingly concerned over what appear to be deteriorating sales trends in the consumer electronics channel," RBC analyst Scot Ciccarelli said in a report Monday. "Specifically, government sales data for CE/appliances has continued to weaken on both a one- and two-year basis, and the last time we saw multiple months of negative CE retail sales growth (before this current streak) was late 2013/early 2014, when Best Buy missed its holiday sales plan."Even Costco (COST) couldn't buck the recent trend as its October consumer electronics sales turned negative, Ciccarelli said. He also noted that major retailers Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) had missed top-line projections recently."When combined with Best Buy's historical volatility around the holidays (since Q4 accounts for 50%-60% of earnings) and our view that the company needs to post sustained comp improvement for the stock to re-rate higher, we believe a more cautious stance is prudent," Ciccarelli said.On the plus side, Best Buy has vastly improved its competitive positioning through price-matching Amazon.com (AMZN) and others, and forming in-store vendor partnerships with technology leaders such as Apple (AAPL), Samsung, Microsoft (MSFT) and Alphabet (GOOGL)-owned Google, he said. These moves have helped Best Buy gain market share in consumer electronics retail.Best Buy is scheduled to report fiscal third quarter earnings before the market open on Thursday.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect the company to earn 35 cents a share, up 3% year over year, on sales of $8.83 billion, down 2%, in the October quarter.For the holiday sales quarter, analysts are modeling for Best Buy to earn $1.45 a share, down 2%, on sales of $13.90 billion, down 2%.Ultrahigh-definition, or 4K, television sets are likely to drive sales in the holiday season and through 2016, Ciccarelli said. But recent fast-growth categories such as fitness wearables, led by Fitbit (FIT), and action cameras, led by GoPro (GPRO), are showing signs of maturity, he said.Wedbush analyst Michael Pachter on Monday maintained his neutral rating and price target of 37 on Best Buy stock.He expects the company to post robust Q3 results thanks to strong management execution and growth in appliance sales.RELATED:GameStop weakness exposed by retail sales report.Ultra HD TVs going mainstream this holiday season.

Never mind "Let It Snow." Heading into the crucial holiday shopping season, retailers are more likely singing "Let It Go" from the movie "Frozen" as they try to shake off disappointing quarterly earnings results and a bad week that collectively sank merchant stocks.Nordstrom (JWN), Macy 's (M), J.C. Penney Co. (JCP) and Kohl's (KSS) were among those that reported the week of Nov. 9, with Nordstrom and Macy's turning in weak results and discounted forecasts, and J.C. Penney and Kohl's shares falling despite beating consensus views.An October retail sales data miss — a worse-than-expected 0.1% gain — didn't help either, though Amazon (AMZN) and other e-commerce sellers notably logged a 7.1% rise from the previous year as consumers continue to do much of their shopping online. Cowen & Co. predicted in July that Amazon would knock out Macy's as the top U.S. apparel retailer by 2017.Even much-lauded off-pricers haven't been immune to the pummeling that retail stocks were subjected to over the past week. Shares of TJX (TJX), the parent company of T.J. Maxx, Marshalls and HomeGoods, lost 12% over the past week.In a possible sign of things to come, Q3 same-store sales at Nordstrom's off-price arm, Nordstrom Rack, fell 2.2%."This type of miss from Rack is surprising to us, and we acknowledge the Rack's off-price slowdown could be a negative indicator for TJX," wrote Cowen & Co. analyst Oliver Chen on Friday.But he added that TJX, which reports Tuesday, could "offset some secular weakness" based on a few factors, including the strength of the company's sourcing and buying teams, home goods offerings and international reach.The company is expected to report a slight earnings dip of 1% to 84 cents a share. That would mark the third straight quarter of earnings deceleration and a swing from earnings gains of 7%, 8% and 15% in the three preceding periods.Revenue is seen rising 5% to $7.73 million, which also would reflect a slowdown.With a 75 IBD Composite Rating, TJX is the highest ranking member of IBD's Retail-Apparel/Shoes/Accessories group, which ranks a feeble 144 out of 197 groups.Peers in the group include Ross Stores, Foot Locker (FL), L Brands (LB) and American Eagle Outfitters (AEO).Fellow off-pricer Ross Stores (ROST) gapped down ahead of its Thursday earnings release, losing 11% for the week. Analysts expect over 6% EPS growth to 50 cents on 6% sales growth to $2.77 billion.And what about the big-box retailers?Target's (TGT) earnings are seen accelerating, with a predicted 59% climb to 86 cents a share on a 1% revenue dip to $17.57 billion. Shares retreated 6.9% last week.And Wall Street expects Wal-Mart (WMT) earnings to slide 15% to 98 cents a share on a 1% revenue decline to $117.79 billion. Shares slid 4%."We believe retail is in a state of transition as brands wrestle with how to compete against growing & dynamic pureplay online retailers," wrote Chen.RELATED:Retail Sales Weak, Except For Amazon, EcommerceMacy's Stock Selloff Could Be Tip Of Iceberg4 Reasons TJX, Off-Price Retailers Will Keep Surging.

Retail ETFs fell hard Friday as Nordstrom (JWN) and Fossil (FOSL) disappointed investors already grappling with Macy's (M) grim results and outlook. October retail sales data, released today, did little to lift the spirits.
The markets sold off broadly, with ETFs tracking major indexes closing at session lows.
J.C. Penney (JCP) reported a sales beat before the market open, but the stock tumbled 15% amid broader retail woes.
Nordstrom, the upscale department store, plunged 15% on the stock market today.
Fossil, the watch and fashion accessories company, sank 37%.
Macy's fell 4%.
Even Kohl's (KSS) reversed, diving 7% despite an earnings beat Thursday that saw the stock gap up to briefly retake its 50-day line.
Retailers' woes rippled across the consumer discretionary sector. IBD Leaderboard stock Starbucks (SBUX) slipped 2% and posted its third consecutive weekly loss.
The retail-restaurant industry group is currently ranked 114 out of 197 industry groups tracked by IBD. Department stores rank 193, the worst among retail groups. Internet retail ranks best at No. 4.

Consumer Discretionary Select SDPR (XLY), the largest ETF holding retail, restaurant and related stocks, tumbled 2.7%, finishing near the bottom of the day's range. It was the hardest hit of 11 Select Sector SDPR ETFs holding S&P 500 stocks.
XLY holds 89 stocks, with Amazon.com (AMZN) its largest holding at 11% portfolio weighting. It also holds Starbucks and fast-food giant McDonald's (MCD).
The ETF is 5% off its 52-week high of 81.87, set Nov. 4. It bagged a 5% weekly loss, giving up its gains over the past month.
SPDR S&P Retail (XRT), which focuses more exclusively on general merchandisers, drug stores, grocery stores and apparel stores, fell 3.8%.
The ETF holds 102 equal-weighted stocks and is 17% off its old high. Amazon is among its holdings.
XRT is down 11% year to date through Thursday vs. a 9% gain for XLY.
Gold continues to lose its shine. Gold ETFs hit their lowest point in the past year Thursday.
Weekly Update
SPDR Gold Shares (GLD) posted its fourth weekly loss, declining 0.5%. The ETF is 17% off its January high.

Major U.S. stock indexes snapped six straight weeks of gains. ETFs tracking the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial indexes breached their 200-day moving averages as the market direction shifted to uptrend under pressure. That calls for a cautious approach from ETF investors.
Among sectors, utilities eked out a 0.7% weekly gain. Every other S&P 500 sector finished in the red for the week. Energy was gouged nearly 6%.

Stocks were narrowly mixed going into the last hour of the regular trading session. The Nasdaq held a gain of less than 0.1%, while the S&P 500 and Dow Jones industrial average each dipped less than 0.1%.

As mall REITs head into 2015, retail outlet centers continue to take center stage as the name of the game in new development.The push comes at a time when the focus for regional mall owners and operators has been on redevelopment rather than ground-up projects and many retail tenants are expanding their off-price store presence as a way to feed the consumer appetite for value and lift sales and profits."It appears that the environment for outlet centers remains strong, or at least the enthusiasm on the part of developers and owners remains," Ryan Severino, senior economist for commercial real estate tracker Reis, told IBD via email. "Outlet centers are a much more prominent part of the retail landscape than they were just 10 or 15 years ago."While high-end mall owners and quality shopping center operators are expected to perform well this year, in a recent report Stifel analyst Nathan Isbee said most of the new development among the mall REITs has been focused on outlet centers."The outlet center industry is experiencing a building boom, delivering eight outlet center openings in both 2012 and 2013 and another six in 2014, well above the historical average of (two to three) centers," he wrote.Simon Property Group (SPG) and Tanger Factory Outlet Centers (SKT) are the two "dominant" outlet center developers, he adds, noting both have "robust" development pipelines in the U.S.Last month, Tanger and its 50/50 joint venture partner started construction on the newest Tanger Outlet center in Southaven, Miss., which is located four and one-half miles south of Memphis, Tanger said in a press release announcing fourth-quarter results Tuesday. Tanger expects the center to be completed in time for a holiday 2015 opening.Construction of the other new developments the company intends to open in 2015 is "ongoing," it said.  Current plans include an April 2015 opening at Tanger Outlets Savannah; a May 2015 grand opening at Tanger Outlets Foxwoods, at Foxwoods Resort Casino in Mashantucket, Conn.; and a third-quarter 2015 grand opening at Tanger Outlets Grand Rapids, in Grand Rapids, Mich.The company and its 50/50 joint venture partner expect to be able to start construction of Tanger Outlets Columbus, a pre-development stage project in Columbus, Ohio, in time to complete construction and open the center during the first half of 2016.Most of Simon Property Group's new development activity is concentrated in the outlet center sector, Isbee said. The REIT opened three outlet centers in 2014. It has four new outlet centers currently under construction, including ones in Gloucester, N.J.; Tucson, Ariz; Tampa, Fla.; and Vancouver, British Columbia, which will come online in 2015, Isbee says.High-end retailer Nordstrom (JWN) is among the store operators expanding its off-price concept, Nordstrom Rack. Nordstrom has 167 Nordstrom Rack stores and has announced plans to open 26 new stores in 2015, spokesman Dan Evans Jr. told IBD in an email interview.Among the openings planned for this year is a Nordstrom Rack at The Mall of Louisiana in Baton Rouge, La. The roughly 30,000-square-foot store is scheduled to open in fall 2015. The mall is owned and managed by General Growth Properties (GGP)."The Rack is a great fit for our overall strategy to serve more customers in more places in more ways," said Evans. "The Rack also allows us to introduce the Nordstrom brand to customers who have never shopped with us. We serve customers through four channels: Nordstrom and Nordstrom Rack stores, online full price at Nordstrom.com, and online off-price at Nordstromrack.com and HauteLook. We hope that by focusing on the customer and making it as easy, convenient and relevant for them, we are able to improve their experience with Nordstrom wherever they choose to shop with us."While the Rack is a "growing part" of Nordstrom's business, online — primarily Nordstrom.com — continues to be the fastest-growing, Evans said.Simon Property Group, General Growth Properties and Tanger Factory Outlet are part of IBD's Finance-Property REIT industry group. Simon Property Group has an 86 Composite Rating out of a possible 99 and General Growth Properties has a Composite Rating of 85, while Tanger Factory Outlet has a 62. The ratings factor in several metrics, such as earnings growth and stock price gains.Nordstrom is in IBD's Retail-Department Stores industry group and has its second-highest Composite Rating, 84, after Dillard's (DDS) at 85.
Stocks were on pace for a flat to slightly higher start Monday amid mixed overseas action.
Nasdaq 100 futures were up 5 points vs. fair value, and S&P 500 futures were up less than a point. Futures on the Dow Jones industrial average were up 15 points in the stock market today.

The major indexes posted big gains last week, but failed to recoup the bulk of the prior week's sharp slide. Despite gains in the overall market last week, a number of market leaders such as Outerwall (OUTR), Vasco Data Security International (VDSI) and Taser International (TASR) got whacked.
U.S. stock futures still fared better than the mixed action overseas. The Greek stock market reopened for the first time in five weeks, plunging by nearly 23% before cutting losses.
But Germany's DAX and France's CAC-40 climbed 1% and 0.7%, respectively. The euro fell to 1.095 from 1.0984 late Friday.
Asian stock markets were firmly lower following weak manufacturing data. The Shanghai composite slumped 1.1%, and Hong Kong's Hang Seng lost 0.9%.
In economic news, personal income rose 0.4% in June, slightly above views for a 0.3% increase. Spending edged up 0.2%, matching views by Econoday. But that was the smallest gain in four months.
Factory data from Markit will be out at 9:45 a.m., and ISM's manufacturing report will be released at 10 a.m. Data on construction spending will also be out at 10 a.m.

In stocks, Tyson Foods (TSN) tumbled 8% in the premarket after posting disappointing quarterly results and cut its full-year earnings outlook. The company said its beef business suffered disruptions in the export market.

Irish drugmaker Shire (SHPG) said it bought privately held Foresight Biotherapeutics for $300 million. Foresight makes a treatment for infectious conjunctivitis, or pink eye.
