Powered by robust demand and lean supply, high-end mall owners and quality shopping center operators are primed to perform in 2015.They are riding the crest of a stronger economy and healthy consumer spending climate, and are now luring shoppers with enhanced services and experiences.The bright prospects come at a time when the stars are also aligned for the retail industry."Retailers are heading into 2015 with the most momentum they've had since the Great Recession," Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, told IBD.A healthy consumer spending climate at retail would bode well for big mall owners such as Simon Property Group (SPG), Macerich (MAC), General Growth Properties (GGP), and Taubman Centers (TCO) as well as community and neighborhood shopping center operator and owner Kimco Realty (KIM), all of which benefit when their tenants get more financially fit.Malls And The MarketRetail mall real estate investment trusts are part of IBD's Finance-Property REIT industry group, and several get high Composite Ratings. Out of a possible 99, Kimco Realty has a 98, Simon Property Group a 91 and General Growth Properties an 87, factoring in metrics such as earnings growth and stock-price gains.All three have run up in the stock market. Kimco Realty shares rose 27% in 2014 and are up 11% this year. General Growth Properties jumped 40% in 2014 and is up 9% in 2015. Simon Property Group lifted 27% in 2014 and is up 11% this year.Macro tailwinds should help malls this year."There should be a lot of momentum with the (stronger) economy and (lower) energy prices," Ryan Severino, senior economist for commercial real estate tracker Reis (REIS), told IBD via email. "The decline in energy should add billions in spending. Some of that will accrue to malls. The real question is how much and will that be enough to offset the impact of store closings?"The top firms should still be regional mall REITs that focus on "A" malls — those that sell the most per square foot and tend toward more upscale retailers and trade areas — real estate experts say."Class A malls should continue to have low vacancy and strong rent growth (in 2015)," said Severino. "But for the remainder of the subsector, vacancy could actually rise, and rent growth will probably accelerate only slightly."At year end, the national mall vacancy rate was 8%, up 10 basis points for in 2014. Rents grew by 1.8% during that year, says Severino. He forecasts that in 2015, rents should grow by roughly 2% to 2.5%.But the national vacancy rate is not likely to change much in 2015 as store closures will offset rising demand and the outlook for lower-caliber malls "is murkier," he said. "Although a strengthening recovery in the economy and labor market, coupled with a decline in energy prices, should bolster the subsector, this will compete against the store closings (in lower-caliber malls) of some important retailers such asJ.C. Penney (JCP) and Sears (SHLD)."Class A OverachieversStifel Nicolaus analyst Nathan Isbee is also upbeat about prospects for "A" malls. "Retailer demand for high-quality mall space will remain robust in 2015 from international and domestic retailers," he wrote in a report, calling high-quality mall space is "extremely limited."General Growth Properties is his top regional mall pick for 2015. The REIT focuses exclusively on owning, managing, leasing and redeveloping Class A regional malls and urban flagship locations in the U.S., spokesman Kevin Berry told IBD.He says the firm believes that owning these retail properties positions it well for the long term.Generally, he adds, the properties' leases have ten-year terms with annual contractual increases in rent. "On average, 10% of the leases expire," he said. "The majority of the annual revenue (is) in place when the year begins."General Growth Properties' strategy since Sandeep Mathrani became CEO in 2011 has been the creation of a redevelopment/expansion pipeline of projects, Berry says. As of Dec. 31, the firm had development and redevelopment activities totaling about $2.4 billion "at share," of which projects totaling about $418 million have opened, $1.2 billion are under construction and $825 million are in the pipeline.Redevelopment is all tenant driven, says Berry. General's largest redevelopment project is at Ala Moana Center in Honolulu, which it is expanding with a new luxury wing anchored by Bloomingdale's and Nordstrom (JWN). General also focuses on improving the shopping experience by adding options such as movie theaters and restaurants, which give shoppers more reasons to come to the malls and spend time."Mall vacancies in the U.S. are currently at a five-year low of 5.7% and at 5.5% for just the major markets," said Greg Maloney, CEO of the Americas Retail Group at commercial real estate firm Jones Lang LaSalle (JLL), citing real estate data company CoStar as the source.He says that malls are going into 2015 with probably the best fundamentals seen in the past five years."Liquidity and appetite for product has been here for a few years, but now consumers are feeling much better about the economy, and that is the driving force," he adds. "We now have positive momentum. Retailers are looking to expand with new stores, and there's a renewed interest in terms of retailers looking for new space."He says that there's some new mall development for the first time in a long time, including three or four projects that JLL is doing.Isbee notes that shopping center REIT fundamentals are "healthy as occupancies are approaching or exceeding pre-recession levels."Kimco Realty is among REITs he rates a buy. It operates North America's largest publicly traded portfolio of neighborhood and community shopping centers. CEO David Henry calls fundamentals for such shopping centers strong. "We've been very fortunate that there's been no new building of shopping centers for six years," he told IBD.While the supply of centers hasn't grown, the U.S. population has grown at between 2.5 million and 3 million people a year. And the need for restaurants, grocers, dry cleaners and other businesses has grown with the population."That's why occupancies are moving up and all the vital signs are looking good for shopping centers," he said, adding that shopping centers are still in "recovery mode" and rents not back to all-time highs. But he says Kimco is benefiting from more demand and limited supply.Henry says that occupancy at "quality" centers is at 95%, close to Kimco's all-time high of 96% before the recession.Redevelopment Vs. New MallsKimco has been doing a lot of redevelopment, he says, and the best place to invest capital is in its own properties — the value of projects in the pipeline is nearing $1 billion.Most of the new development among the mall REITs has been concentrated on outlet centers, with six opened in 2014, says Isbee.David Ober, president of Global Outlet Management, says that among the reasons behind building more outlet centers is retailers' desire to include outlet stores as a part of their "omnichannel" distribution mix along with full-price stores.Still, Garrick Brown, vice president of research at property services firm DTZ, says, "We are nearing a saturation point" in outlet center building and adds that there's room for only "a little more product.""Everyone wants to jump on this bandwagon to build these because they have performed so well in recent years," he said by email. "But they will probably build too many."

Holiday hiring is in full swing, and this year — like last year — the biggest employment gains are expected in a handful of retail sectors, according to the Pew Research Center.In November, clothing companies and department stores accounted for more than half of retail job gains, adding 121,600 and 114,700 jobs, respectively, noted Pew Research in a report issued Friday.Last year, nearly a third of the retail-job surge over the holidays occurred in clothing/accessories stores, with 202,400 jobs added from October through December. Department stores followed with 177,400 new jobs.Retail payrolls typically rise 3% to 4% between October and December, Pew said. Some 626,200 retail jobs were added in November and December last year, for a 4.1% gain over the earlier year.Other big holiday hirers are general merchandise stores and sporting goods, hobby, book and music stores, Pew said.Macy's (M) announced in late September that this year it would hire seasonal associates for about 86,000 positions at its Macy's and Bloomingdale's stores and in other parts of the company, up about 3.6% from 2013, with 10,000 of the jobs based in fulfillment centers that support online ordering and other aspects of Macy's "omnichannel" selling strategy.This holiday shopping season is broadly shaping up stronger than expected so far in terms of retailer revenue, despite some reports of a lackluster Black Friday. Sales at stores open at least a year rose 5% year over year in November, according to a Retail Metrics index, while forecasts had called for just a 3.4% rise.Considering factors such as earnings growth and stock market gains, Ross Stores (ROST) and TJX (TJX) are the highest-rated stocks in IBD's retail-apparel group, which is ranked 34 out of 197 industry groups in stock market performance. Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy's are the highest-rated stocks in the retail-department store industry, though the sector itself is ranked relatively low.What happens after all that holiday hiring? What goes up must come down. Retail payrolls typically fall 5% to 6% between December and February, Pew's research noted. Last year, the retail sector shed 888,000 jobs in the two months after December. That was more than the number hired over the holidays, as some retailers with disappointing results laid off staff or closed poorly performing stores."If history is any guide, retail payrolls will rise again this month before dropping sharply after the New Year," wrote Pew Research's Drew DeSilver.Sectors that don't much change their hiring policy over the holidays are nonseasonal grocery and drug stores and building materials and garden supply stores, which hit their peak payrolls in summer.Related: Costco, Gap Lead Solid November Holiday Start.

When a sale falls through or something else flops, look at how you helped cause the problem rather than blaming someone else. Maybe you didn't…

Shares of specialty department store Kohl's (KSS) have been suffering some unwanted promotional activity in early trading Thursday as the discount retailer reported earnings and revenue misses from the third quarter amid an often-challenging retail environment.
Shares of the company, which has 1,163 stores nationwide, fell 3.7% to 55.76 in the stock market today.
Profit fell 13.6% to 70 cents a share, missing analyst forecasts by 4 cents, while sales dipped 1.6% to $4.37 billion, falling short of views for $4.4 billion.
Kohl's opened three new stores and reopened one store during the quarter.

Dillard's (DDS), which also reported Q3 results Thursday, said per-share earnings notched up 15% to $1.30, while revenue edged down 0.5% to $1.5 billion, missing slightly. The department store company said sales trends were strongest in the juniors' and children's apparel areas.
Discounter Wal-Mart (WMT) topped Q3 views with a 1% earnings rise to $1.15 a share, topping by 3 cents, and a 3% sales rise to $119 billion, also topping.
Nordstrom (JWN) reports after the close Thursday.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Wal-Mart's Q3 Tops Expectations As U.S. Comps Rise

Department Stores To Give Back-To-School Show & Tell.Shares of specialty department store Kohl's (KSS) have been suffering some unwanted promotional activity in early trading Thursday as the discount retailer reported earnings and revenue misses from the third quarter amid an often-challenging retail environment.Shares of the company, which has 1,163 stores nationwide, fell 3.7% to 55.76 in the stock market today.Profit fell 13.6% to 70 cents a share, missing analyst forecasts by 4 cents, while sales dipped 1.6% to $4.37 billion, falling short of views for $4.4 billion.Kohl's opened three new stores and reopened one store during the quarter.Dillard's (DDS), which also reported Q3 results Thursday, said per-share earnings notched up 15% to $1.30, while revenue edged down 0.5% to $1.5 billion, missing slightly. The department store company said sales trends were strongest in the juniors' and children's apparel areas.Discounter Wal-Mart (WMT) topped Q3 views with a 1% earnings rise to $1.15 a share, topping by 3 cents, and a 3% sales rise to $119 billion, also topping.Nordstrom (JWN) reports after the close Thursday.Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.RELATED:Wal-Mart's Q3 Tops Expectations As U.S. Comps RiseDepartment Stores To Give Back-To-School Show & Tell.
Retailers overcame a sluggish Black Friday as a brighter jobs picture and lower gas prices put consumers in more of a buying mood in December and heading into the final stretch.

Steep early promotions led to a disappointing Thanksgiving weekend. Meanwhile, Amazon (AMZN) and other online rivals continue to take a bigger slice of a limited retail pie.Still, retailers are on track to deliver the best holiday season in three years.Michael Niemira, principal of The Retail Economist, is sticking to his forecast for combined November-December sales growth of 2.9% after a Scrooge-like 0.9% increase last year. That's based on Census Bureau's GAFO (general merchandise, apparel, furniture and other, including electronics and sporting goods), and would be the best gain since 2011."The key difference this holiday vs. last year and the last few years is the stronger economy, which is the underpinning for holiday spending," Niemira said.Mobile Still ActiveTop gift items were consumer electronics, especially mobile devices such as smartphones and tablets, says Marshal Cohen, NPD Group's chief industry analyst. Home decor products, small appliances and activewear were also big winners, he says.Bill Martin, founder of ShopperTrak sees retailers on track to show a 3.8% gain in GAFO sales for November and December."That's a pretty good number," he told IBD.November retail sales rose 5.4%, fueled by an "early push" that helped offset an underperforming Thanksgiving weekend, says Martin. It took until the week before Christmas for consumers to get "ramped up again, which is going on right now."Sales on the last pre-Christmas Saturday likely rose 0.5% above last year to about $9.16 billion, according to Martin's preliminary tally. That would just top Black Friday's sales of roughly $9.1 billion, making Super Saturday the No. 1 shopping day for the first time in 10 years.Thomson Reuters analysts see December same-store sales rising 4%, up from 2013's 3.5%."That suggests shoppers hit the malls this month," said Jharonne Martis, director of consumer research, via email.Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, says it was a "decent holiday, fueled by a good jobs picture and significantly lower gas prices."But apparel was "soft" due to a lack of fashion and as consumers focused spending on other areas, such as home furnishings, electronics and accessories.Best Buy (BBY), Williams-Sonoma (WSM), Lowe's (LOW) and Home Depot (HD) were among retailers with good holiday sales, he says.Thomson Reuters analysts forecast the home improvement segment will be the big winner in the November-to-January quarter with a 5.3% same-store sales rise, followed by footwear at 4.6% and jewelry at 4.1%."The season shows that the consumer is alive and kicking a lot harder than you would think," adds Brian Sozzi, CEO of Belus Capital Advisors. "You really got a good feel of what 5% GDP (growth) meant for retailers during this holiday."Consumers were buying the priciest items at stores such as Best Buy, J.C. Penney (JCP) and Dick's Sporting Goods (DKS), Sozzi said. At Best Buy they snapped up GoPro (GPRO) action cameras and the Apple (AAPL) iPhone 6 and iPhone 6 Plus.Expensive lightweight jackets and hoodies from Nike (NKE) and Under Armour (UA) were also hot, says Sozzi.Cohen says the season turned out OK. "Retailers had an early start, a lull (later) that was expected, and a strong finish through Christmas (Eve)," he said. "Now they have the gift cards, the returns and exchanges. There's still more revenue to come for retailers."Retailers Didn't 'Panic'Retailers did a "very good job" all year managing inventory, including doorbusters, Cohen said. Except for mall-based apparel chains, they mostly stuck to their planned holiday promotions, a good sign for profit margins."They weren't in a panic mode," Cohen said.Perkins estimates holiday online sales — from pure play e-tailers to brick-and-mortar stores — rose 15%, with traditional chains' online business up 10% to 15%.He says traditional stores such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN) are getting a "handle on" ecommerce with features like ordering online and in-store pickup."They're doing a better job of capturing online sales and not just feeding them to Amazon."

Macy's (M) discounted full-year per-share earnings guidance as the nationwide department store retailer reported lagging third-quarter sales. Shares rose 3% to 60.34 in the stock market today as it reported better-than-expected Q3 earnings. Department-store retailer Nordstrom said Thursday that its board of directors has approved a $1 billion share repurchase program that will last until March 2016.
Nordstrom (JWN) shares gapped up 1.7% to 70.82 in early morning trading on the stock market today, reaching a record high.
Nordstrom says that existing cash on hand will fund the buyback.
Nordstrom's current stock repurchase program, initiated in February 2013, has $323 million outstanding and will expire in March 2015.

The new plan comes several weeks after Nordstrom reported lackluster second-quarter sales, which increased just 3.3% to $3.3 billion and fell short of analyst expectations. Earnings inched up 2.2% to 95 cents a share, edging views by a penny. Shares tumbled 7% that week.
But Nordstrom has since recovered from the loss. The stock is up nearly 13% so far this year.

"While we've been huge fans since the early recovery days of '09, we believe it's best not to get greedy, particularly given a few yellow flags that have recently emerged," said Sterne Agee analyst Charles Grom…
Macy's (M) posted second-quarter earnings below views Wednesday as aggressive promotions took their toll, and the department store giant cut its full-year same-store sales forecast.

Earnings rose 11% to 80 cents a share, short of forecasts by analysts for 86 cents. Sales rose 3.3% to $6.27 billion, reversing sales declines in each of the prior two quarters. Still, sales missed forecasts for $6.3 billion.
Same-store sales rose 3.4% from a year earlier in Q2. Including comparable sales licensed to third parties, same-store sales increased 4%.

The operator of stores under its name and Bloomingdale's also cut its full-year same-store sales growth forecast to 1.5%-2% from 2.5%-3%. Macy's noted that even with better sales trends in Q2, it couldn't make up for the harsh-weather-related sales slump it saw in Q1.
Gross margin in Q2 slipped to 41.4% from 41.8% a year earlier.
Shares slid 5% in the stock market today.
Why the earnings miss?

"The company simply overordered inventory in the first quarter when same-store sales missed," said Brian Sozzi, CEO of Belus Capital Advisors, via email. "Hence, it came into the second quarter being forced to enact more unprofitable markdowns."

Sozzi added that the report is "disappointing from an execution standpoint and an economic standpoint. Macy's is the pulse of the country, and with quicker job creation the company shouldn't be having any inventory issues. People should be buying the stuff."

Ken Perkins, president of Retail Metrics, said in a note that the report raises concerns about prospects for other retailers: "As one of the top performing and best executing retailers in the industry, Macy's second-quarter earnings miss is an ominous early marker for retail that could portend further disappointing results over the coming weeks."

Macy's CEO Terry Lundgren said in a statement that the sales trend improved at both Macy's and Bloomingdale's in the second quarter, "reflecting a rebound in shopping activity once weather patterns normalized."
The trend also reflected a shift in a major Macy's promotional event into the first two days of the quarter.

"We are approaching the second half of 2014 with confident optimism in our business strategies, merchandise assortments and marketing plans, tempered with the reality that many customers still are not feeling comfortable about spending more in an uncertain economic environment," Lundgren added.
The company maintained its same-store sales guidance for 2014's second half.
The company also maintained its full-year 2014 earnings per share guidance in the range of $4.40 to $4.50.

Gordon Segal was clueless about retailing when he opened the first Crate & Barrel in 1962.He forgot to buy a cash register for opening day.He didn't realize that he was selling many products at cost when overhead was factored in.The store lost rising amounts of money for the first four months.But Segal learned from his mistakes and studied masters of upscale retailing such as Nordstrom (JWN) and Neiman Marcus.By the time he retired in 2008, the privately held Crate & Barrel had $1.3 billion in annual revenue and was profitable, with 7,000 employees and 104 stores."Retailing is like theater," Segal told IBD. "The store is the stage, with scenery, lighting and music. The products are the script — each item has an interesting story. The employees are the actors who make it come alive and bring the customers back."And C&B's customers have indeed come back.Stanley Marcus, former CEO of Neiman Marcus, told Inc. magazine in 1985 that Gordon Segal is "one of the great merchants of this century."Illinois RiseSegal, 75, was born into a restaurant family in Chicago.He earned a business degree from Northwestern University in 1960 and went to Europe to study restaurant supply houses for a fresh perspective on the industry he expected to enter.The next year, he and his new wife, Carole, honeymooned in the U.S. Virgin Islands, where they discovered European shops with snappy housewares that they had seen sold for much higher prices in America.Back home, Segal began wondering whether there might not be a lot of other young couples with good taste and no money who would buy well-designed items for the home at an affordable price.In 1962, the Segals spent $7,000 to refurbish a factory in Old Town Chicago and bought $10,000 — worth $77,000 now — of unique merchandise from European manufacturers.They didn't have money left for fancy displays, so they opened the shipping crates and barrels, and put them on the floor, underscoring the store's no-frills, direct-import value.As they grew more sophisticated in creating a distinctive look that would also drive sales, they drew attention with big stacks of merchandise, rough-hewn wood shelves, music, spotlights and lots of plants.Later, they brought in furniture and pioneered vignette displays, like a dining room with the table set and accompanying decor.These days, C&B stores have a sleek Northern European look.Segal emphasized to employees the need to build long-term relationships rather than pushing hard for the immediate sale.A thick handbook explains how to treat customers. Also at the stores, employees undergo product training to make them passionate experts. Most managers rise from the ranks and are not above helping customers on the floor.Neither was Segal. He was there daily for the first 15 years."I liked to hire teachers and others with upbeat personalities," Segal said. "We didn't call them salespeople. They were merchandising specialists who would manage a department of 1,500 or 2,000 square feet like a ministore."We created jobs that would be challenging for intelligent people. Competitors would try to copy us but didn't really understand what we were doing, and 30 days later their stores looked disheveled."Barbara Reimann, who retired as executive vice president of C&B's operations in 2012, said: "Gordon's curious nature, entrepreneurial spirit, passion for the details and enthusiasm are a winning combination and contagious. He constantly elicited feedback from associates on the front lines, knowing they were closest to the customer, and he's a great listener and wants to hear it all. He would tell them if they were comfortable in their jobs they weren't growing, and he encouraged them to take on new responsibilities in uncharted waters."Associates knew that the company's leadership cared about and respected them. That's why the longevity at the company was remarkable; 15 and 20 years was common. I was there over 37 years."C&B signs explain the origin of each item to emphasize its quality and uniqueness.One current example: "Our picnic-style indoor dining table is handcrafted of Northern European solid Baltic pine certified by the Forest Stewardship Council. Historically used by the British Royal Navy for ship masts, Baltic pine is extremely strong, with very few knots due to the colder climate. Select planks are hand-planed by skilled craftsmen, wire-brushed to bring out the grain and then whitewashed in a multistep process."Right from the start, Segal periodically went to Europe to seek out small companies that were not represented in America. Some had been burned by department-store buyers, who placed large initial orders and promised more. The vendors had expanded, but the stores didn't follow through.Global ReachSegal had to build trust so they would ship to him on credit.Eventually, he also established solid relationships with unique producers from India to the Far East.Segal aimed to grow slowly to make sure the formula was right."We wanted to be the best, not the biggest," he explained.His wife retired to start their family in 1965, and it would be another three years before Crate & Barrel opened a second store in suburban Wilmette, then a third in Oak Brook in 1971.Its first store outside the Chicago area was in Boston in 1977.Eight years later, the firm had reached 17 locations, bringing in $50 million a year, with a cult following for C&B's combination of high style and affordable prices.In need of cash to expand, Segal was afraid to go public because the market could be unforgiving of mistakes. But he wanted the benefit of "being able to take risks and learn from the experience."So in 1998, he sold a majority stake to the Otto Group, a giant German direct marketer, which became sole owner when he retired 10 years later and the family sold its shares. "They were great partners, and it was a pleasure running the company with them," Segal said.Going YoungIn 2000, C&B opened CB2, a home furnishings division geared to young adults, then set up a partnership with the founders of Land of Nod, which sells children's furniture and gifts.Meanwhile, C&B made a name for itself with sales online and by mail, especially with its bridal registry. When Segal stepped down, online accounted for a quarter of sales. Now it's 32%, says the firm."The Internet is a wonderful way to do research, but it doesn't replace the excitement of going into a store, where you can discover things that would go well with what you already knew you wanted," said Segal. "If you want to buy a good sofa, you really need to try it out, to understand the quality of the wood construction, to see if the seats have enough cushioning, how the springs feel, and if the height is right for your legs and it's a good fit."Said Reimann: "I didn't have an MBA, but I earned a virtual Ph.D. in retailing by working with Gordon. He's a true leader. You'd often hear associates use the expression 'WWGD' — which stood for 'What Would Gordon Do?' He inspired people to work as a team; there was no 'I,' just 'we.'"Lately, the Segals have a Chicago office investing in startups with entrepreneurs "who have the energy, communication skills and products we think will be useful," he said.He also heads up the educational properties committee on new buildings at Northwestern University and serves on the board of the University of Chicago Medical Center, looking for research projects, especially those aimed at pancreatic cancer, which has befallen close friends in and out of C&B.Sascha Bopp became CEO of C&B in 2012, with company headquarters in Northbrook, Ill.Some of its toughest competition comes from Williams-Sonoma (WSM), Restoration Hardware (RH), Pier 1 Imports (PIR) and Sur La Table.

While brick-and-mortar stores may see Amazon.com as the big, bad wolf, traditional retailers could be hurting themselves by not investing enough in mobile e-commerce before the holiday shopping season.

An eBay (EBAY) survey of holiday retail investment trends found that retailers with revenue projections of $5 million-$250 million put price, marketing and customer service over shipping- and fulfillment-related investments on their list of priorities.

Despite the ever-growing competition online, the poll found that 68% had no plans for new or continued mobile investments, even as they acknowledged mobile commerce being a primary competitive weakness.
Mobile investments, an "Achilles' heel," came in ninth on the priority scale, although 51% of retailers identified Amazon (AMZN) as a direct competitor with a lead in the mobile sales area.
"Retailers have an opportunity to win this battleground by increasing their delivery speed," said Tom Barone, eBay's North American omnichannel operations head, in a statement on the study.

"Multichannel retailers can optimize their brick-and-mortar locations as distribution points to fulfill orders closest to customer location, reducing shipping times and cost through inventory and order management solutions."
Macy's (M) has notably taken the lead in omnichannel strategy with more fulfillment points and a same-day delivery pilot program.

Meanwhile, security concerns stand at the forefront of large-scale retailers' minds — perhaps with good reason, given last holiday season's data breach at Target (TGT) and Home Depot's (HD) even larger security slip recently.
The eBay survey also noted that Canada, the U.K. and China were the top markets for global e-commerce expansion, though retailers are perhaps not taking advantage of global market opportunities.
Nordstrom (JWN) opened its first stores in Canada this year, and Target last year expanded its operations north of the border.

Stocks remained lower in early afternoon trade after turning tail on reports of Ukraine attacking a Russian convoy.

The S&P 500 slipped 0.4%, while the Nasdaq was off by just 0.3%. They had been down as much as 0.7% and 0.6%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.6%, with 26 of 30 issues in the red. Volume was tracking sharply higher across the board in the stock market today due to options expiration.

Autodesk (ADSK) tumbled 7% after staging a big downside reversal. It had been up as much as 4% after reporting better-than-expected quarterly results and raising its sales growth forecast. The stock had cleared a 57.69 buy point earlier, but it triggered the 8% sell rule after the reversal.

Dillard's (DDS) gapped down and slumped 7% on disappointing Q2 results. Before the open, the department store operator reported earnings of 80 cents a share, up a penny from a year ago. Sales slipped to nearly $1.51 billion from about $1.52 billon. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters had expected 86 cents a share on revenue of $1.53 billion. Shares hit a near three-month low.
Fellow department store operators Nordstrom (JWN) and Macy's (M) fell 3% each.

On the upside,BitAuto (BITA) added 2% for its fifth straight new high. It's now 65% past a 47.03 buy point from a cup base. The company announced a joint venture with auto retailer Lentuo International (LAS). BitAuto is on pace for a 10th straight weekly gain.

Rival Autohome (ATHM) added 2% to its best levels in more than four months. Vince Holding (VNCE) stock was up 17% Thursday as the designer of high-end apparel reported quarterly earnings that beat expectations.
The company reported Q1 revenue of $53.5 million, up 32% from the same quarter a year ago and above the consensus estimate of $48.8 million. Comparable store sales rose 11%.

Vince reported earnings per share of 4 cents, compared with one cent in the year-earlier quarter and 3 cents above estimates. Earnings for its fiscal first quarter ended May 3 were reported before the market open.
The company also raised full-year EPS and revenue targets.

Vince makes a broad range of women's and men's clothing, including cashmere sweaters, leather jackets, leggings, dresses, denim and footwear. Vince is carried in 2,350 stores across 47 countries, including Nordstrom (JWN) and Bloomingdale's, which is owned by Macy's (M) . Vince also operates 24 full-price retail locations, 6 outlet stores and its e-commerce site, vince.com.
Vince Holding stock was up 4.77 to 32.50 in late-afternoon trading in the stock market today. That is close to its all-time high of 32.76 set on Dec. 16.

"Our apparel business remains solid, our licensed women's footwear business is gaining momentum and next month we will launch children's wear and men's footwear, both new licensed categories," CEO Jill Granoff said in prepared remarks with the release.
Vince completed its initial public offering on Nov. 27. The stock priced at 20, above the high end of its 17 to 19 range, and finished the day up 43%.

Two months prior to the Vince IPO was the IPO of Burlington Stores (BURL), which priced at 17 and rose 47% on its first day of trading. Burlington, a national discount retailer of high-quality, branded apparel, now trades near 28.53.

Among the top performing stocks in the apparel manufacturing industry sector is Michael Kors Holdings (KORS). Kors launched its IPO in Dec. 2011, pricing at 20. High-end retailers such as Nordstrom (JWN) and Tiffany (TIF) have reported Q1 upside earnings surprises so far. Will Michael Kors (KORS) follow suit when it reports next week? The former "Project Runway" judge's namesake company has consistently beaten profit and sales forecasts since its December 2011 debut. Wall Street expects Michael Kors to grow fiscal Q4 earnings per share by…
Urban Outfitters' (URBN) namesake brand continues to struggle with its core teen and 20-something customers, as first-quarter results released after Monday's market close showed.

Of the company's three core divisions, Urban Outfitters dragged down overall profit as same-store sales fell 12%. Overall unit sales declined 5.2% from last year's same quarter to $277.7 million, bumping the division from No. 1 to No. 2 in sales behind Anthropologie, which reported a 10.3% increase to $295.8 million.
Per-share profit fell to 26 cents per share vs. 32 cents a year earlier, a penny below analysts' consensus estimate.

Total revenue rose 6% to $686 million, beating views by $6 million, thanks to robust results at Anthropologie and Free People. Smaller but fast-growing Free People saw revenue jump 30.4% to $108.7 million.
But all that wasn't enough to impress investors, who sent shares down nearly 5% in after hours trading.
Gross profit dropped by 209 basis points due mainly to negative comparable sales at the Urban Outfitters brand and pre-opening expenses related to new stores.
"Lower merchandise margins at the Urban Outfitters brand resulting from poor performing product also contributed to the decline," the company said.

CEO Richard Hayne said in the release that the Urban Outfitters division "is working diligently to regain its fashion footing." And in a post-earnings conference call, he said the business is "slowly improving."
But excess inventory remained from the first quarter, which will likely mean more promotional activity in the second quarter, he said.

Hayne said that Urban Outfitters would expand product offerings, including food. A massive three-story Urban Outfitters lifestyle store is slated to open in Manhattan's Herald Square next month, featuring a coffee bar, hair salon and other service-oriented features.

If the company decides to roll out more of those amenity-laden large stores, "it could be an interesting concept, but it's too early to tell if it will work out," said analyst Susan Anderson of FBR & Co.
"I'm concerned about the continued weakness going forward if we see Urban Outfitters continue to weigh down the total," she said.
Both Anthropologie and Free People cater to a somewhat older customer with higher and more disposable incomes than the young Urban Outfitters' customer, Anderson said.

One problem is that teens are spending more on tech gadgets than apparel, she says. Meanwhile, she says, Urban Outfitters faces stiff competition from lower-priced fast-fashion rivals such as H&M and Forever 21, as well as online players.

Anthropologie, which targets women 28 to 45 with a mix of casual wear, home furnishings and gifts, was one of the only brands of 26 retailers checked that was "consistently less promotional," said Morgan Stanley analyst Kimberly Greenberger in a note last week. "Anthro's outstanding performance shows differentiated brands with pitch-perfect assortments can achieve full-price sell-through even in the toughest environments."

Free People sells private-label casual apparel targeted to women 25 to 30 in name-brand stores and at wholesale. It's benefiting from strong wholesale sales (up 27% year-over-year) to department stores such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN).

A Chinese-language web site for Free People is set to launch in China this summer, and the company is preparing to open a Free People wholesale venue in mainland China, Hayne said in the conference call.Urban Outfitters' (URBN) namesake brand continues to struggle with its core teen and 20-something customers, as first-quarter results released after Monday's market close showed.Of the company's three core divisions, Urban Outfitters dragged down overall profit as same-store sales fell 12%. Overall unit sales declined 5.2% from last year's same quarter to $277.7 million, bumping the division from No. 1 to No. 2 in sales behind Anthropologie, which reported a 10.3% increase to $295.8 million.Per-share profit fell to 26 cents per share vs. 32 cents a year earlier, a penny below analysts' consensus estimate.Total revenue rose 6% to $686 million, beating views by $6 million, thanks to robust results at Anthropologie and Free People. Smaller but fast-growing Free People saw revenue jump 30.4% to $108.7 million.But all that wasn't enough to impress investors, who sent shares down nearly 5% in after hours trading.Gross profit dropped by 209 basis points due mainly to negative comparable sales at the Urban Outfitters brand and pre-opening expenses related to new stores."Lower merchandise margins at the Urban Outfitters brand resulting from poor performing product also contributed to the decline," the company said.CEO Richard Hayne said in the release that the Urban Outfitters division "is working diligently to regain its fashion footing." Stock futures eased lower ahead of Friday's open, as the dollar gained and Q4 GDP data came in below expectations.Dow futures slipped 17.2 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were off 2.3 points. Nasdaq futures shifted from gains to a 1.5-point loss an hour before the start of regular trade.Stock Market TodayThe stock market today starts with the Nasdaq steering toward its worst week since October, down 3.2% through Thursday. The S&P 500 opens with a 2.5% loss for the week. Both indexes are testing support at their 50-day moving averages while toting a hefty count of seven distribution days each.The Nasdaq may be gathering itself to again challenge resistance at the 5000 level. But maintaining support at the 50-day line will be the crucial test on Friday.Economic NewsThe Commerce Department reported its estimate for Q4 GDP growth was 2.2%, unchanged from prior estimates, but below economist projections for an upward revision to 2.4%. The GDP price deflator inflation gauge held steady, up 0.1%, in line with expectations.A final reading on March consumer sentiment is expected from the University of Michigan at 10 a.m. ET. Fed Chairwoman Janet Yellen is scheduled to speak in San Francisco, beginning at 3:45 p.m. ET.StocksOlin (OLN) rocketed 20% higher on news that Dow Chemical (DOW) would merge its chlorine operations with Olin. The companies expect the deal, valued at $5 billion, to form an industry leader in chloralkali processing, producing vinyl, chlorinated organics and epoxy.Dow shares rose 6% in premarket trade. Olin had pulled back below a 15-month high after briefly clearing a long-term consolidation. Dow has been consolidating since September.Restoration Hardware (RH) slumped more than 4% ahead of the opening bell. The Corte Madera, Calif.-based chain reported late Thursday a narrow Q4 earnings beat and sales in line with expectations. Q1 guidance was below analyst targets. The stock has been forming a base-on-base cup, ending Thursday back above its 10-week line of support.Yahoo (YHOO) added nearly 2% after its late Thursday announcement of a $2 billion share buyback initiative. The company reported the new program was in addition to the $726 million in buybacks still active under its previous plan.Morgan Stanley launched coverage on the stock with an overweight rating and a 55 price target. Yahoo shares have been working to retake their 10-week moving average, within a four-month consolidation.OverseasChina's markets ended relatively flat on Friday after a week that left the Shanghai Composite up 2% and Hong Kong's Hang Seng index with a 2.7% gain. Tokyo's Nikkei 225 dipped 1% on Friday to end the week little changed.Leading indexes in Paris and Frankfurt were up nearly 1%. London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.3% loss near midday. For the week, the CAC-40 in Paris and Frankfurt's DAX were tracking toward 1% losses. The FTSE 100 traded 2.1% below last Friday's close.Currencies/CommoditiesThe dollar gained on the yen and sent the euro back below 1.09. Oil pulled back, almost 2% for the U.S. benchmark West Texas Intermediate crude, to below $51, and 1% for Europe's Brent crude, to below $59.

Even though the market bounced back from recent losses, the number of new highs was again slim Friday. Some of the best performers that hit new highs Friday were department store operators. Dillard's (DDS) ramped up 14.40, or 15%, to 111.00 in huge turnover. The stock hit an all-time high and closed 18% past a 94.38 buy point from a…

Wal-Mart Stores on Thursday said harsh winter weather cooled spending at its stores, leading to weaker-than-expected first-quarter earnings. But its challenges are far more than seasonal: U.S. same-store sales fell for a fifth straight quarter. The world's largest retailer also gave weak guidance. Earnings slipped 3.5% to $1.10 a share, the second straight quarterly drop after several years of increases.…

Despite the threat of competition from Apple (AAPL), wearable device maker Fitbit (FIT) saw its share price close higher Tuesday after an analyst initiated coverage on the stock, while Time Warner (TWX) and American Express (AXP) both had their price targets cut. Pacific Crest started Fitbit with an overweight rating and a 47 price target. Fitbit's stock rose 3.25% to…

Long-struggling J.C. Penney (JCP) surged 7% Friday after it beat analysts' earnings and revenue views for its second quarter ended Aug. 1, a stark contrast to disappointing results posted by Macy's (M) on Wednesday. Plano, Texas-based J.C. Penney still lost money — 41 cents per share on an adjusted basis — but it was 7 cents better than analysts had…
Stocks opened narrowly mixed on Friday, as the currency effects stirred by China early in the week settled and oil prices imposed some mild upward pressure on the market.
The Dow Jones industrial average rose 0.2%, the S&P 500 added 0.1% and the Nasdaq was effectively flat in early action.
Trading got off to a soft start in the stock market today, with volume down 11% on the Nasdaq and 12% on the NYSE.

Oil prices were mixed, with West Texas Intermediate up more than 1%, and Brent crude down a fraction. WTI was tracking toward a steep loss for the week, while Brent was up about 1%. Energy stocks will be keeping an eye out for Baker Hughes' weekly rig count, which is due out at 1 p.m. ET.

The Labor Department reported earlier producer prices rose 0.2% in July, up 0.3% minus energy and food. That was slightly above expectations and below June's 0.4% gain — showing inflation continuing to run below the 2% pace the Fed says would trigger a rate increase.

Industrial production popped 0.6% in July, the Federal Reserve reported, while downgrading June's increase to 0.1% from 0.2%. Consensus views looked for a 0.4% jump in July. Capacity utilization eased slightly to 78% vs. 78.4% in June and forecasts for 78.1%.
August consumer sentiment cooled, putting the University of Michigan's Consumer Sentiment Index at 92.2 for the month, down from 93.1. and disappointing expectations for an increase to 93.5.
In stocks, Nordstrom (JWN) led the S&P 500 index, followed by a long list of energy and oil-related companies. DuPont (DD) led the Dow with a 1.4% gain.

Chip equipment makers were under some early pressure after Applied Materials (AMAT) reported fiscal Q3 earnings in line with consensus expectations, but revenue and Q4 guidance below forecasts. Applied dropped 3%, deepening its five-month correction. Smaller peer ASML Holding (ASML) also fell 3%, setting a new low in its two-month consolidation.

A weak Q2 earnings report didn't keep China-based WuXi Pharmatech (WX) from surging 5% at the open. A management group landed a $3.3 billion deal to buy the provider of clinical trials for drugmakers, in a deal that would take the company off the U.S. stock market. The company gave no timeline for the $46-per share deal to be completed. The gain punched the stock back above its 50-day moving average, leaving it just below its mid-May high.

Three out of five leaders opened lower on the IBD 50 list. CyberArk Software (CYBR) led the upside after Wells Fargo upgraded the stock to outperform from market perform. Shares remain below their 10-week moving average in a two-month consolidation and below a prior buy point of 69.10.

Losses were narrow, with Tesoro's (TSO) 1% slip being the deepest cut. Stock futures narrowed early losses abruptly approaching the starting bell on Friday, while overseas markets continued to trade lower. Dow futures showed an 83.8-point decline, vs. a 153.8-point tumble an hour earlier.

Nasdaq 100 futures halved their hour-earlier loss to trade 17 points below fair market value. S&P 500 futures were 12.3 points lower, improved from a 20-point loss. Small caps remained under pressure, although Russell 2000 futures eased from their early loss to a 7.8-point decline.

The stock market today gets rolling with the S&P 500 below its converged 50- and 200-day moving averages and the Nasdaq below its 50-day line only. The market posted three days of healthy gains through Wednesday, which also included the Federal Reserve's launch of an interest rate tightening cycle. That's big news, and a big hurdle for the market to clear.

While Friday's premarket action was not encouraging, the Nasdaq does open the session with a 1.4% gain for the week, the S&P 500 is ahead 1.5%, and both indexes have gained in nine of the past 11 weeks.

The economic calendar closes out the week on a quiet note, with only the preliminary reading on U.S. services due out from researcher Markit at 9:45 a.m. ET, and regional surveys expected from the Atlanta Federal Reserve Bank at 10 a.m. and from the Kansas City Federal Reserve at 11 a.m. Baker Hughes (BHI) releases its weekly rig count data at 1 pm.

About half of the Dow's 30 stocks moved lower, the other half remained flat in premarket trade. Johnson & Johnson (JNJ), Boeing (BA) and Chevron (CVX) dipped more than 1%. DuPont (DD) was the sole gainer, up 0.6%.
Several late-season earnings reports whipped up some action before the bell.

CarMax (KMX) dived 13% before the open, after reporting its third-quarter sales and earnings stopped short of analysts estimates. Same-store-sales rose 0.8%, vs. expectations for a 2% increase. The stock has been scooping out a consolidation in tight trade since June.

Homebuilder Lennar (LEN) rose more than 1% as its fiscal Q4 earnings easily beat consensus views. Revenue growth stopped just short of forecasts, but new home deliveries rose 10% and orders for even newer homes jumped 20%. Lennar shares have been in a gradually weakening consolidation since August.
Handheld device maker BlackBerry (BBRY) grabbed a 6% gain. The Ontario, Canada, firm reported not-as-bad-as-expected Q3 sales and losses.

Among leaders, open source software developer Red Hat (RHT) jumped more than 6% to lead the IBD 50 list. The Raleigh, N.C., company late Thursday delivered Q3 revenue and earnings above consensus forecasts. Management's Q4 revenue guidance was above, earnings guidance was below, analyst consensus views. The stock has been working to retake its 50-day moving average, and ended Thursday 3% below an 81.59 cup-base buy point.

Qihoo 360 Technology (QIHU) climbed almost 2% after finally inking a deal to be taken private by a group of investors led by company chairman Zhou Hongyi for $9.3 billion. Zhou had proposed the deal earlier in the year, before markets in China slumped into a serious correction.

Oil prices slipped — West Texas Intermediate crude shed more than 1% to below $35 a barrel and down just over 3% for the week. Brent crude was a fraction lower, just below $37 and down almost 3% on the week. Gold rose a fraction, still standing tight near the $1,055 per ounce level. Copper futures popped 3%, leaving prices effectively level for the week.

Overseas, markets were broadly lower Friday but trading higher for the week. Japan's Nikkei 225 in Tokyo toppled 1.9%, leaving the index with a 1.3% loss for the week. The Shanghai Composite ended flat Friday and up 4.2% on the week. Hong Kong's Hang Seng ended Friday down 0.5%, but with a weekly gain of 1.4%.

In Europe, stocks were under pressure near midday — the Cac-40 in Paris was off 1.3%. Frankfurt's DAX dipped 0.8% and London's FTSE 100 showed a 0.7% decline. A company's stock price doesn't set a new high every session by accident — something must be going right for so many investors to swoop in day after day. For Ulta Beauty (ULTA), a lot of things are going right. The company operates the largest chain of beauty supply stores in the U.S., with nearly 800 locations in 48 states.…

Stocks finished high in the day's range Friday as the indexes held above key support lines. The Nasdaq scored a 0.5% gain after being down 0.6% in the morning. The S&P; 500 added 0.2%, and the IBD 50 0.6%. Volume fell across the board. The S&P; 500 again held above its 50-day moving average, an area which the big-cap index…

As the retail first-quarter earnings train moves full speed ahead this week, investors will get an idea of how high-end players Tiffany & Co. (TIF) and Williams-Sonoma (WSM) fared during the harsh winter when they report results on Wednesday.If followers are on the money, the two retailers likely saw both sales and earnings heat up during the quarter as consumers braved the cold weather and stepped up the pace of spending.Luxury consumers have been reaping the benefits of stock-market gains and increased home values, which have helped buoy spending at retailers that cater to this crowd — retailers like Williams-Sonoma and Tiffany.Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect upscale jeweler Tiffany to see earnings rise 11% from a year earlier to 78 cents a share when it reports before the opening bell Wednesday. That would follow a 5% rise during the holiday fourth quarter. Sales are seen increasing 6.6% to $955.63 million. That would be up from a 5% increase in the prior quarter.High-end home-goods retailer Williams-Sonoma is seen showing a 7% increase in Q1 earnings to 44 cents a share when it deliver results after the close Wednesday. Analysts expect it to report a 6% increase in sales to $941.88 million.The high-end retail segment also includes players like upscale department store operator Nordstrom (JWN), which beat Q1 earnings views Thursday. Fashion house Michael Kors (KORS) and home furnishings retailer Restoration Hardware (RH) also cater to upscale consumers.Williams-Sonoma is likely getting a lift from the rise in home improvement spending amid the continued recovery in the housing market.Other members of IBD's Retail/Wholesale-Jewelry group, where Tiffany operates, include Signet Jewelers (SIG) and Fossil Group (FOSL).

The team at Vince Holding wasted no time getting its high-end contemporary fashion brand all glammed up with new products and categories after hitting the Wall Street runway late last year.Vince is a premium clothing brand known for its collection of everyday luxury essentials for women — from slouchy cashmere sweaters and understated leather jackets for colder temperatures to flowy silk blouses and linen pants for the warm seasons.Since going public in November, Vince (VNCE) has woven a new pattern for growth, which includes expanding its product offerings into new categories such as handbags. The idea is to evolve into a lifestyle brand and strengthen its position with the company's wholesale partners, including upscale department stores such as Neiman Marcus, Nordstrom (JWN) and Saks Fifth Avenue (owned by Canada's Hudson's Bay (HBC), as well as its own namesake retail stores.Men And Children NextIn addition to women's clothing, which accounts for about 85% of sales, Vince offers women's footwear through a licensing arrangement and is about to launch men's footwear with the same licensing partner, Brown Shoe (BWS). The line will come out in July, according to WWD.com.Vince also plans to launch children's apparel through a licensing partner in this year's second half. Early next year, the company plans to launch a handbag collection and other accessories."This is a company that starts with a very distinct point of view in apparel, which today makes up the majority of its business," said Piper Jaffray analyst Erinn Murphy."It's taking that everyday luxury aesthetic and pushing it into different categories," she said. "The biggest opportunity is their next big launch of handbags and accessories in early 2015."The move into handbags and accessories would put Vince in a market between players like "jet-set" lifestyle brand Michael Kors Holdings (KORS) and traditional European luxury players such as Celine and Louis Vuitton, Murphy adds.Murphy says that Vince is positioned to fare well in this category. It's a premium brand that's priced closer to luxury than so-called "accessible luxury," she says, with sweaters from around $225 to $400, leather jackets at $995 and tops from $100 to $200."What's unique about its positioning is it's taking what we believe is white space in the handbag market," said Murphy.She expects Vince's handbags to be priced between $700 to $1,000 in department stores, which she says would be a "sweet spot."There are few brands around that price point, she says, which means Vince could capture not only the "trade-up consumer but the trade-down consumer."That price would compare with handbags priced at around $300 to $400, where there are many competitors — such as Michael Kors, Coach (COH), Tory Burch and Kate Spade (KATE).Sweet Spot In PricingThe luxury end of the market is priced between $1,200 and $3,000.As Vince extends into accessories, it has a "good opportunity" in that space, Murphy adds."It already has a captive audience in the premium wholesale market domestically because of how well it's performing in women's apparel," she said.Murphy says that Vince prevails as the No. 1 contemporary apparel brand in Nordstrom, Saks and Neiman Marcus.Vince has been faring handsomely on the financial front with its current lineup of products. In its fourth quarter ended Feb. 1, its first as a public company, earnings grew 15% to 23 cents a share. Sales grew 21% to $87.8 million.Analysts surveyed by Thomson Reuters expect earnings to rise 21% to 88 cents a share in 2015. They see a 30% gain in 2016 and a 13% increase in 2017.Prior to the IPO and related restructuring transactions, Vince Holding was a diversified apparel company operating a broad portfolio of fashion brands, including Vince. As a result of the IPO and the related restructuring transaction, the non-Vince businesses were separated out, and Vince became the sole operating business of Vince Holding.Management is eying several growth drivers for the company in addition to expansion into new product categories.Covering New TerritoryAs of March 27, Vince had 28 stores in the U.S., 22 of which are full-price stores and six of which are outlet stores. It's on track to open six to eight new stores in the 2014 fiscal year, with a "strong pipeline for 2015 and beyond," said CEO Jill Granoff on the fourth-quarter conference call.Murphy estimates that Vince could grow its retail-store base domestically to 100 over time.As of Feb. 1, Vince products were sold to consumers via about 2,300 points of distribution through its wholesale partners.Vince's U.S. wholesale business represented 71% of sales in fiscal 2013, and international wholesale represented 8%.In fiscal 2013, Vince opened 90 new shop-in-shops globally in the wholesale channel, and it expects to open more."Given the success" of its shop-in-shop investments last year, it's planning to open an additional 15 to 25 domestic shops in fiscal 2014, to bring the total at the end of fiscal year to 26 to 36 domestic shops, Granoff said on the call.On the product front, the company is looking to expand its existing categories with an "increased focus" on outerwear and dresses, said Granoff. It's also planning to launch an "elevated" product assortment in its men's business in the fall.Vince is also pursuing international expansion, which includes opening free-standing stores.The company recently opened its second Vince store in Istanbul, Turkey, with its distribution partner. Vince is also actively looking to lease its first international showroom in Paris to further build the brand's European business, Granoff said.William Blair & Co. analyst Amy Noblin called Vince a "rapidly growing accessible-luxury brand" in her initiation report on the company.She said it's "well positioned" to capitalize on three trends including the "growth in the number of and wealth of global luxury consumers; a designer customer that is trading down; and consumers increasingly cross-shopping and mixing higher- and lower-end merchandise."Noblin says the Vince brand has developed a "cult following" for its everyday luxury essential products."The brand differentiates itself through a clean, modern and somewhat timeless aesthetic that is comfortable and effortless," she wrote.

Macy's (M) reported slightly better-than-expected earnings Wednesday morning, but sales unexpectedly dipped for a second straight quarter due to harsh winter weather. The retail giant, which announced a 25% dividend hike, said business improved in April. Macy's earnings rose 9% from a year earlier to 60 cents a share, 1 cent above forecasts by analysts polled by Thomson Reuters. That…

Investors will get an idea of how the harsh winter weather impacted consumer spending when Macy's (M) and several other retail giants report earnings this week.If followers are on target, top department-store operator Macy's saw a slowing of earnings growth from the past two quarters and a bit of an uptick in sales growth compared with the fourth quarter's gain. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters expect Macy's to post a 7.3% increase in earnings from a year earlier to 59 cents a share when it reports first-quarter results before the open on Wednesday. That would be a slowdown from the double-digit gains it saw the prior two quarters. They see sales rising 1.3% to $6.47 billion, compared with a 2% decline in the fourth quarter.Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) will report earnings before the opening bell on Thursday. Analysts expect the world's largest retailer to see earnings rise 1% from a year earlier to $1.15 a share. That would be an improvement from the fourth quarter's 4% earnings decline.Analysts forecast that revenue will rise 2% to $116.249 billion. That would be the same growth that Wal-Mart saw in the prior three quarters.Thursday will be a busy one for major retailers. Value department stores Kohl's (KSS) and J.C. Penney (JCP), as well as upscale Nordstrom (JWN), all report earnings that day. Kohl's and Nordstrom are expected to report modest year-over-year EPS declines. JCPenney should post its ninth straight quarterly loss, with many more forecast going forward.Kohl's reports before Thursday's open, while Nordstrom and J.C. Penney release results after the market close.

Are men becoming fashionistas?
Not exactly. But sales of men's clothing are growing faster than women's. And man, they've really needed pants, overcoats and socks.
Total men's apparel U.S. retail sales grew 5% to $60.8 billion in 2013 vs. a year earlier, thanks in large part to double-digit gains in sales of outerwear, pants and socks.
But guys have a long way to go to catch up with spending by the ladies. While the women's apparel market grew by only 4% last year, sales totaled $116.4 billion, or more than double the men's total.

Sales of men's pants rose 12% to $4.8 billion, and socks grew by 14% to $2.8 billion. The only one of the 13 categories tracked by the market-research group NPD in men's apparel to see dollar sales decline was men's tops, with a 2% decrease.

"Innovation and men's perception of fashion contributed to an increase in spending in 2013," said Marshal Cohen, chief industry analyst for NPD. Another notable reason for the rise included colder than usual weather conditions, which helped the sales of men's outerwear grow 12%.

Most channels benefitted from total men's apparel sales in 2013. Strong sock and pants sales helped drive an increase at specialty stores, while outerwear sales trended upward at department stores and mass merchants.

Department stores, off-price retailers, warehouse clubs and mass merchants all saw a 6% rise in dollar sales of men's clothing in 2013. Likely beneficiaries of the uptick in men's clothing sales were department-store operators such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), and discounters such as Target (TGT), Wal-Mart Stores (WMT) and Costco Wholesale (COST).

Website purchases, which represented 14% of men's apparel sales, saw some of the highest growth for the year, increasing 19% over 2012. Meanwhile, the average price of an in-store purchase grew 3% for men's apparel, while online prices declined 7%.

"To remain competitive, brick-and-mortar retailers must step up their game," said Cohen. "They need to disregard antiquated marketing and sales strategies, and adjust their tactics to better accommodate the whims of online shoppers, including the development of more dynamic pricing models, enhancing selections and addressing convenience."Are men becoming fashionistas?Not exactly. Deutsche Bank downgraded Macy's (M) to sell from buy and slashed its price target to 63 from 71 as the nationwide department store is seen unable to drive up same-store sales growth.

"We are downgrading M to Sell from Buy as we lower our estimates below the Street and guidance to reflect low confidence that the company can bust out of its SSS rut, sales deleverage, and increasing pressure from shipping, health care, and retirement expenses," said Deutsche Bank analyst Paul Trussell in a note.
Macy's shares fell 2.3% to 68.27 in the stock market today. The stock gapped down out of buy range but was still trading above its 50-day line as of late Monday morning.

Despite the downgrade, Trussell acknowledges that selling some of its real estate could unlock value for the company. Macy's was reportedly under some pressure earlier in the month to put up for sale its flagship New York City storefront, among other assets, in a sale-leaseback.
"We acknowledge that unlocking the real estate portfolio could drive significant value and represents a key risk to our Sell rating," said Trussell.
But he believes the odds of Macy's utilizing a REIT — particularly with its flagship stores — are low.
Sears Holdings (SHLD) has engaged in real estate joint ventures with Macerich (MAC), General Growth Properties (GGP) and Simon Property Group (SPG) this year.
Rival department stores Nordstrom (JWN) shares fell 1% to 75.44, while JC Penney (JCP) fell 0.3% to 8.80.
Follow Elaine Low on Twitter: @IBD_ELow.

Stocks climbed out of the starting gate Thursday, as investors looked past soft unemployment and jobs data.
The Nasdaq pumped up 0.5%. The Dow Jones industrial average and the S&P 500 added 0.2% each.
Trade dipped 4% on the NYSE but rose 8% on the Nasdaq vs. action at the same time Wednesday.
The stock market today felt some early drag from data showing a larger-than-expected rise in weekly unemployment claims.

The Labor Department also reported 4.74 million job openings in its September Job Openings and Labor Turnover Survey. That was down from an upwardly revised 4.85 million for August, disappointing expectations for a mild decline to 4.8 million. The quits number increased, however, showing more workers comfortable enough to leave their jobs. And the number of hires hit 5 million for the month, its highest since December 2007.

In stocks, among the morning's biggest gainers and losers, DreamWorks Animation (DWA) sketched out a 16% advance at the open. News reports said the company was discussing a possible takeover by toy maker Hasbro (HAS) .
J.C. Penney (JCP) dropped 8%, as revenue slipped vs. expectations for an increase, and despite a narrower-than-expected Q3 loss.

Wal-Mart (WMT) broke character and snapped up 4% to a new high after its third-quarter results surprised analysts. A penny per share increase topped expectations for a 2-cent decline. Revenue rose a much better-than-expected 3%. Overall same-store sales rose 0.5%, above forecasts, boosted by a surprise 5.5% leap in comparable sales at Wal-Mart's small format Neighborhood Store chain. The move sent shares above their November 2011 high.

Data storage powerhouse NetApp (NTAP) slumped 4%, despite narrowly topping third-quarter earnings expectations. Revenue was flat however, and just short of analyst estimates. Q4 earnings guidance came in just below consensus views. The stock is in the eighth week of a cup-with-handle base.

Leading stocks set off on a positive note, with nearly four in every five IBD 50 stocks gaining ground at the open. Gains were on the thin side, with AmTrust Financial Services (AFSI) up almost 2% and leading the early advance. The workers compensation and specialty insurer is 12% above a 46.12 buy point after a couple of volatile weeks.

Gilt Groupe is an online retailer launched in 2007 that sells luxury goods at a…
When it comes to shopping, "omnichannel" is the name of the game these days, with retailers aiming to build a seamless experience between online shops and brick-and-mortar locations.

But outside of a few companies that are ahead of the curve, such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), most are still trying to figure out what omnichannel even means as they test various e-commerce strategies. And Twitter's (TWTR) launch of a "buy" button Monday only adds to the pressure.
"Everyone's playing catch-up," William Blair analyst Amy Noblin told IBD, adding that it's still "early innings on omni."
"It's easy to spend money; it's less easy to spend effectively. It's one thing to say 'We need to invest in omnichannel.' It's anoth er thing to know what it really is."

Based in Seattle, i.e. Amazon's (AMZN) backyard, Nordstrom has been at the forefront of adapting to an increasingly Web-centric retail environment, said Noblin. Excellent customer service, early website development and its embrace of in-store technology have helped set the department store chain apart, she said.
Nordstrom's Online Shopping

Perhaps more notably than others, Nordstrom has been investing in online properties, from its 2011 acquisition of flash-sale site HauteLook, to its partnership with social-shopping site Wanelo, to its recent $350 million acquisition of personalized men's shopping service Trunk Club.
Despite praise for its online moves, being an early adopter like Nordstrom has a price.
The company is allocating $1.2 billion of its $3.9 billion in planned 2014-18 capital expenditures to technology. Such spending is also weighing on its earnings outlook.
"We like the Trunk Club acquisition but are fatigued with JWN investment spending," said Macquarie analyst Liz Dunn in an Aug. 14 research note.

Fellow department store chain Macy's has found success in an omnichannel approach with a focus not just on tech but on order fulfillment, having this year turned every one of its department stores into mini-fulfillment centers.
Items are shipped from the nearest Macy's, be it a mega center or a local retail outlet, using a "search and send" algorithm.
"Macy's seems to have made a concerted investment in backend technologies," Retail Metrics President Ken Perkins said.

"Given the tech out there, it's amazing more retailers haven't done this," he added, referring to inventory management and control systems that allow retailers to know where a product is across the entire company.

Tactics like Macy's are no doubt designed to compete with e-commerce pure plays like Amazon, as the online behemoth develops fulfillment centers closer to major cities and expands same-day delivery capabilities.
Wal-Mart Ramps Up

But other retailers have yet to fully refine their e-commerce strategies. Wal-Mart (WMT) recently had to lower its full-year earnings guidance due in part to investments in e-commerce and mobile, though global e-commerce sales jumped 24% in Q2.

"Initially, Wal-Mart was slow to adapt but they've ramped up their game, and they have the resources — more than other retailers do — to build out a seamless experience," said Perkins. Still, "They have a long way to go."

Having built new fulfillment centers to deal with online orders and making quiet e-commerce investments along the way, the big-box retailer is performing "probably above average" in the online realm compared to other sellers, said ISI Group analyst Michael Montani.

"The growth rate is good, but the basis is so small that to move the needle with dot-com is a challenge," said Montani. "I don't question their moves (and) I think they're doing a good job, but it takes time."
Shopping Via/Vs. Smartphone
Just as retailers are starting to integrate online shopping more effectively, other trends are already threatening to upend the landscape again.
Globally, 44% of people surveyed by Nielsen use mobile phones for online shopping. The share is 52% in Asia-Pacific, 48% in Latin America, 33% in Europe and 27% in North America.
"The use of these devices introduces all sorts of questions for retailers and manufacturers alike," said Nielsen President of Strategic Initiatives John Burbank in a press release.
Retailers are struggling with in-store customers, armed with smartphones, comparing prices and evaluating products in showrooms only to buy them online.

But perhaps most concerning, at least for retailers hoping to nab the coveted teen and 20-something markets, isn't shopping via smartphone but the desire for a new smartphone over shopping altogether.

"(Teens are) far more concerned about what kind of smartphone they have than what they're wearing," Perkins said.When it comes to shopping, "omnichannel" is the name of the game these days, with retailers aiming to build a seamless experience between online shops and brick-and-mortar locations.But outside of a few companies that are ahead of the curve, such as Macy's (M) and Nordstrom (JWN), most are still trying to figure out what omnichannel even means as they test various e-commerce strategies. It's one thing to say 'We need to invest in omnichannel.' It's anoth er thing to know what it really is."Based in Seattle, i.e. Amazon's (AMZN) backyard, Nordstrom has been at the forefront of adapting to an increasingly Web-centric retail environment, said Noblin. After the big splash that it made when it last reported in June, will fashion-brand owner Vince Holding impress again when it reports quarterly results early Wednesday? Investors certainly seem positive. Shares this past week jumped nearly 5% to 36.30, putting Vince (VNCE) 81.5% above its November initial public offering price of 20. As Googling an elusive button-down shirt becomes too much work for some shoppers — let alone making the trek to a brick-and-mortar mall — retailers are looking to convert "likes" and "favorites" into actual buys.
Target (TGT) on Wednesday adopted Curalate's software Like2Buy for its Target and Target Style Instagram feeds, in the hopes that users will turn a casual scroll into a shopping spree.
Target has 319,000 Instagram followers and Target Style has 375,000, which means nearly 700,000 potential online customers.

"We frequently get questions from our guests who are excited about something they see on the platform and want to know how to purchase it — this tool helps us address this need," said Target's PR and social media VP Dustee Jenkins in a release.
Instagram, Facebook's (FB) photo-only social-media platform, has around 200 million monthly active users and 1.6 billion "likes" daily.
Users who see a must-have item in their feeds can click the Like2Buy link on Target's Instagram profile page, where they'll be led away from the app and toward the shopping source.
Nordstrom (JWN) also adopted Like2Buy for its Instagram feed this week. The nationwide department store retailer has over 532,000 Instagram followers.

Amid an often challenging retail environment, retailers such as Nordstrom have been doing their best to stay abreast of e-commerce pure plays like Amazon (AMZN). More recently, Nordstrom acquired men's online personal shopper Trunk Club and formed a partnership with social-shopping site Wanelo.
"We continue to believe Nordstrom is the most forward-thinking retailer we cover when it comes to emerging models in retail," said Macquarie analyst Liz Dunn in a July 31 research note.

"The company is investing like a venture capital firm but has the added benefit of being able to use the knowledge and the models that it acquires to augment its own multichannel capabilities and to better serve its customer base," she said.
"Over time, we would expect this to drive accelerated top-line growth and be reflected in the earnings multiple."
Target shares fell 0.9% and Nordstrom dipped 0.1% in the stock market today.

Discount retailer Kohl's is in buying range after showing surprising strength following a mixed earnings report. Kohl's (KSS) stock is still in the 5% buy zone from Wednesday's breakout past a 58.30 buy point. Volume was a little shy of the 40% jump that signals a healthy breakout. The stock has advanced since Aug. 13, the day before Kohl's second-quarter…
Dillard's (DDS) stock fell 5.3% to 109.48 on the stock market today after reporting second-quarter earnings and revenue that missed expectations, in part because of sagging home and furniture sales.

For the quarter ending Aug. 2, the Arkansas-based department store earned 80 cents a share, up 1.3% from the same quarter the previous year. Analysts polled by Thomson Reuters estimated earnings of 86 cents a share.
Revenue slipped 2.7% to $1.475 billion, missing views for $1.532 billion.
Total merchandise sales, which exclude Dillard's construction business, inched up 0.2% to $1.461 billion.
Comparable-store sales increased 1%.
Dillard's said that sales were weakest in the home and furniture category, while juniors' and children's apparel sales were strongest.
On Thursday, value department store Kohl's (KSS) Q2 EPS improved slightly, but sales fell. Kohl's shares fell 0.4% to 56.66 Friday.
Nordstrom (JWN) followed the Macy's (M) Wednesday results — both missed sales estimates. Nordstrom shares fell 4% to 65.98, while Macy's shares fell 0.8% to 57.37 Friday.
J.C. Penney's (JCP) results topped views, sending shares up 4% Thursday, but Friday's downward movement has reversed almost all of that gain.

Online retail sales will hit $370 billion by 2017, said a Forrester Research report, vs. the $263.3 billion in 2013 e-commerce sales reported by the Census Bureau. Meanwhile, with…
Early gains faded into losses late Friday morning amid reports of fighting between Ukraine and Russia. But the major indexes stuck to solid gains so far for the week.
The Dow Jones industrial average slumped 0.4%, hamstrung by Merck's (MRK) 1% loss. The S&P 500 shed 0.3% and the Nasdaq dipped 0.1%.

The stock market today set out seeming largely unswayed by mixed early news and data reports. But early optimism eroded, and options expirations drove volume higher. Late morning trade remained up 92% on the NYSE and 20% higher on the Nasdaq, compared with action at the same time Thursday.

Monster Beverage (MNST) (up 30%), Applied Materials (AMAT) (up 5%) and Kinder Morgan (KMI) (up 4%) continued to hold the top spots on the S&P 500. Nordstrom (JWN) posted the index's largest loss, gapping down to a 4% loss in heavy trade after reporting results late Thursday.

Jazz Pharmaceuticals (JAZZ) gained 3% to move to the head of the IBD 50 list. Shares had initially punched up 4%, putting the stock back above its 50-day line. The stock had faded more than 8% below a 156.44 cup-with-handle buy point, negating the breakout. If it retakes that buy point in solid trade it remains a valid entry.

Lithia Motors (LAD) dropped 3% in fast trade, slipping back to retest its 50-day moving average.
